TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, which is a Bill to amend the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and for related purposes. The main thrust of this Bill is that it clarifies and strengthens the provisions of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983. Under the World Heritage Convention, to which Australia is a signatory, an area needs to fulfil one or more of the following four criteria in order to be placed on the World Heritage List:

SPEECH.PARA: (i) be an outstanding example representing the major stages of the earth's evolutionary history; or

(ii) be an outstanding example representing significant ongoing geological processes, biological evolution and man's interaction with his natural environment; as distinct from the periods of the earth's development, this focuses upon ongoing processes in the development of communities, of plants and animals, landforms and marine areas and freshwater bodies; or

(iii) contain superlative natural phenomena, formations or features, for instance, outstanding examples of the most important ecosystems, areas of exceptional natural beauty, or exceptional combinations of natural and cultural elements; or

(iv) contain the most important and significant natural habitats where there threatened species of animals or plants of outstanding universal value from the point of view of science or conservation still survive.

Australia already has seven areas on the World Heritage List. These areas are: the Great Barrier Reef, the Lord Howe Island group, Kakadu National Park, the Willandra Lakes region of New South Wales, Uluru National Park-that is, Ayers Rock and Mount Olga-western Tasmania's wilderness national parks and the Australian east coast temperate and sub-tropic rainforest parks. However, it is a particular principle of the Convention that it is not intended to provide for the protection of all properties of great interest, importance or value, but only those exhibiting the most outstanding features from an international viewpoint.

The World Heritage Convention was adopted by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation general conference in 1972. Australia ratified the Convention in 1974 and it came into force in 1975. Besides Australia, countries which are party to the Convention include New Zealand, the United Kingdom, the United States of America and Canada. Countries which are signatories to the World Heritage Convention undertake not to damage their cultural and natural heritage deliberately and to take the necessary legal, scientific, technical, administrative and financial measures in order to protect their heritage.

Only national governments can nominate areas for World Heritage listing. The World Heritage Committee has the responsibility of determining whether an area is to be listed. Together with 20 other nations, Australia has served as a member of the Committee each year since 1976. Nominations for World Heritage listing are thoroughly investigated by the World Heritage Bureau and also by internationally acknowledged scientists who are nominated by the Bureau. The Bureau is elected by and from the World Heritage Committee at its annual meeting, and its members hold office until the following meeting of the Committee.

In the debate on this Bill, which has now proceeded over quite a few days, the coalition Opposition has expressed fears about the application of the provisions of the Bill. Senator Panizza spoke particularly about Shark Bay in Western Australia. I intend to talk more about that area later. We cannot continue in the same way as we have done in the past. That is, in the light of current knowledge and experience it can no longer be regarded as feasible to allow an owner, leaseholder or licence holder of land to do exactly as he wants with a piece of land. There are countless examples of such a restriction. For example, the owner of land in an urban area cannot build exactly what he wants on his land. Any construction must be in keeping with local building and planning regulations. In at least one Sydney suburb and at least one outer Perth suburb householders cannot cut down a tree on their land without permission. In the United Kingdom, the owner of a house that is classified as part of the National Estate-as is the case with relatives of mine in Dorchester-cannot do any alterations or refurbishments without the express permission of the relevant heritage authority. That is how it should be, because if land, whether rural or urban, is degraded and if our natural or cultural heritage is lost, not only our generation but also future generations will be the poorer. We can only own or lease for the period of our limited lifetimes.

Thank goodness we have moved on from what used to be a standard joke about Australia, to the effect that if it moves, shoot it; if it does not, cut it down or dig it out, and sell it to the lowest overseas bidder. We have indeed moved on from that position and that is why the Government has seen fit to introduce this legislation, which is supported by the Australian Democrats.

As I said previously, this legislation will clarify and strengthen the protection offered under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983. The Bill will amend the definition of `identified property' which is protected by the World Heritage Act in order to follow more closely the format of the World Heritage Convention, about which I spoke earlier. This means that property which the Commonwealth Government believes may be of World Heritage value and which is subject to an inquiry with regard to its World Heritage status will be protected against damage or destruction during the investigation. Surely that is only common sense.

The legislation makes provision also for other amendments to the World Heritage Act which will rectify problems that have arisen with its operation since its enactment in 1983. The amendments include the provision of ministerial power to appoint inspectors under the Act for the purpose of obtaining information concerning the making of proclamations and regulations or of determining possible breaches of the Act. It is proposed also that sections of the Act deemed invalid by the High Court in the Tasmanian dams case can be repealed. The provisions of the Act with regard to compensation are to be simplified. That of course is very important because if anyone is to be disadvantaged by this legislation, obviously adequate and fair compensation should be paid.

I should like to speak now about Shark Bay. That area has been referred to previously because of the possibility of World Heritage listing of that area. Because it is extremely relevant to this debate I shall quote a passage from the Shark Bay Regional Plan, which was published by the State Planning Commission and the Department of Conservation and Land Management in Perth, Western Australia., in March 1987. The document states:

In 1975 the Environmental Protection Authority recommended to the State Government that the significant land and marine conservation values of Shark Bay be conserved through a system of Nature Reserves and National Parks on land and water. These recommendations have not been implemented, although accepted by the Government of the day.

However, it has become clearer with each passing year that the environment of Shark Bay must be conserved, not only for scientific or educational interest, but also because the environment is essential to the continued economic prosperity of the region through its fishing, pastoral and tourist industries.

This need has become particularly critical since 1985, when the road to Denham from the Overlander Roadhouse on National Highway 1 was sealed and the number of visitors to the area increased dramatically.

In 1986 the Government decided that a plan should be prepared for Shark Bay which would achieve the intent of the E.P.A. recommendation, while providing for the region's development, community and conservation needs. This plan suggests how this combination can be achieved and it is significant that it has involved the co-operation through consultation of the Shark Bay community, government departments and lay groups keenly interested in the area.

This is what would be involved also in the World Heritage listing as advocated in the publication A Sustainable Future for Shark Bay: A Response to the Shark Bay Region Plan put out by the Shark Bay Action Group, representing the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Conservation Council of Western Australia. The report noted:

The Shark Bay region has been recommended for World Heritage nomination by several independent parties. The advantages that such designation would provide for the future management of Shark Bay's special areas demand solid support form regional planners in their position as community liaison experts.

The primary aim of this submission has been to collaborate on the massive task of a comprehensive response to the draft Shark Bay Region Plan prepared by the State Planning Commission and the Department of Conservation and Land Management.

I should like to allay some of the fears of Senator Panizza and other Opposition senators who have spoken in the debate. Although obviously a detailed examination and investigation is required of the physical properties of an area submitted for World Heritage listing-in the case of Shark Bay this would include both the terrestrial and the marine component-nonetheless the human component must also be considered as part of the investigation. Again I quote from the report:

In parallel to recognising the Shark Bay area's physical context and significance, the human system must also be referenced. By virtue of its unusual natural features, renowned beauty and relatively easy access, Shark Bay has demonstrated very definite emotive links with the State, National and global human community. Scientists, conservationists and holiday makers all have their legitimate concerns for the future of the area. These links have very pragmatic implications since the adoption of tourism by the local community as a major economic base. It is therefore incumbent upon our delegated public servants and decision makers to facilitate wide public input at as many stages of plan formulation as possible; to be evaluated and weighted after objective analysis of the message.

I wish to quote selectively from some of the recommendations, but before doing so I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the recommendations of the report A Sustainable Future for Shark Bay. They are recommendations (1) to (23) and they appear on pages 6, 7 and 8 of the report.
Leave granted.
The recommendations read as follows-
SHARK BAY AND WORLD HERITAGE
Recommendations and Conclusions Summary

(1) The Shark Bay region is an environmentally sensitive area which has a number of faunal and floral, geological, aesthetic and cultural attributes that make it suitable for World Heritage Listing. However, the environmental characteristics which make it worthy of consideration for the World Heritage List are threatened by a variety of human activities which, if uncontrolled, have the potential to degrade and even destroy the heritage values of the Shark Bay region. These activities include mining, grazing, sandalwood extraction, fishing, and tourism.

(2) The international significance of the Shark Bay region is recognised in the IUCN's (1982) indicative inventory of natural sites of World Heritage quality. The four criterion for including a natural property on the World Heritage List are all met by the Shark Bay area. International significance of the natural values of the region are further enhanced by the presence of fauna (including migratory birds and whale species) that are subject to international conventions and treaties concerning their conservation and the protection of their habitat.
(3) The World Heritage significance of the natural property of the Shark Bay region are also strengthened by the area's cultural values.
(4) The cultural property aspects of Shark Bay do not by themselves justify nomination to the World Heritage list.
(5) The World Heritage values of Shark Bay should neither be seen to exist nor managed in isolation from each other.

(6) The Shark Bay Region Plan (SBRP) (State Planning Commission and Department of Conservation and Land Management 1987) in its current form does not adequately provide for the protection of natural property neither does it meet the conditions of integrity for the natural property of World Heritage value in the Shark Bay area.

(7) One of the most important factors in examining the integrity of an area is related to its size and shape. The SBRP (1987) makes no mention of the problems of size and shape of the conservation areas it proposes. Furthermore, the SBRP (1987) tends to see zones of land use as isolated units rather than as an integrated structure. This is a major shortcoming of the plan and casts serious doubts as to its ability to provide for sound ecological management and for it to establish a regime of implementation which would fulfil the conditions and requirements of the World Heritage Convention.

(8) The Environmental Protection Authority's (EPA) (1975) System 9 recommendations provide a far more appropriate management strategy for the Shark Bay region, and with relatively minor modifications to allow for some of the values identified in the SBRP, should be used as the basis for World Heritage nomination.
(9) No attention is paid in the SBRP to the notion of minimal viable area. Similarly, consideration needs to be given to the provision of buffer zones.

(10) The existing salt mining operations at Useless Loop should be allowed to continue provided they do not interfere with fish nursery areas vital for the local fishing industry and the habitat of trans-equatorial migratory waders. Upon completion of the salt mining operations the land should become a national park.

(11) Proposed development of a gypsum mine on Peron Peninsula should not go ahead because both the mining site and the loading facilities would adversely reduce the conservation and recreation values of the area.

(12) Fishing practices may need to be curtailed or modified in certain instances in order to prevent either the depletion of certain populations of marine fauna, including nursery stock, and/or the degradation of certain marine habitats.

(13) The System 9 study recommended the creation of an aquatic reserve on the eastern shoreline of Shark Bay. This recommendation should be implemented with the western boundary being extended to include prawn nursery and seagrass protection as recommended in the SBRP (1987).
(14) Aquatic reserves should be declared on the western shorelines of Bernier, Dorre and Dirk Hartog Islands; and in the Freycinet Estaury, as recommended by the SBRP (1987).
(15) The waters on the northern tip of Peron Peninsula presently recommended for recreation and commercial fishing by the SBRP (1987) should be declared an aquatic reserve.

(16) The remaining area recommended as recreation and commercial fishing by the SBRP (1987) should be declared a marine park (as per the System 9 recommendations) with recreational use as its prime function, and with commercial fishing activities being carefully managed.
(17) In all the protected marine zones close attention must be given to overfishing of the fisheries resource by amateurs. A catch limit should be introduced to help achieve this goal.

(18) The pastoral industry, as it at present exists in the Shark Bay region, does not provide a basis for the management of the area along the lines required for World Heritage listing. Pastoralism's impacts are such that they threaten the integrity of the region as an ecological unit and, hence, reduce the possibilities for fulfilling the criteria for World Heritage listing.
(19) Tourism, provided it is suitably managed, is compatible with World Heritage nomination at Shark Bay. It should also produce significant economic and educational benefits.

(20) To ensure the minimum desired level of direct Commonwealth involvement in the region the management plan for a Shark Bay nomination should meet the requirements of integrity laid out by the World Heritage Committee. The SBRP does not fulfil these requirements, and any nomination of Shark Bay under the SBRP may well result in either the rejection of the nomination, placement of the nomination on the World Heritage in Danger list, or acceptance of the site subject to modification of the management plans.
(21) The following should be undertaken to ensure that legislative and management objectives of World Heritage listing are met:

(21a) The creation of State legislation to cover the area of the nomination. This legislation should be matched by the enactment of regulations at the Commonwealth level under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983. A body similar in structure to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority would be ideally suited to the particular needs of the Shark Bay area. Such a body would also provide an avenue for the channelling of Commonwealth funds to assist in the management of the region.
(21b) The establishment under legislation of a board of scientific advisers to provide a sound basis for the management of the natural and cultural property of the World Heritage site.
(21c) The establishment under legislation of a management body which would include input from Commonwealth, State and Local Government consistent with the objects of the legislation.

(22) To ensure full consideration of the implications of World Heritage nomination an independent committee of inquiry should be established to investigate the benefits and costs of listing. During the period that the committee meets no new projects should be undertaken in the Shark Bay region which would substantially damage the resources that listing would be designed to conserve.
(23) Shark Bay is clearly of World Heritage quality and steps should be taken as soon as possible to nominate the region to the World Heritage list.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I did not wish to quote selectively from the recommendations without all of them being incorporated. Recommendation (1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Shark Bay region is an environmentally sensitive area which has a number of faunal and floral, geological, aesthetic and cultural attributes that make it suitable for World Heritage Listing. However, the environmental characteristics which make it worthy of consideration for the World Heritage List are threatened by a variety of human activities which, if uncontrolled, have the potential to degrade and even destroy the heritage values of the Shark Bay region. These activities include mining, grazing, sandalwood extraction, fishing, and tourism.
The operative words in that first recommendation are `if uncontrolled'. It does not state that these activities should cease; merely that they should be managed correctly. Recommendation (10) states:

The existing salt mining operations at Useless Loop should be allowed to continue provided they do not interfere with fish nursery areas vital for the local fishing industry and the habitat of trans-equatorial migratory waders. Upon completion of the salt mining operations the land should become a national park.

That is typical of the recommendations. In other words, the recommendations are rational, sensible and take into consideration the whole area-that is, the economic and human sides of it. Recommendation (11) states:
Proposed development-
in other words, it is not going-
of a gypsum mine on Peron Peninsula should not go ahead because both the mining site and the loading facilities would adversely reduce the conservation and recreation values of the area.
What we have here are balanced recommendations. Some of them are not firm recommendations; they are recommendations for further discussion and investigation. Part of recommendation (7) states:
One of the most important factors in examining the integrity of an area is related to its size and shape. The SBRP (1987)-
that is, the Shark Bay Regional Plan of 1987-
makes no mention of the problems of size and shape of the conservation areas it proposes.
That is also an important recommendation because, as it says:

This is a major shortcoming of the plan and casts serious doubt as to its ability to provide for sound ecological management and for it to establish a regime of implementation which would fulfil the conditions and requirements of the World Heritage Convention.
Recommendation (16) states:
The remaining area recommended as recreation and commercial fishing by the SBRP (1987) should be declared a marine park-
that goes back to a 1975 Western Australian report-
with recreational use as its prime function, and with commercial fishing activities being carefully managed.
Again, that is an example of the correct sort of balance. Recommendation (19) states:
Tourism, provided it is suitably managed, is compatible with World Heritage nomination at Shark Bay. It should also produce significant economic and educational benefits.
So, unlike statements made in debate by members of the coalition Opposition, tourism is not excluded from an area which has World Heritage listing. Recommendation (22) states:

To ensure full consideration of the implications of World Heritage nomination an independent committee of inquiry should be established to investigate the benefits and costs of listing. During the period that the committee meets no new projects should be undertaken in the Shark Bay region which would substantially damage the resources that listing would be designed to conserve.
Again, that is just common sense. Finally, recommendation (23) states:
Shark Bay is clearly of World Heritage quality and steps should be taken as soon as possible to nominate the region to the World Heritage list.

Remarks made previously by Senator Panizza about the possible World Heritage listing of the Kimberleys in Western Australia are unfounded on the basis of fact or even realistic speculation. World Heritage listing of the Kimberleys would not mean that there would be fewer people, tourists or schools. It could very well mean the reverse situation, certainly regarding tourism. When I was in the Kimberleys recently I looked at two new tourist developments. One is currently under development at Cable Bay, which is close to Broome. It is a development by Lord MacAlpine. Many of the local people there feel that it is over-intensive. I think that it needs to be looked at more closely. I saw a very different type of tourist development at Cape Leveque which is under the management of a husband and wife team-white managers. They are setting up a development involving a maximum of 15 chalets dispersed throughout the area. The whole tourist development would be managed by members of the local Aboriginal community many of whom would work there. The development would be both exclusive and unique. It would probably be an expensive holiday, but those from overseas who want to do something different and very Australian would certainly find it there. They would be taught Aboriginal craft making by members of the local community and Aboriginal methods of fishing. At the same time, the area's integrity would be maintained and people would have tourist comforts. I commend that type of tourist development, which is totally sensitive to the area concerned and bears in mind the area's assets. Certainly, it is not designed to spoil them in any way.

The serious situation of pastoralists at Shark Bay needs to be taken into consideration sensitively, as we must always do when we talk about people's livelihoods-meaning, sometimes, the investment of a lifetime's savings. Only the other day I spoke to a pastoralist from the Shark Bay area who took up his lease only a few years ago. The pastoralists are sensitive to the degradation previously caused by the overstocking of animals, particularly hoofed animals, in sensitive areas and also by the adoption of European farming methods. Due to our previous ignorance and blissful unawareness-almost blissful innocence-our natural resources, which are not renewable unless we take care of them, have been seriously exploited. In Western Australia in particular we have vast tracts of land which are seriously degraded. Soil erosion and wind erosion in particular pose a very serious problem. As far as Shark Bay is concerned, only six pastoral leases are in jeopardy. Not all of the leases have actually been taken up. In some cases the land has been used as an investment. Of course, it is very important that any compensation due to any pastoralists or others in the area should be fair and more than adequate.

In conclusion, the economic and other benefits of not protecting Shark Bay are absolutely nil. To place it on Heritage listing and to meet the consequences of that placement sensibly, rationally, with sensitivity and with due regard to the local people involved, can be regarded not only as a bonus to the Shark Bay area but as a benefit to Australia as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do with the people you drive off?
—Did Senator Panizza not hear what I said earlier?
—Yes, that is why I came in here.

—I spoke a lot about that earlier. Australia is a unique island continent. Currently we are `celebrating' 200 years of European settlement. Enormous damage has been done, as I said before, during those 200 years because European farming methods have been used in fragile areas. The destruction to our east tropical rainforests in New South Wales has been an ecological disaster. Fortunately, to date we have not destroyed areas which remain off the beaten track-areas such as Shark Bay and the Kimberleys. Australia is logically an area in the world in which conservation is absolutely critical. It is still possible to save whole areas. The tourism industry has enormous potential for Australia. What do international tourists want to see? They want to see what is unique to Australia-indeed, what is unique to the world. If we destroy that, then we will destroy our tourist industry. In many of these areas there is a lot more money to be made by tourism--
—Than the pastoralists?

—Yes. The way things are going, tourism is an up and coming and very economically viable industry. Certainly as far as tourism is concerned, we do not want at Shark Bay developments such as the Observation City development at Scarborough in Western Australia. Areas such as Shark Bay and the Kimberleys in Western Australia need to be surveyed by a task force which would be composed of architects, tourist agents, conservationists, farmers, pastoralists, graziers, local people and whoever else may be concerned. World Heritage listing properly managed and controlled, as this legislation seeks to do, can only be to the benefit of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 is straight-out socialist legislation. I say that because it consolidates the Federal Government's land grab of State lands. These are lands that were vouchsafed to the States under our Constitution. The legislation absolves the Federal Government of any responsibility under its own laws and it precludes the States from any appeal to our courts should they feel aggrieved because of the actions of the Federal Government. On top of that, like all socialist legislation, this Bill has to create a new police force-which it is doing; the greenshirts they have been called-with unusual powers. The Government seeks to reintroduce the midnight knock on the door-even the midnight knock on the door on one's car. Although these people cannot search one's house, they can still knock on the door at midnight. This is why I describe the Bill as socialist legislation. It is typical of such legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Just last week Senator Walters introduced a Bill to require the Commonwealth Government to consult the owners of any property that was to be involved in World Heritage listing and to advise the owners of progress in the Federal Government's attack on them. That Bill was rejected by the Government with assistance by the Australian Democrats. I think that the people of Australia should be made well aware of the Democrats' action in doing that. I can understand this Federal Government moving ahead in its own socialist style, despite all the rebuffs it is experiencing around Australia at the moment in both State and Federal areas. It is just like this Government's brazen effrontery to persist with a Bill such as this. Not only that; in respect of the Queensland rainforest, I think this Government gave the industry six months to stop logging. Six months is not time enough to readjust in any industry. I cannot imagine the Government doing that to the automobile or textile industries. However, the Government gave the Queensland forestry industry six months to stop. That was a thoughtless, cruel and heartless action by the Federal Government. Of course, another thing the Government has done is to elevate the friction and abrasiveness between governments in Australia to the international arena. It is embarrassing for our country to have these types of arguments highlighted in the international fora.

One would think that, as a result of the speeches of many honourable senators involved in the debate on this Bill, the Government would be taking more notice of the hostility that the Bill and the World Heritage listing generally are causing in the country. I am pleased to note that now other people are waking up to this. There is a new coalition being formed in Australia of farmers, business people and other concerned groups to attack World Heritage listing, which is having a most detrimental effect on the Australian people. I notice that even the media are starting to take a new look at World Heritage listing because they realise the enormous responsibility that should be assumed by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, in regard to the enormous power he has to list areas.

I suppose that when we take the broad view we see that Australia has come through about four stages of government. First of all we had colonial government. We then developed our Constitution and moved to cooperative federalism. Then as the taxing powers went to the Federal Government we moved to the stage of coercive federalism. That was boiling along nicely. Now it appears that we have entered a stage of conniving federalism. However, a consistent theme through all the stages of government has been one of increasing federal power. The Federal Government is now attempting to bypass the people by not having referenda on these sorts of things, by bypassing the Constitution and by bypassing the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been done constitutionally.

—In the case of Queensland and the World Heritage listing of the rainforests, there was no consultation at all. It was done by fiat, by an act of the Cabinet. The Government is using the executive power of the Cabinet. This has been tested in the High Court. The High Court has agreed that the Federal Government has the power to do that. However the Government is responsible to the people at the next election-which is when Senator Cook will get his. It is becoming obvious throughout the country at the moment that power resides with the people and that they are being bypassed at the moment by a specious use of the treaty power. I do not cavil at the use of treaty powers. We have, indeed, about 1,500 Acts extant in Australia today in regard to which treaty power has been used. They mainly involve matters of international trade and commerce, international transport, the airlines, pollution, Antarctica and things such as that. However, those treaties are all a result of cooperation for the peace, order and good government of the country. However, this kind of legislation is not. It is just a case of the Federal Government forcing its will on the States and people of Australia. It is offensive. It is objectionable.
—It is acting in accordance with the Constitution.

—The Australian Labor Party and the Labor Government have decried and demeaned our Constitution. However, when they want to use it, they use it to its full. That has been done here in the past by honourable senators. I must say that the Labor Party uses the power of the Constitution when it wants and destroys it when it does not want it. However, the unilateral listing of the Queensland wet tropical rainforests is an affront, particularly as there was no consultation-as was promised by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). That never occurred. The listing gives no recognition to the action taken by Queensland in respect of that State's rainforest management.

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland had zoning laws in respect of controlling these forests. It had a land management program that involved conservation and preservation. That program was one of balanced development. I suppose Queensland has well over 50 per cent of Australia's rainforests. New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania have 10 or 12 per cent each and the Northern Territory, Western Australia and South Australia have very little. South Australia probably has none, although it may have had some in the past. The point I am making is that the Labor States-and this included New South Wales until recently-have destroyed or removed most of their rainforests. This Government is moving against only those States which have rainforests and which happen to have conservative governments. In other words, this legislation has nothing to do with conservation or preservation; it has everything to do with power and control over land usage. The Federal Government is expanding its power over the land at the expense of the States.

New powers will be granted to the Minister under this legislation. A list of powers is set out under the heading `Unlawful acts' in section 9 (1) of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983. The section states:
Except with the consent in writing of the Minister, it is unlawful for a person, whether himself or by his servant or agent-
(a) to carry out any excavation works on any property to which this section applies;
(b) to carry out operations for, or exploratory drilling in connection with, the recovery of minerals on any property to which this section applies;
(c) to erect a building or other substantial structure on any property . . .;
(d) to damage or destroy a building or other substantial structure . . .;
(e) to kill, cut down or damage any tree . . .;
(f) to construct or establish any road or vehicular track . . .;
(g) to use explosives on any property . . .;
(h) if an act is prescribed for the purposes of this paragraph in relation to particular property to which this section applies, to do that act in relation to that property.
I repeat that the section begins with the words:
Except with the consent in writing of the Minister . . .

A lot of people think that the only difference between World Heritage listing and not being listed is the fact that the Federal Minister can stop one from doing certain things. Obviously, that is not so because with his consent one can do all of the things I have mentioned. I see this simply as a transfer of land management usage from the State government to the Federal Government. That will be the absolute effect of the introduction of this legislation.

As I have said, Queensland has over 50 per cent of Australia's rainforests. We have managed them well and we are proud of that. Of the rainforests we have, 80 per cent is in a pristine state and 20 per cent has been logged for about a century. The area that has been logged is being included in the World Heritage listing, which I think is a testament to the good management of the Queensland Government.

Having been to the rainforest area in north Queensland and having had a good look at it, I have come to the conclusion that logging is a good idea for all forests. The pristine forest is impenetrable and unable to be used. One cannot manage its water catchment; the felling of trees cannot be controlled; there is no prospect of tourism; and nobody can enjoy the area. But what is the situation in respect of the logged areas? By logging, I do not mean clear-felling, as was portrayed by the media previously, probably because of ignorance. But having had another look at this matter, the media has realised that in any hectare of rainforest there are about 15,000 trees. Logging involves the felling of six to 10 selected trees-not just any trees-about every 40 years. That is what is meant by the logging of rainforests.

Trees are felled selectively in our logged areas. Old big trees which fall over cause a lot more damage to a rainforest than is the case if they are selectively logged and felled according to a plan. In addition, light is let into a logged area which allows regrowth to take place. New trees are able to grow because of the elimination of big trees which sap the growth of younger trees. Also, selectively logged areas encourage trees to fruit more, which attracts birds and animals. That is where all the action is. In fact, we find that birds and animals prefer the garden of paradise to the garden of Eden.

Planned logging and snigging tracks are used for the management of water catchment areas. They also allow tourists to enjoy the rainforests. They can be used for research into flora and fauna and for educational and recreational purposes. This is what has been happening in the 20 per cent of rainforests that we have been logging. I think there are a lot more benefits in the logged than in the unlogged areas. In addition, of course, logging provides quite a deal of industry. When one considers the forest industries that are derived from the activities that I have been mentioning plus the industries that manufacture forest products, the Queensland Government really should be congratulated and encouraged, not bludgeoned as it is being bludgeoned under this Government with World Heritage listing and the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill.

One of the things that is concerning me at the moment is the increasing locking up of areas of Australia under various pieces of national parks legislation, World Heritage listing and other forms of listing that preclude the exploration and development of our country. Today about 20 per cent of Australia is locked up and exploration is precluded. I think it is very important that we know what we are locking up. Exploration causes very little damage. I think it is vital to our country that we do this before the Government proceeds to list a whole lot more new areas such as those that have been mentioned in debate here today. Western Australia is affected. Of course, Tasmania has been affected. Queensland is affected in terms of the Great Barrier Reef and rainforests. The Government is now threatening to put on the World Heritage List the Channel Country which covers an enormous area of Queensland. I think we want to know what is being locked up. If we want to be in a position to preserve anything and to do any good, we have to have the economic capacity to do so. By restricting our ability to develop and use our assets, we will reduce ourselves to a state where we will not be able to preserve anything.

There is just one other item I want to mention, and that is the inspection of this Bill by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The Committee pointed out that the Bill leaves the determination of acts which are unlawful to regulations. According to the Committee, the regulations would come into force and would continue in force unless and until disallowed. There is no prospect of amending those regulations. I have pointed this out to the Minister, and I hope that he will keep it in mind when he responds to the second reading debate.

I merely conclude by saying this is socialist legislation which consolidates the Federal Government's land grab of State land. The legislation absolves the Federal Government from action in its own courts. It precludes the States from applying to the courts for relief. It creates a new police force and it does not provide for consultation with owners of land that is proposed to be listed on the World Heritage List. It is a concept that should be, and I am sure will be, rejected by the people at the next election because that is our only way of stopping the Federal Cabinet going ahead in this high-handed manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be following Senator Sheil because he, like previous speakers from the Opposition, has identified a fundamental philosophical difference between the framers of the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, as supported by the Australian Democrats, and the position of the Opposition. This was identified by Senator Puplick and Senator Alston and now it has been further elaborated by Senator Sheil. I am surprised at Senator Sheil's arrogance in setting his judgment about the management of water catchments in tropical rainforests against the management which nature has carried out for some 3,000 million years and suggesting that he knows better. That seems to underlie the attitude which the Opposition has taken.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate Senator Collins on his speech. I think he gave an excellent answer to many of the assertions made by the Opposition in relation to this Bill. In doing so, he particularised the claims made against the Bill and his objection to them. I think he did that extremely well. But I do not think that either he or the Government has covered adequately the philosophical objections which can be raised to the Opposition's position on the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. The thrust of my remarks will deal with that philosophical base and why the Democrats are strongly supporting this Bill, which clarifies and makes more effective the legislation protecting World Heritage areas.

In his speech, Senator Puplick spoke of the National Estate, suggesting disparagingly that it was being preferred and given primacy over the rights of individuals. Senator Walters also spoke in pejorative terms about a landowner not being permitted to subdivide land as though that was an unalloyed natural right which citizens should have. We have also just heard Senator Sheil speak pejoratively when he listed the things which one may not do in World Heritage areas without the permission of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson).

I would like to defend and extend the idea that we need to control not only World Heritage areas but all parts of Australia as if they were World Heritage areas because we are at a very crucial stage in the history of human development and of evolution on the face of this planet. I think it was the German philosopher Hegel who said, `Freedom is the recognition of necessity'. In using that expression, he pointed to the need to understand exactly where we are and to conform with the restrictions which nature places upon us if we are going to have true freedom. Honourable senators opposite speak as though freedom is a natural right which is not constrained, but there are considerable restrictions in the exercise of our human activities. It is only by conforming with and perfecting our understanding of nature that we can have freedom.

Let us look at where we are in relation to our custodianship of planet Earth. Let us compress Earth's history into a 24-hour period and suppose that the world began at midnight. From that time until 5 p.m. the next day the planet was lifeless, undergoing great geological transformation, some features of which subsequently became important to man. Life first appeared at 5 p.m. and by 11 p.m. dinosaurs dominated the scene. Mammals emerged at 11.30 p.m. and, from amongst them, man burst forth at one second to midnight. We are so very recent that if a cosmic observer of this diurnal evolution were to blink, our presence might be missed altogether.

Let us change the time context and expand our human time on earth to a 24-hour period. Let us suppose that we shared our last common ancestor with another animal species at midnight. It is thought, from immunological and protein sequence data, that this occurred about six million years ago. On the 24-hour scale, we were living in groups in Africa, recognisably human, and using simple tools by about 2 p.m. the following afternoon. We became expert hunters and gatherers, developed comprehensive languages, complex cultures and expressive art forms but did not settle to growing crops or herding domesticated animals until 11.58 p.m. Christ came by at 11.59 and 30 seconds and Australia was visited by Captain Cook at six seconds to midnight. Six seconds out of our 24 hours on Earth is hardly a representative sample. Yet all of the industrial development and the pervasive exploitative attitude-the attitude that is coming from the Opposition-that has accompanied it occurred in this minuscule interval. How arrogant it is that we should use this tiny sample of our period on Earth as the basis for extrapolation into the distant future.

Herein lies a very significant paradox which needs to be clearly understood-that is, that unless one takes a particular religious view, in no sense is Homo sapiens the preordained pinnacle of a climaxing evolution. We just happen to be one of the end products of that continuing process which, without the interruption and disturbance created by modern man, would continue long into the future, but while we are in no sense a predetermined climax, we are nonetheless now responsible for the further course of evolution on this whole planet. Indeed, by certain acts we could, quite easily, truncate further evolution on the planet.

This is a paradox which places an enormous responsibility upon us. It is in that context that we must see the protection of the genetic diversity on the planet, of World Heritage areas and of habitats and everything else involved in the continuation of that evolutionary process. Perhaps it is not going too far to say that the primary function of human civilisation from hereon should be the protection of the evolutionary process so it can continue as it would have continued before we burst upon the scene so very recently.

Having looked at that large time scale, I turn now to the forest situation-the particular matter of concern in relation to north Queensland-and I am reminded of a visit which I made to a museum in the south-west karri forests of Western Australia. This museum dealt with the recent history-the last 150 years or so--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Manjimup one?

—Yes, of timber getting in the south-west of Western Australia. Anybody who has visited that area cannot but feel incredibly emotionally moved by those forests. That museum details the ways in which the early timber cutters spent four or five days in cutting down one large karri tree. On the wall of the museum is an enormous karri tree section. The rings on the tree are indicated with arrows and, if I recall it correctly, that tree started its growth at around the time of the signing of the Magna Carta, a copy of which we have here in King's Hall. There is another ring somewhere out near the periphery which shows the time when Captain Cook arrived in Australia, and further out other rings indicate more recent events in the history of Western Australia. While taking all this in, one sees right beside this enormous section on the wall a video description of the way in which we can now remove these large trees from the forest in as little as 20 minutes. It explains in very glowing terms the marvels of modern technology whereby we are able to remove, in as little as 20 minutes, these giants which have survived in the forests for as long as 1,000 years. Frankly, when I saw that I felt somewhat sickened that one should take such a simple view of our responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to a remark which Senator Alston made in his speech last week, in which he questioned the need for legal mechanisms, injunctions and the like whereby we can interfere with the processes of timber cutting in short order. He said, among other things:

. . . we are not dealing with a transient piece of the environment or something that can be destroyed by a few simple movements of vehicles or men; we are dealing with something that is of enduring quality and, presumably, of outstanding significance.

Against that background it is very difficult to imagine how something which, for perhaps thousands or millions of years-certainly for the past 200 years-has stayed in place without too much desecration or violation of its integrity can all of a sudden at the whim of a Minister be the subject of a court action on the basis that irreparable harm will flow unless an interim injunction, an interlocutory, is granted.

The fact of the matter is that we now have the power to destroy these areas incredibly quickly. It is in recognition of that that this Bill grants powers to provide those sorts of injunctive measures which can protect areas from incredibly rapid and vicious onslaught.

Senator Sheil referred to a cost-benefit analysis. He expressly mentioned the moves in the last few days of the National Farmers Federation and other bodies which wish to put in place a cost-benefit analysis in relation to the preservation of areas of particular interest. I point out, as I have done on a number of other occasions, that we would have no objection to such a proposal, provided that the national accounts took proper account of and kept records of both the flow of resources-of money-through the economy and the stock of resources. For instance, if we cut down a tree which has been living for a thousand years, we deplete our stock by the value of that tree and we increase the flow by the value in terms of a fallen tree. We do not increase our wealth one iota by cutting down the tree; we increase our wealth only by the value which we add to that tree by turning it into a piece of furniture or some other useful item. If we were to keep our accounts in that way, if we were to keep both a flow account and a stock account, we might then more properly assess what was a benefit and what was a cost.

I would like briefly to contrast the exploitative attitude of the Opposition towards the environment with that which we see in the indigenous population of this country. Most indigenous people around the world have come to terms with a sense of belonging to the environment. In this year, the Bicentenary of Australia, I believe that one of the important tasks we should be addressing is that of bringing that sense of being part of the nature-that element of Aboriginal culture-fairly and squarely into dominant white culture. Unless we do, we will really go down the gurgler.

In conclusion, I point out-the Democrats have used this expression before-that we have not inherited this Earth from our forebears; we have borrowed it from our children. I believe that that does not go far enough. Another notion is that of stewardship; that we have a responsibility to care for the land, to care for the environment. Again, I do not believe that that goes far enough, because it presupposes a necessarily dominant position for humans in relation to the environment. I think the correct position is to recognise our evolutionary dependence upon the environment, our being part of that life process, and to recognise that trees, and all living things, are part of our flesh and that we damage life at our own peril. That is the sense that we need to put in place if we are to ensure that evolution on the face of planet Earth continues into the distant future and is available to be enjoyed by our own descendants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill moved by my colleague Senator Robert Hill:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after ``That'', insert: ``consideration of this Bill be deferred pending the report of the interdepartmental committee which is currently looking at land use''.

I believe that there are compelling reasons why this Bill should not be proceeded with at this stage. I propose to come to those in just a moment. However, some of the remarks that Senator Coulter made in asserting that this Bill should be passed, and passed without amendment, I think should not be let go without some comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Puplick, you have to confine yourself to the terms of the amendment and the response to Senator Coulter may not come within those terms.

—I am aware of that, Mr Deputy President, but I will give it my best shot. There is an attempt to rush this Bill through because it is now half a second to midnight, or whatever it is, as distinct from deferring the Bill so that it can be properly considered and the other factors brought to bear in that consideration. Those factors, referred to in the amendment-namely, matters dealt with in the report of the interdepartmental committee-are of very great importance. It is simply not true to assert that, in seeking this deferral, the Opposition is somehow arrogant in terms of believing that it knows better than the processes of nature, any more than it is arrogant for Senator Coulter to assert that we are now in control of the processes of evolution. That is an equally outrageous and stupid comment to make. The trouble with that approach is that it comes from people who claim that they love nature, red in tooth and claw or whatever, but who really despise human beings-there are too many of them, they are too destructive and they pollute the environment. If Senator Coulter believes that, all I can say is that the remedy in his own case lies very much in his own hands.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also certainly not a valid point to say that what we have is the opportunity to go back and live like native peoples around the world in sympathetic harmony with our environment. That may have been an option 201 years ago; it is no longer an option for modern Australia. Therefore, the question of the deferral of this Bill pending the report of the interdepartmental committee is an important matter.

There was a report yesterday in the Sydney Morning Herald which not only added to the weight of argument but indicated that an advisory body was going to be set up by the Government to examine the economic costs of all National Estate and World Heritage proposals, that such a proposal was being advanced by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and that such a study would seek to weigh economics against aesthetics and would seek to bring a balance of evidence to bear on the question of whether areas should proceed to World Heritage listing. Under this legislation the regulations declaring parts of the wet tropics of north Queensland are to be repealed and other regulations are to be made in their place in an identical form once the Bill has received royal assent and has been proclaimed.

It is quite clear that there has not been brought to bear, particularly in the public domain, a full examination of the issues which impact upon the decision to proceed in this fashion. In October last year the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) announced that consultants had been appointed to undertake a series of studies-specifically on the implications of World Heritage nomination for the forestry industry by ACIL Australia Pty Ltd; on the implications of World Heritage nomination for the mining industry by the National Environmental Consultancy; on rainforest tourism potential by the same firm; and on alternative employment creation by the Institute of Applied Environmental Research.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The amendment refers specifically to one particular interdepartmental report. Senator Puplick is entitled to speak to that only. He has already spoken to the Bill as a whole. I do not see how other reports are relevant to the interdepartmental report, but the senator may be able to show me how it is.
—I shall certainly endeavour to do so. Undoubtedly, the interdepartmental committee would want to have access to these significant consultants' reports which are being prepared for this purpose.
—I think that is a rather tenuous link. You will have to do a little better than that.

—The interdepartmental committee is one which has been notified to the Senate by virtue of a series of questions asked of Senator Richardson. He was asked whether such a committee was being established. He indicated to us that as a result of the difficulties being faced by him in Caucus-under assault by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and various others-this interdepartmental committee has been established to look at the question of land usage. I am putting to the Senate that until such time as that interdepartmental committee has had the opportunity to evaluate and to report on this matter the legislation should not proceed in its current form. I was saying that the interdepartmental committee presumably would have access to those consultants' reports which the Minister has said not only have been given out but have been received by the Minister and which the Minister is deliberately suppressing, deliberately not making available to the Senate and deliberately not making available to the people of Australia. Presumably they would be made available to the interdepartmental committee. The study to which I was referring when you, Mr Deputy President, rightly drew my attention to the necessity to specify the relationship between them and the interdepartmental committee was the one being undertaken into alternative employment creation by the Institute of Applied Environmental Research at Griffith University. The two others, again at Griffith University, are into social aspects of the listing and the regional economic implications. All of those would be available to the interdepartmental committee. They are not available to Parliament, they are not available to the public, they are not available to the people of Queensland--
—I got them under the Freedom of Information Act last week.
—My colleague Senator Boswell says he has made application under the Freedom of Information Act.
—He said he has them, so they must be available.
—Senator Cook will have to do better than that.
—You have just said that they are not available. Senator Boswell said he has them, so the evidence is that they are available.

—The fact that they have not been presented to Parliament, despite the assurances of the Minister that they would be provided to Parliament, as distinct from being potentially discoverable under freedom of information legislation-
—Actually discoverable. They are in the possession of your colleague.

—No. Senator Boswell has said that he has made a freedom of information application. We do not know whether that will be granted. We do not know whether the mechanism will be put in place to delay the granting of that until after this Bill has proceeded. We do not know what the cost is going to be apart from the application form-whether Senator Boswell will be charged $1,500 in the way in which the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) has been given bills for $7,000 worth of information-and to say they are discoverable when we do not know that that is the case, we do not know the cost and we have the Minister's assurance that they will be made available to the Parliament but are being deliberately suppressed from Parliament until this legislation is dealt with, is simply not a good enough excuse for Senator Cook to try to persuade Parliament otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: The matters that I believe need to be carefully considered as a result of the report of the interdepartmental committee report also touch on the way the Government is proceeding on the matter as far as the specific part of the nomination relating to north Queensland is concerned. In order not to put a strain upon our relationship, causing the Deputy President to interrupt me on a number of occasions in order to speak to this amendment, I might confine myself to a series of speeches in committee, particularly if the Bill is taken as a whole. Presumably that will allow me a far greater degree of latitude in this matter. I hope honourable senators bring their toothbrushes.

The timing of the passage of this Bill seems quite unnecessary. The High Court in its recent decision on the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests Commission of Inquiry legislation has made it quite clear that the Commonwealth has the power under the current legislation to act in the way in which it wishes. If its intention is purely to secure the protection of the tropical rainforests of north Queensland, the Minister has the power under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act to prevent things from being done or to authorise things to be done as he sees fit. Why then is it necessary to put this Bill through in this particular form at this stage when an interdepartmental committee, which is looking at the question of land use, presumably is addressing itself to the underlying principles of World Heritage listing and their management in relation to alternative plans for land use around Australia? The Opposition simply does not believe that there is justification for this Bill being proceeded with before all the evidence is on public record. That evidence comprises the evidence both of the consultants' reports to which I have made reference and the report of the interdepartmental committee which the Minister has told us is looking at land use management questions. Therefore, I simply indicate that the Opposition will be pursuing that particular amendment.

We do not believe that the urgency has been established in the light of both the High Court's decisions in the case to which I have referred and the other parts of the Bill dealing with the establishment of inspectors, the regime relating to compensation, or the Government's attempt to get out from the provisions of its own impact of proposals legislation. In those circumstances, and with the proviso that I shall raise a number of other matters in committee, I simply emphasise that we shall be pursuing our amendment.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell, before you begin I should warn you that as you have already spoken in the debate, you are confined to speaking on the terms of the amendment moved by Senator Hill, which reads:

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I shall be careful as I do not wish to transgress your ruling, but this is a very important issue on which I feel very passionately. I use this opportunity to represent the people of north Queensland, as I do on every occasion that I can speak, in order to put their concerns before the Senate. SPEECH.PARA: I see no reason-and ask the Senate to back me-why we have to rush into this matter. Logging cannot be continued up in the north Queensland rainforests; the regulations are down; the proclamation has been signed by the Governor-General; logging has stopped and a $33m industry is down the drain; the jobs of 3,000 people are finished-sold out. I feel that we are offering Senator Richardson an escape hatch through which he can withdraw after the rout-the only word I can use to describe it-in the New South Wales election, the biggest political rout in history. I would never call people common. The people to whom Senator Richardson was referring are the decent working men and women of Australia who make our economy tick. They were traditional supporters of the Australian Labor Party, but they have said, `We do not want Labor any more. We do not want a Labor government looking after conservation issues. We do not want you to be all things to all men. We send you here with the bulk of our votes-or at least, we did-to represent us, not to represent a mish-mash of trendies, conservationists, feminists and gays. We want you to represent the decent working men and women of Australia. But, like Pontius Pilate, you have completely washed your hands of us'. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn Senator Boswell that he is getting rather wide of the amendment.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy President, that I am transgressing your ruling. I will try to get back to the interdepartmental committee report. That report is expected in three or four weeks and there is no need to make a decision on this Bill. I suggest that the Labor Party has made a great mistake and the Opposition is now offering an escape hatch. Labor members should go back and lick their wounds. They should say honestly to the people, `Let us await the IDC report'. While the Labor members are awaiting that report, they can go into Caucus and listen to the views of some of the more reasonable people in the Labor Party. There are a few reasonable members of Caucus, though not many. Certainly Senator Button shows a bit of wisdom from time to time, as does the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), a person to whom Labor members should listen.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson has an opportunity to back down gracefully by saying that the Government will have to await the IDC report before any decision can be arrived at. Senator Richardson can go to his greenie mates and say `I am not prepared to make any decision until the IDC report comes down'. His greenie mates will have to buy it because of the position of people in north Queensland who have lost jobs. Senator Richardson has sold out his unionist mates. If he makes a decision before the IDC report comes down and decides to rush ahead and destroy 3,000 unionists jobs in north Queensland, as well as destroying towns in the area and devaluing the price of workers' homes, also ruining many small businesses before the report is published, he will have to wear it politically, as the Labor Government wore it in New South Wales. The Minister must take a fair degree of responsibility for that because he is the recognised power broker in the Senate and in New South Wales. It is no good the Minister saying that the Labor Party has forgotten what the common people are all about and that Labor does not understand them any more. The Minister should have said, `I have forgotten what the common people are all about. I have lost touch with them as I hobnob with the captains of industry and society'. What about Senator Richardson's grass roots? He has neglected them. I am offering the Minister an opportunity to come out from under. He does not deserve it, and should take the consequences. But I offer him a way out by saying that he should tell the Government to do nothing until the IDC report comes down.

There is another reason that I am concerned as to why the Government is rushing ahead with this Bill; my colleague Senator Puplick alluded to this matter in his remarks. A total of $300,000 of taxpayers' money has been spent to inform the Senate on socioeconomic impact studies and environmental impact studies. Eight reports have been requested, commissioned by the Minister, and yet he has not had the courage to present those reports to Parliament. He has not allowed us to debate the issue with any scientific evidence. The Minister has been frightened to put that scientific evidence before the Senate and he has forced all his colleagues, and indeed Opposition members, to make decisions without the advantage of that evidence. If those reports supported the Minister's argument on World Heritage listing, I believe that he would have introduced those reports into the Senate in 35 seconds flat. But the Minister has not put down those reports because they will not support his arguments. He is running for cover and that is another--

TALK.START.PARA: —Show us the NORMA scientific report.
—I will present the Northern Rainforest Management Agency scientific report. I will present the report from the professor at the university at Townsville.
—The name you are groping for is Harris.

He is on the way out. If he does not repent and see the light, what has happened to the New South Wales Government will happen right throughout Australia as one Labor government after another falls and, finally, the Federal Government will fall. That will be exactly what the Labor Party deserves when it admits that it has forgotten what the common people are about. It does not understand them any more.
