TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —To illustrate the humbug that has surrounded this debate in the last few weeks, I can do no better than to quote Senator Puplick. Senator Puplick has had a bit to say about World Heritage in the past and this has differed markedly from what he has had to say in the last few days. Just so that we understand what Senator Puplick thinks of the values, let me quote him exactly. In a Press release in August last year he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland wet tropical rainforests are worthy of inclusion on the World Heritage list; they are unique; they are of international significance; they contain one of the greatest and scientifically most significant concentrations of unique flora and fauna in the world. Australia is the only industrialised country with remaining tropical rainforests and we have a responsibility to protect them.

That is the only thing Senator Puplick ever got right on the question of rainforests in north Queensland. We have to protect them and, fortunately, this Government is honouring that obligation. What the Opposition has done today in another desperate attempt to do anything to stop us from protecting them typifies the humbug that has surrounded us now for weeks in this debate. Members of the Liberal Party of Australia do not represent a majority. Senator Puplick's words, that I have just read out, ring true. His actions show something entirely different. Of course, what they show is that when the crunch came he could not convince his colleagues. Here they are, whipped and beaten, doing anything they can to get out from under on World Heritage listing.

The Sydney Morning Herald carried a report this morning, which should not have shocked the Liberal Party and the National Party in Queensland. It certainly did not shock the Government. Dr James Thorsell, the executive officer of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources, said that north Queensland rainforests were `clearly of World Heritage calibre'. Dr Thorsell is one of the key officers who will report to the World Heritage Bureau on the nomination by the Australian Government of the wet tropics at the end of this year. Dr Thorsell is acknowledging what all the scientific evidence has acknowledged so far-that is, that clearly these areas are worthy of heritage listing and that we have to make sure that they are listed.

On the other hand, Senator Puplick says that a Liberal government would not nominate any areas for World Heritage listing if an individual State did not agree. So he is really saying that, in the case of the wet tropics in Queensland, because the Queensland Government will not agree, that is it; it is all over; nothing is saved; nothing gets nominated for World Heritage listing; and the Queensland Government becomes the arbiter of heritage listing in Australia. That is more than a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you spoken to Ahern?

—The honourable senator asks me whether I have spoken to Premier Ahern. I have made arrangements to speak to Premier Ahern and that will take place very shortly. I have been trying to speak to him for a very long time and, finally, I am having some success.

SPEECH.PARA: One wonders how long the forests would wait for protection under Senator Puplick's plan of State veto. Just where are his principles? If Senator Puplick believes that there is a responsibility to protect the rainforests-and those are his words-just what is he prepared to do about it? So far, we have seen him coming into this chamber only twice to try to contribute in the debate to make sure that we do nothing to protect them. It is a pathetic attempt to hide some of the embarrassment of the Liberal Party over World Heritage issues, but it is not the only pathetic attempt being made in that direction.

Last week we had a big shock when the Leader of the Queensland Liberals, Dr Angus Innes, leaked copies of the World Heritage nomination of the north Queensland rainforests to the Press. He claimed that our nomination was fraudulent and this was shown up in the document. It is hardly a secret document. Copies of it were sent to the Queensland Premier and to Senator Puplick in January, so it was not a great shock to me that people would suddenly find out about it. Far from trying to hide the document, we have made it public, we have made sure that people have had access to it, and it has been available to anyone who has requested a copy. Apparently, we have been told that the nomination was fraudulent because it stated that the rainforest was in very good condition and this contradicted claims that the listing was necessary because the State Government could not be trusted to look after the area. I just wonder how pathetic some of these attempts can get. If people lack the fortitude, the vision and the courage to stand up to the National Party, the Liberal Party, Senator Puplick and Mr Innes will have to bear that responsibility in the end and it will fall heavily upon their shoulders.

The document about which I have just spoken clearly states that the condition of the forest ranges from relatively pristine areas to various stages of regeneration following disturbance and degradation over 100 years, from logging in some cases. Some of those areas that have been logged still retain heritage value, so they have been nominated. Some do not, so they have not been nominated. We have never made a secret of the fact that not all the rainforests in Queensland are up to World Heritage standard and that is why we chose not to nominate all of them.

There is nothing fraudulent in the Commonwealth's action in trying to protect these rainforests. The only fraud in this whole bitter campaign has been the Queensland Government's attempts-I think the word `misrepresentation' is far too weak a word-to create hysteria over this listing. Unfortunately, that has been endorsed by a spineless expediency shown by the Liberal Party. The moral bankruptcy involved in bowing down to the Nationals on this really makes my mind boggle. Of course, the fraud is a clear example of why Queensland never could have been trusted to manage those rainforests. It was demonstrated three weeks ago when I released the maps prepared by the Queensland Forestry Department just how great this fraud was and just how far the Queensland Government was prepared to go in misrepresenting its case. The Queensland Government's Forestry Department, in its attempts to justify the continued logging of the forests, has attempted to create a folklore, a new myth, that only 25 per cent of the rainforests had been logged, and, therefore, we had nothing else to worry about. The world could be reassured. Conservationists did not need to panic. The Queensland Government neglected to tell the world that the only reason there were any virgin forests left at all was that either they were on very steep slopes and so were inaccessible or there was no commercial timber in them anyway.

A report by two independent Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) scientists who analysed the maps for the Commonwealth found that, of all the rainforests in the wet tropics between Townsville and Cooktown, 35 per cent in State forests and timber reserves had been logged. If we include rainforests on private land the figure was up to 45 per cent. By the Queensland Government's own maps the figure was 45 per cent. The Forestry Department either confused itself or, in an attempt to confuse others, responded by claiming that less than 20 per cent, or about 167,000 hectares, of the rainforests are zoned for logging. That was never the issue.

I was putting on the record the history of logging in the wet tropics. The forestry department tried to get out of its embarrassment by talking about the amount of forest that it intended to log, not the amount of forest that has been logged. The reason that much of this remaining rainforest, some of which is on private land, is not in the heritage area, is that the malicious and hysterical campaign waged by the Queensland Government did so much to worry private landholders. In the end the barren legacy that will be left by the Queensland Government, by Senator Puplick, and by the spineless performance of the Liberal Party, if it were to succeed, would be no rainforests at all. That is where the industry was heading, and it was heading that way for a long, long time.

Senator Puplick revealed extraordinary environmental ignorance this week when he said that we could applaud Queensland's rainforest management. I can excuse Liberal Party spinelessness in one sense, I suppose, with Queensland's buy and sell, bash and burn attitude to the environment that it has always had. However, it is going just a bit too far for Senator Puplick to attempt to have us believe that Queensland's management of national parks is, to quote him, `of the highest order'. That is simply too hard for anyone to stomach.

Let us critically examine this claim about Queensland's rainforest management. In 1986 about 2 per cent of Queensland was reserved as national park. All other Australian States with the exception of Queensland have reserved and set aside for national parks a minimum of 5 per cent of their areas, which is of course the recommendation of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature. Only 45 per cent of Queensland's biological diversity is represented in its national parks. In New South Wales and Victoria the figures approach 100 per cent. In Queensland the richest and most diverse natural heritage that we have in Australia is being left to rack and ruin by a government that has a cavalier, development at all costs attitude. That Senator Puplick can endorse that State's rainforest management shows just to what extent he must have been defeated within his own party.

I shall go even further and give some examples of Queensland's national park management and the commitment to national parks demonstrated by the Queensland Government. At Lawn Hill in the north-west of Queensland, Brazilian millionaire Sebastian Maia, after buying a pastoral lease at a bargain basement price, stalled a national park proposal for years and years. The original proposal was for more than 80,000 hectares of land. After a personal visit to the property by the then Premier Bjelke-Petersen, the park was finally declared but, guess what, it comprised only 12,000 hectares. In Queensland, if one is rich enough and complains loud enough one does not have to worry about a national park; one can ride straight over it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can win elections.

—When it comes to winning elections I hope Senator Boswell will look at the results of last Saturday's local elections in Cairns and Townsville, located right in the area where Senator Boswell told me that the conservation movement would be routed. On the contrary, it has routed the Opposition. However, let us look at some specific proposals. I instance proposed national parks at Cape York Peninsula, Shelburne Bay, Iron Range and McIlwraith Range which have been on the books for more than a decade. What has happened to them? At what stage are they? What about Bayfield National Park, which was first proposed in 1960? A few weeks ago, of course, we heard that half of that area is to be utilised for sand mining before any of it is declared. We still do not know what will happen there.

SPEECH.PARA: Bribie Island was promised as a national park three years ago. What has happened to it? All we know now is that a town site for 200,000 people will not be allowed on the island; we have not been told just how much will be allowed. What has happened to that national park? Only 200 of the 800 islands on the Great Barrier Reef are protected as national parks from development. Why is that? Why is it that a national park on Masthead Island off Gladstone, promised two years ago, has never been delivered? Why is it that the Queensland Government tried to sell off Lindeman Island to East-West Airlines? Why has the Queensland Government tried to do all those things? The answer is that when it comes to national parks the Queensland Government does not care, and never did care.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were trying to give some of your fellows a job, that is why.

—I might say that even Bjelke-Petersen backed off selling Lindeman Island. It is interesting to note that Senator Boswell still supports that sale. We will ensure that many people in Queensland find out that Senator Boswell still supports selling off Lindeman Island. That is typical of his attitude, and typical of his party's attitude. Of course, at the time Sir Edward Lyons was the chairman of the company trying to buy the island, so I can understand why Senator Boswell would have that attitude; I can understand that only too well.

SPEECH.PARA: If we proceed beyond Queensland's procrastination and prevarication on national parks, we should look at what is represented by the Opposition's performance in the Parliament in the past few days. The memory of the Australian public will certainly not be as short or as selective as that of Senator Puplick, who claimed that I had consistently refused the offer of the Queensland Government to discuss the World Heritage listing. If one examines the facts, one sees that four years ago the Australian Heritage Commission recommended that this area should be nominated for the World Heritage List and that attempts to discuss anything with the Queensland Government ever since have been doomed to failure.

For three long years the Commonwealth Government attempted to discuss that matter with the Queensland Government, but it did not get us very far. The State which has 54 per cent of Australia's rainforest refused to compromise or alter its destructive logging schedules in any way. In September last year, just four months after the Commonwealth Government announced that it had no option but to proceed with World Heritage nomination, former Premier Bjelke-Petersen-Senator Boswell will remember him because he was the senator's patron-was in north Queensland whipping up local fervour. His geriatric, bigoted rantings at that time were pretty fantastic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: Senator Richardson's remark about the former Premier was derogatory, and I ask that he withdraw it.
—No protection is given to former members of parliament. I call Senator Richardson.

—Sounding like an erratic emperor, Bjelke-Petersen ranted as his empire crumbled. To indicate the sort of discussion that Senator Puplick encourages, I should like to quote part of what he told the troops in north Queensland on that occasion. Bjelke-Petersen said:

SPEECH.PARA: We're at war-we are really at a war, in a war situation, not the Brisbane Line, but we are at war in this part of the State from Townsville north.

That was the prelude to my visit to Ravenshoe. I should like to believe that Premier Ahern has a different view. I really would like to believe that, and I am sure that he has. However, Premier Ahern still has to talk to his Cabinet members about world heritage. That Cabinet has a pretty fair record. It includes Brian Austin, who seems to think that there is a connection between AIDS and the rainforests simply because Brazil has both. There is Bob Katter Jr, whose crowning political achievement is apparently convincing the Queensland Government that there should be no more national parks on Cape York Peninsula. There is Martin Tenni. Who could forget Martin Tenni? He has earned a pretty sordid place in environmental history in Queensland by his not so private advice on the question of the Daintree road in 1984, when he was saying that what had to be done was to `do as much damage as possible so the greenies will never get this world heritage'. They are the sorts of attitudes with which Premier Ahern will have to compete. However, I am sure that he will manage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, Graham, you are out of touch.

—If ever I have to get in touch I shall not be asking Senator Walters. The times are a'changing in northern Queensland, fortunately. The timber companies and the timber workers who have been bullied for so long and have not cooperated with the national government, are now cooperating and I am delighted about that. The financial analysis of the timber companies is proceeding apace so that when I announce the compensation package I shall be in a position to do the right thing by them. On the score of that cooperation it has to be remembered that on 11 December, which is some time back, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wrote to Premier Ahern, saying that he would like to discuss the issue with the Premier. Less than two weeks later Premier Ahern said that he would fight to the end.

SPEECH.PARA: Time and again I have asked for talks with the Queensland Government. My hopes are buoyed because some talks have now been agreed to. One never knows one's luck in the big city; even in Brisbane one never knows one's luck. We shall see how that goes, and I shall take some delight in reporting on it to the Senate.

I shall go a little further and talk about our commitments in Queensland, and Senator Puplick's statement about how we should trust Queensland's national park management, and why this Bill is not necessary. I should like to say something about Dr Ross Hynes, the person who advises the Queensland Government on forestry and national parks. Recently he described me as a `numbers kneecracker'. He often gets his cliches slightly confused, and that is another example of that. However, the examples of his advice that I want to give are a little more serious than that. His scientific colleagues are more than concerned that the forests should not be logged. What happened with the NORMA scientific report is the classic example of the Queensland Government on the run on the issue. Dr Hynes's performance has been castigated by all sides.

Senator Puplick, without even the hint of a blush as bright as his bow tie, stood up in the Parliament and told us that the Liberals would have expected the timber industry to agree to a voluntary moratorium. I would have thought that the actions of the timber industry in Queensland over the last however many years one wanted to count would never lead one to that conclusion. Certainly, the discussions it had with me did not leave that to any imagination. It made its position very clear. For more than a century it has made its position very clear. The rainforest timber industry has always wanted to operate in virgin forests because it is in virgin forests that it can get the best timber. That is why the argument is so passionate and intense now. The best timber has been running out. The areas of virgin forest are not there any more; there are very few left. Is it any wonder that, with the last few fragments of old, accessible forests and today's technology, this would arouse so much passion among the environment movement. There is no doubt that, with logging going at the pace it is, industry is on the verge of collapse. It has nothing to do with World Heritage; the industry is doomed anyway.

I can show honourable senators headlines of the Ravenshoe Press going back to 1986, such as `Ravenshoe under threat'. That was long before World Heritage nomination. Ravenshoe was under threat because the Queensland Government, in one hit, halved the quotas; there were none left. If any politician had bothered to listen over the past decade or so to the foresters and mill owners in Queensland, he would have been told that the good timber was running out. That is why in the old days they needed only a handful of species and now they need over 100. There just is not the good timber left. If we are to preserve what is left, we have to act now and pass the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill.

All that has happened with World Heritage Listing is that the timber industry, the Queensland Government, Senator Puplick, those who have shown spinelessness and Senator Boswell and his colleagues, have looked for someone else to blame. Obviously, the World Heritage listing is a convenient whipping boy, so away they go. That will not change what has happened to the rainforests of north Queensland.

The really embarrassing advice which the Queensland Government received from the scientific sub-committee of NORMA in the last few weeks is worth a few more words. Senator Boswell said that he would like to get permission to table it. I will be in anything that I can do to assist Senator Boswell in this endeavour. The committee is chaired by Dr Hynes, whom I mentioned earlier. Despite what happened with its political masters, the work of that committee is very welcome. The report has real significance. One has only to listen to the Queensland Minister responsible for the environment, Mr Muntz, to work out just how significant it was. It was not the work of one scientist; rather, it was the synthesis of input from 14 scientists, all of whom have expertise in rainforests. Their combined work found that the area had World Heritage value.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you worried about going to court?

—However, Mr Muntz, Senator Parer and others do not want to listen to the scientists. Those rantings and explanations as to why it was not right vary dramatically according to whom one listens to. Even Mr Muntz could not work out why it was not right. He gave three different answers in the space of two days. That happened because they set up a committee when they were sure of the outcome. With the acknowledged scientific expertise of Senator Boswell, Senator Parer, Mr Muntz and others, it was thought that in no way would the scientists find that the area had heritage value. However, they woke up one morning and discovered that the scientists said it had heritage value. That was the end of the day when it came to scientific evidence. The Queensland Government will seek no more because it knows what it will find. As to Mr Muntz's claim that the report was a preliminary one which had been stolen, it was available in the CSIRO library in Atherton. The idea that it was not available is just ridiculous. The next excuse was that it contained computer errors. However, they have backed off that excuse now, because it did not contain such errors. We are not sure what the third excuse will be. Perhaps Senator Boswell can tell us. Perhaps he has the insight into the problem. I suspect that, as usual, he will tell us nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: In November, the NORMA Chairman-that well-known north Queensland knight, Sir Sydney Williams-put out a Press statement claiming that north Queensland would be paralysed by the listing. He said that there would be no more roads and powerlines. He went through all the hysteria and nonsense that has gone on for a long time. Like all good messenger boys, he put out the release which had been prepared for him by the Press Secretary of the then Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. I know from discussions with the staff of NORMA, how embarrassed by that and the scientific committee's report they really are.

I want to turn to some of the criticisms that have been made as to the powers of search and seizure. We have heard about Richardson's greenshirts. We have heard about this new environmental police state that I seek to create through this legislation. The rights of private citizens will not be diminished under the legislation. What I will demonstrate now is just how moderate the legislation is when it comes to police powers. It contains no power of seizure or arrest, so it cannot be regarded as draconian. It contains powers to obtain information only. Inspectors cannot enter a property without permission or a judge's warrant, unless they believe that there are serious circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Unless'. You must think we are gullible.

—I will tell Senator Boswell about the Queensland Government's laws. Let us hear about the Minister Geoff Muntz's gestapo and what powers it has. Section 56 of the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service legislation gives the Director, his officers and employees the power to enter any land or waters at any time, without previous notice, without warrant, to inspect forest products or for any national park purpose. The Tasmanian Government is not real bad on this either. I am glad that Senator Walters is in the chamber. Let me give a couple of examples. Section 41 of the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Act gives authorised officers the power to seize anything on reasonable grounds. Section 42 gives the power to search any premises, including private homes. Section 43 gives the power of arrest without warrant, even for failing to give full name and address. That is what Tasmania and Queensland are about. I am referring to their Acts. In a report entitled Privacy and Statutory Powers of Intrusion, which was produced in October 1981, the Law Reform Commission of Western Australia identified 54 provisions under its State Acts which authorised search and seizure and only 14 of those required a warrant.

SPEECH.PARA: Far from talking about the shock, horror proposals contained in this Bill, we ought to look again at Western Australia. The Carnarvon Banana Industry Act 1961 to 1980 entitles any inspector not only to enter premises but also to inspect books, accounts, records and documents. The only safeguard is that he must enter the premises at a reasonable time, which is pretty decent of him. One would hope also that inspectors or veterinary surgeons in the Western Australian Department of Agriculture would be discreet about the times they go in. They have similar powers.

I was a bit worried about Senator Walters. Apparently, she depicted someone at her car late at night flashing something at her. Fortunately, we discovered that it was a badge. So we were able to have our delicate sensibilities satisfied. Looking at the powers of arrest and seizure that the Acts in her State give people, one is in a lot more trouble in that State. Some of Queensland's Acts are much worse. There are no worries about Richardson's greenshirts and brownshirts. Already in Queensland one can have one's property entered and searched. One can be arrested. It requires no warrant. It requires nothing. I did a very different thing in looking at this legislation. I would never agree to the draconian practices in which Senator Walters's Liberal Government in Tasmania or Senator Boswell's Government in Queensland are involved. I could never agree to it, and never would; and of course, I have not. In terms of the impact of this Bill the reality is--

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us a bit of detail.

—If I had an hour and a half, I would. However, I am afraid I do not get that. I am given only some of the time necessary to try to answer some of the misrepresentations that Senator Walters and other honourable senators opposite have perpetrated in this place. Unfortunately, it is not long enough. All I can say, in conclusion, is that the later amendment moved by Senator Puplick is pretty typical of his performance in this debate. it is a desperate attempt to do anything at all to stop World Heritage listing going ahead. There is no substance in it, so there is nothing to answer. All that Senator Puplick and Senator Boswell said is, `Don't list it. Let's delay. Let's procrastinate. Let's do anything we can'. Further to that, as far as the Bill's so-called draconian provisions are concerned, there are none. What the Government is concerned about is not only saving Queensland rainforests but also setting a procedure for the future for the World Heritage to make sure that all citizens know their rights; that we all know in which direction we are heading. This Bill does no more and no less than that. I would hope that the Senate can speedily pass the Bill so that we can all make sure that our World Heritage areas get some protection. There are not many such areas left. There is no big list that the Government is about to draw up, but our great areas need preservation. The rainforests are one such area. I am proud of all we have done to save them. Whatever other areas need saving, we will look at them as well.

That the amendment (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given that since the election of the Hawke Government an average single income family is paying $15 a week more tax; that the average price of a litre of petrol has gone from 44c to 57c while world oil prices have halved and that this rise is thanks to a trebling of the excise under Labor; that foreign debt has more than trebled and now stands at around $7,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia; that an extra 700,000 Australians have slipped below the poverty line; and that the prices of average cars such as the Commodore and the Ford Laser have increased by 57 per cent and 63 per cent respectively since the start of the car plan, will the Minister confirm that in 1986-87 real disposable income fell by 1.2 per cent-the first time in 30 years that this important measure of family welfare has gone backwards? Does the Minister agree that the only way to reverse this situation on a sustainable basis is to achieve real productivity growth? Given the present stagnant situation, what steps will the Government take to lift productivity?
—I am not able to go through Senator Chaney's lexicon of political propaganda. I understand that that will be debated in the matter of public importance debate later today.
—You are not disputing that these are facts, are you?

—Oh, come on, Senator! I think that there are alternative figures on many of those matters which lead me to the conclusion that they are matters of dispute rather than fact. On the question of productivity, one cannot wave a magic wand when one is in government in order to improve productivity across the economy. There are a number of things happening, industry by industry, which are designed to improve productivity and which involve improved investment, improved labour force relations, better management techniques and so on. Senator Chaney asked me a very general question which is not susceptible to precise answers. The matters I have mentioned are in train and will continue to be so under this Government.

—I note the Minister's answer and, by way of a supplementary question, I point out that this Government has been in power now for five years and has indicated that it wishes to continue following the policies that it has pursued to this point. It is clear that productivity is stagnant. Does the Government have in mind any changes to policy to tackle this fundamental problem which must be solved if we are to have any sustainable rise in living standards in this country?

—My answer to the original question was that the Government has a number of policies relating to the issue which Senator Chaney raised in his question. Only yesterday I answered a question from Senator Chaney about the Government's wages policy. In my answer I indicated that, in terms of discussions about wages policy, the Government was primarily concerned to see a moderate wage regime and that in the negotiations about this the issue of productivity should be regarded as paramount. That is a very important macro-policy which is relevant to the questions that Senator Chaney asked, quite apart from numerous other factors which are taking place on an industry by industry basis.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of remarks made by Senator Lewis in an interview on 2GB yesterday, 22 March, when he alleged that the export market development grants (EMDG) scheme was defaulting in payments to approved firms? Is it true that, as Senator Lewis stated, there is a $64m shortfall in funds under the scheme? Is it correct that, as also alleged, Australian firms with legitimate claims for export assistance under this scheme will have to wait until next year's Budget to receive funds due to them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis's remarks have been drawn to my attention. Once again, his particular political views and role have not let him have a clear sight of the facts in this matter. Senator Lewis may not be aware of this but on 20 March-well before he participated in this radio program yesterday-I announced an additional--
—Two days before.
—One cannot afford to be two days behind in this game. I announced that an additional $64m would be made available to finance claims under the export market development grants scheme.
—Once again government by Press release. I warned you about that yesterday.

—Senator Lewis makes the great plea of the illiterate in saying that governments sometimes make announcements by Press release. Press releases are capable of being read and are useful vehicles of communication with the bulk of the electorate. Perhaps, in Senator Lewis's case, we should have Press releases in braille or something similar to help him out.
—You are the Leader of the Government in this place and you have a responsibility to the Parliament.

—Senator Lewis should not distract me from my answer. He probably does not want to hear it. I understand his motives. The scheme to which I referred, which is administered by Austrade, as Senator Lewis might know, aims to encourage small to medium sized Australian exporters to develop overseas markets for goods. There are specific programs within the export market development grants scheme. It was first introduced in 1974 and revised in May 1985 to help ensure a more effective targeting of export assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: I must say that throughout the scheme's life the grants payable have generally exceeded the amounts provided in the Budget. This is because the scheme is responsive to exporters' claims as well as exchange rate movements. It is thus very difficult to estimate total Budget requirements. For example, for this financial year the Government initially provided $109m to cover claims made by exporters for 1986-87; actual commitments amounted to $146m. Taking account of previous backlogs, this left the scheme with a shortfall of about $64m for claims to be processed by 30 June 1988. The increase in claims under this scheme can be attributed to the 26 per cent increase in exports of manufactures and services during 1986-87-something which never happened in the Opposition's time in government-and the 14 per cent depreciation of the Australian dollar during the year.

This Government has a firm resolve to help Australian firms improve their export performance through this scheme and related Austrade administered schemes. Equally, we need to ensure that government funds are spent effectively. To this end, the Government is reviewing the EMDG scheme to ensure better targeting and to help avoid substantial shortfall situations in the future.

In looking at Senator Lewis's remarks about the EMDG scheme-inaccurate as they were-I had occasion to read the rest of what he said in that little bobby-dazzler radio interview, full of factual errors as it was-a nice little discussion based on totally false assumptions. I will mention one other false assumption that Senator Lewis made. He asked me yesterday about concessional finance that was made available to help the Australian company, Austoft Industries Pty Ltd, one of the two producers of sugarcane harvesters in the world and probably the best, to market its goods in Cuba and Nicaragua. In yesterday's radio interview Senator Lewis said:
We made a grant available, a concessional finance arrangement, just to keep the Labor Party's Left wing happy because that is why these loans were made.

Senator Lewis comes out of the cold war of the 1950s; in fact he is still there. That grant was about helping an Australian company, which is world competitive, in a difficult market and one of the only export markets available to it-Cuba and Nicaragua, which are big producers of sugar. I intend no disrespect to the left wing of the Australian Labor Party; the left wing of the Labor Party would not have such a stupid view as that. It probably did not even know that it happened. It is only in the minds of people such as Senator Lewis that this sort of mind-boggling 1950 vintage politics is still about.

In making concessional assistance available to exporters, a wide range of countries has to be considered. I do not want to mention some of the other countries. Senator Lewis can run them through the political spectrum if he likes, but this has nothing to do with politics. It is about helping Australian exporters, and helping them in difficult market situations. I invite Senator Lewis to look at the way the scheme operates and to come back and ask me some questions about the concessional financial arrangements that we have made available to countries other than Cuba and Nicaragua. I have seen Senator Lewis's Press release. It represents an extraordinary misrepresentation both of the Government and of very fine Australian companies such as Austoft.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Has his attention been drawn to the report of the Victorian Young Homeless Allowance Reform Group which calls upon the Government to review the social security legislation and its implementation? Is the Government satisfied with the current legislation? Is the administration of the allocation of this allowance satisfactory or are there problems? What is the estimated cost per head of applicant, including costs of local government youth workers assisting applicants, of administering this $26 a week allowance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that is raised is of concern to government. In response to the last part of the question, I do not have any specific statistics but I will endeavour to obtain them for the honourable senator. However, a number of newspaper reports recently have indicated concern that the new arrangements for the young unemployed are leading to increased youth homelessness. This, of course, is something that the Government is monitoring very closely. Our position is that it is too early to monitor the effects of the recently introduced jobsearch allowance. The young homeless allowance, however, is available to young people who have to live away from home without parental support. That is one Government program which we are gearing towards the particular problem that is raised by the honourable senator.

ANSWER.PARA: I should also spell it out that the Government's policy is aimed to ensure that parents who are able to provide more support for their children do so, but also that there should be government support and protection where parental support is not an option. The young homeless allowance, which was introduced in July 1986, was increased in January of this year from $73.28 to $76 a week. The payment represents an increase of some 50 per cent in the normal rate of payment for 16- and 17-year-olds without parental support.

It has been of concern to the Government that we establish reasonable and workable criteria for treating young people as independent of parents, and this is one area of social policy in which there have been difficulties. There is on the one hand the problem of unnecessary incentives to leave home to be considered. The Government's position is that the effectiveness of the young homeless allowance will be kept under constant review. Having in mind the fact that I have promised to provide further information, I should also mention for completeness that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is conducting an inquiry into problems faced by Australia's homeless youth. Its report is expected to be available in September 1988. I assure both the honourable senator and the Senate that the priority issue that has been raised is under constant review by the Government in terms of both our financial commitment and our keenness to keep under constant monitoring the effectiveness and the implementation of our programs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. I asked the Minister whether his attention has been drawn to the report of the Victorian Young Homeless Reform Group but in his answer he did not give me any information as to that. I ask what response the Minister has to the following statement made by the Homeless Allowance Reform Group:

QUESTION.PARA: The guidelines are so strict and narrow and the administrative procedures so time-consuming that young people are forced to wait months to get it, because the Government has put more effort into ensuring that those who are not eligible will not get the Youth Homeless Allowance rather than ensuring that those who are homeless are supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the question is that my attention has not been drawn to that specific article.
—I will give you a copy.

—I thank the honourable senator. In respect of the second part of the question, I thought I made it clear that the Government, in working out and monitoring its policy, is keeping under constant and close review both the effectiveness and the implementation of the young homeless allowance. As a consequence, the issues that the honourable senator raises are very much to the forefront of the Government's monitoring considerations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has his attention been drawn to an article by Gerard Henderson which appeared in the Australian newspaper on Monday, 21 March? Mr Henderson stated in that article:

QUESTION.PARA: Voluntary work contracts are the obvious answer to the calls for productivity and enterprise level negotiations that are so essential if Australian industries are to become truly competitive on world markets and if we are to get rid of our appalling restrictive work practices. N.S.W. can take a national lead here.
Is the Government persuaded by the argument that a system of voluntary work contracts is the answer to improving Australia's overall economic performance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the last part of the question, the Government is not persuaded.
—I wonder why.

—I am about to tell the honourable senator. If he tunes in he will hear why. There are a number of reasons for that. The first and most obvious one, probably, is the success that the accord has achieved. That is, following the wages explosions of 1981 and 1982 when, under the Howard formula, wages increased by 13 per cent and 14 per cent respectively, the accord over the next four or five years has led to a very substantial decline in real wages and an even more substantial decline in real unit labour costs. That is something that had to happen, because the wages explosion that John Howard presided over had driven the Australian economy into the deepest recession since the 1930s and led to massive unemployment. That was a major factor in that recession and the consequential unemployment. Since that time more than a million additional people have been employed. The Australian economy has grown at what is by Australian standards a high rate and simultaneously unemployment has fallen and real wages have declined.
—The international debt has grown at a phenomenal rate.

—There is no precedent in Australian economic history-as Senator Stone would know very well, even though he is not too good on some British labour history-for a decline in real wages, necessary as it was in the circumstances, at the same time as the economy was growing quite strongly and unemployment was falling.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the most obvious reason. There are less obvious reasons, one of which was highlighted in the Australian Financial Review of 11 March. It gives an account of two former executives of Repco who were eased or, one should say, squeezed out of their jobs by a Mr Cafiero, who has apparently taken over the management of Repco. I suppose the orthodox theory to which Senator Stone subscribes would say that Mr Cafiero must have been a very efficient manager. If that is so, there is nothing in his record to support it. He presided over the near bankruptcy of Chrysler before moving on to De Lorean and presiding over its ultimate bankruptcy. So there is nothing in Mr Cafiero's background to suggest that he was a particularly good manger. He did, however, manage to get rid of the former executives, Messrs O'Brien and Roberts, who were sacked but not told why. They were given no explanation. The Financial Review reported:
O'Brien and Roberts took legal advice immediately and their lawyers, Corrs, Pavy, Whiting & Byrne, advised them to use the Industrial Relations Commission to have their case heard.

The reason for that was that they had contracts which they thought would protect them in the circumstances which had arisen; that is, that they got the sack without even being told why. Their lawyers suggested that they go to the Industrial Relations Commission (IRC). The article continued:
Apart from being less expensive, they could expect to be heard within a matter of weeks, rather than an estimated two and a half years through the court system.

That was 2 1/2 years through the court system, and a matter of weeks in the IRC. Just as another aside, a snide Press release was put out by Andrew Hay who, as we know, has a long association with the Liberal Party as a staffer in Parliament House, among other things, and is a would-be Liberal member of parliament. The snide Press statement by Andrew Hay criticised Messrs O'Brien and Roberts for going to the Industrial Relations Commission. The real point is that if people like Messrs O'Brien and Roberts, who were the finance director and the manager of a large company, had contracts drawn up which in the end were found to be dud contracts, not enforceable at all possibly and certainly not enforceable within 2 1/2 years, and could be dudded in that way, what hope is there for the ordinary employees of a company to be protected against unjust dismissal or whatever through a contract?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an account in the West Australian newspaper of Friday, 18 March, which stated that almost 160,000 passengers have refused or failed to pay the Federal Government's airport arrival fee in its first two months of operation? Can the Minister confirm the figure of 160,000 passengers? If not, what is the correct figure? What feedback has the Minister received from the tourist industry and from international tourist bureaus concerning the effect of the $5 arrival fee? Is the Minister convinced of the advisability of retaining the fee in the light of widespread opposition to it and the difficulty in collecting it? If the fee is to remain, what steps will the Minister take to make it more acceptable to both the airlines and the travelling public?

—I have to advise Senator Jenkins that I cannot confirm the figures she has quoted, though she has drawn those figures to my attention. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has advised me that he and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories have met with airline representatives on three occasions. The Government and the airlines have raised a number of options but discussions have not yet been finalised. The Government wishes the discussions to be completed before announcing any final options, so any media reports about numbers as quoted by Senator Jenkins or possible resolution of these differences are obviously premature. However, I note that Senator Jenkins has a particular interest in this matter and I assure her that as soon as it is appropriate to make a more detailed response to her question I will certainly ensure that full details are given to her.

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that reply and the assurance that details will be available. However, are we then to presume that the present haphazard situation of collection-that is, that some pay and some do not-is to continue for the time being?

—That question is essentially one for the airline industry. What we are trying to do and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories have been working on, is to resolve with the airline industry the concerns that have been raised, but it is premature at this stage and I am not in a position to pre-empt any announcement that might be forthcoming following those discussions.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Has the Minister seen reports alleging government disregard for families headed by sole parents? In view of the Hawke Government's clearly stated concern for the living standards of families with dependent children, what has been done for sole parents, whose households are amongst the poorest in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Giles for raising this question and say to her that an accusation I have heard in recent days is that sole parents are amongst those parts of the Australian community that the Government has allegedly disregarded. I should, for the sake of the record and for the sake of public debate, make the record clear, firstly, about the Government's commitment to alleviating the poverty problems of sole parents-a very needy group in the community-and secondly, on the commitment of the Government over recent years in those areas.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe the Government's record in these areas has been a very proud one and one that critics obviously disregard. In making an assessment of the Government's position, obviously they work from a position of ignorance. We have taken a number of steps to alleviate poverty in this area. We have increased payments for children from $10 a week to $22 a week and, for older children, to $28 a week. We have taken steps like increasing the mother's/guardian's allowance from $6 a week to $12 a week, which is a 100 per cent increase. We have extended the allowance to cover all sole parent pensions and beneficiaries. The Government's commitment in the area of poverty has led to changes in the poverty trap problem and as a consequence assistance to sole parents means that they can now earn quite an amount each week before they start to lose their pensions. The amount that can be earned by a sole parent with three children has been increased from $48 to $76 a week-almost a 60 per cent increase. In the last Budget the Government also introduced an earnings credit scheme, a scheme that means that sole parents just starting work or who from time to time do casual work will now be able to earn more and not jeopardise their pensions in the process.

I should mention also that the record of this Government has been to increase the availability of child care places. In targeting our priorities in that area, sole parents have been one of the major beneficiaries of the Government's program. Sole parents have become a priority group for Commonwealth Employment Service and labour market programs. Government information and records indicate that sole parents are becoming major users of the range of labour market transition programs. I should also mention that in last year's Budget the Government made changes to the eligibility criteria for sole parents' pensions. Although those changes make it more difficult for sole parents to receive a pension in particular circumstances, the changes reflect our belief that sole parents should be encouraged to move out of the social security system, where possible, and become financially independent, but at the same time consider and take care of those in grave need. I should emphasise also that we have provided training courses for sole parents who are no longer qualified for pensions.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have to read it all.

—We have a reaction from the Opposition. It seems that honourable senators opposite come in on cue every time. I should take this opportunity to mention in response to them that the Government's approach in this area contrasts very starkly with their policy. It is on record that the Opposition would decimate labour market programs, would destroy child care programs, would shed public housing responsibilities and cancel the pensions of every sole parent whose youngest child is over 10 years of age.
—Is this for next Saturday?

—No, it is not for next Saturday. This has been ongoing Government policy and something of which honourable senators should be reminded from time to time. In closing, and with reference to the stark contrast in the records of the Government and the Opposition, I should say that the Government is still committed to doing more for sole parents. As honourable senators might know, we are introducing a child support scheme. The other plank of the Government's program in this area will be consideration of the Cass review of social security, particularly those recommendations for sole parents. That consideration will be proceeding in the next few months.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to Senator Bishop and others, I should say that under the Australian Labor Party sole parents do have a chance of leading a decent life. Under the policies of Senator Bishop they have Buckley's chance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the statement he made on 15 December last in which he announced the extension of the coastwatch contract to Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd for 18 months and amongst other things stated that it would be paid:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . with necessary allowances for the acquisition or modification of equipment.

I ask the Minister: Has the Government paid Skywest the sum of $1.28m under this item of that contract? What has Skywest expended this money upon? Is it a fact that Skywest is currently operating an interim coastwatch contract with eight aircraft only? Is this in accordance with the terms of the interim contract? Is this figure, if it is correct, the number of aircraft which were being operated by Amann Aviation Pty Ltd when the Minister terminated its contract on 12 September last year?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little short of up-to-date information on this matter. The 18-month interim contract was in the process of being negotiated when I had most recent advice before me. I am not quite sure what the final terms of that negotiation are. I shall take the question on notice and give Senator Durack an answer as soon as I can.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to Press reports today about exports from Australia of motor vehicles and automobile components which point to substantial growth in export sales to Japan, Europe and the United States. Are these latest reports indicative of future growth prospects for Australian car and parts manufacturers? Also, what levels of exports may we expect in future years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some of the Press reports to which Senator McKiernan refers. I think there are signs to support cautious optimism about the export performance of the motor vehicle industry in Australia. Last financial year exports of motor vehicles and components totalled $637m, which was an increase of 64 per cent on the 1985-86 exports. This compares favourably with the 23 per cent increase in manufactured exports as a whole over the same period and reflects the significant progress being made by the industry towards world competitive manufacturing. The industry is adopting a fresh approach to export possibilities. There have been a number of factors, including the devaluation of the dollar, which have helped that process. The industry is also capitalising on its expertise in low volume production, and a number of niche export market opportunities in the United States and Europe are emerging.

ANSWER.PARA: Press reports in various newspapers today refer to export deals with Ford in Japan, Nissan and Mitsubishi in Japan, and sales of automotive components to Japan. Australia is now the third largest importer of automotive components into Japan. Also, the Press reports refer to sales of components by Ford Australia to its European parent plants and increased sales from Holden's engine establishment at Fisherman's Bend to the United States and Europe. On the basis of these announcements by companies and the figures which are available to date, the industry estimates of $1.2 billion in exports by 1992 will be easily attained and are well within the industry's grasp.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and follows the answer he has just given on motor vehicle exports. The Opposition welcomes those exports, but in light of the fact that the price of a Ford Laser has gone, from the time of the commencement of the car plan, from just under $8,000 to over $13,000, an increase of 63 per cent, the price of a Commodore in the same period has gone from a little over $11,000 to about $17,500, an increase of 57 per cent, and the price of a Falcon has gone from over $12,000 to over $17,000, an increase of 43 per cent, I ask the Minister: Since one of the objectives of the car plan was to produce more competitively priced vehicles for Australian consumers, is there any prospect of the very steep rises in motor vehicle prices being slowed down, or even reversed, and to what extent is the car plan succeeding in providing cheaper vehicles for Australian consumers?

—The rapid increase in car prices in the domestic market followed closely and dramatically from the devaluation of the Australian dollar in 1985 and again in 1986. That is, first of all, because the price of imported cars went up significantly, but also because the price of significant components in motor vehicles, imported largely from Japan, went up very significantly at that time. The motor vehicle industry reflected more dramatically than any other industry, I suppose, because of its vulnerability to component imports, the changes in the value of the dollar, particularly as against the yen.
—Taxes and interest rates surely had something to do with it.

—Taxes and interest rates may have had some marginal effect on it at various times, but we have debated that issue before in this place, particularly in relation to the fringe benefits tax. There is no doubt that for a variety of reasons, associated with Government macroeconomic policy in the difficult trading environment in which this country was situated, Government decisions of one kind or another had some effect on the car market. I do not retreat from that at all. My recollection-and I will get Senator Chaney the figure-is that as distinct from the year 1986-87, in the year 1987-88 there has been a quite distinct decline in the acceleration of motor vehicle prices, if acceleration is the right--
—A reducing rate of increase.
—A reducing rate of increase, yes. But even Senator Chaney would admit that that is better than an accelerating rate of increase.
—It is better than a poke in the eye with a sharp stick.

—Absolutely, Senator; I would not put it any higher than that. Let me say that, relatively speaking, Australian motor vehicle prices compared with those in other countries are not abnormally high. I shall try to get Senator Chaney some figures.
—That is not right.

—As I said, I shall try to get Senator Chaney some figures on that and Senator Messner can look at them at that time. It is an objective of the car plan to reduce relative prices of motor vehicles in Australia. I believe that we still have the capacity to attain that objective over time. Any future announcements about the car plan will partially go towards helping with that process.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance, who represents the Treasurer, been drawn to an advertisement in yesterday's Australian Financial Review for companies to enter into arrangements with Carlton Football Club for $65,000 entertainment packages in the guise of `visible advertising signs'? Would the `favourable tax implications' advertised as available with this package be consistent with the taxation arrangements proposed today by the President of the Carlton Football Club as they would affect the club's supporters in buying a ticket for the outer? Is the Government contemplating implementing these new taxes for football fans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are three questions there. The answers are yes, no-and as to the third question, whether the tax advantages described are real, I do not know the answer to that one and I shall seek an answer from the Treasurer. I have seen the advertisement, and for those handicapped people from the north who may not know it, I should mention that the President of the Carlton Football Club is one John Elliott, better known probably as President of the Liberal Party.
—I wouldn't bet on it.

—Outside Melbourne, Senator Ray. Do not be parochial about this. Outside Melbourne or outside southern Australia he is better known as President of the Liberal Party. The advertisement, as Senator Schacht's question states, says that for $65,000 a company can become a sponsor of the Carlton Football Club and that the company representative will be able to take seven guests along to several of John Elliott's presidential lunches, have the three-course corporate lunch, as much booze as one can drink at the footie in the afternoon and get to the footie free as well-all the nine games at Princes Park and one at VFL Park, `along with favourable tax implications'. The clear message there is that the company will be able to write off the $65,000 as advertising expenditure. I shall seek an answer from the Treasurer as to whether that would be allowed.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked whether this advertisement was consistent with the statement made today by Mr Elliott, President of the Liberal Party. The answer is definitely no. Mr Elliott, as President of the Carlton Football Club, is soliciting and promoting a device, brazenly proclaimed in the terms of that advertisement, for him, his ilk and their mates to bludge on the taxpayers, go to the footie free, gobble the free lunch, swallow free booze all afternoon and then claim the whole lot as a tax deduction against the company. That humbug was compounded today when he appeared on the Schildberger program advocating yet again a broadly based consumption tax which I understand, and according to today's Australian Financial Review, Mr Peacock is also contemplating, but which the Financial Review says, in the end, he will not have the stomach to go ahead with. In other words, not only is Mr Elliott brazenly advertising and soliciting for people to join him in bludging on the rest of the taxpayers with free trips to the footie, free lunches, free booze and the whole lot being claimed as tax deductible, but also he has the audacity the very next day to say that all the ordinary people who pay their own way when they go the footie, who have to buy their booze if they drink there, who have to buy their own pies, will get taxed on them as well while he is still sitting in his corporate box paying nothing for it and claiming the whole lot as a tax deduction.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED GUN LAWS: PROTEST BY UNIONISTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Numerous accounts are emanating from the Latrobe Valley in Victoria regarding the heavy-handed approach by union officials in threatening unionists not to sign a petition opposed to the Cain Government's gun laws. Has the petition signed by 1,000 Latrobe Valley unionists from 13 separate unions protesting against the Victorian Government's gun laws been drawn to the attention of the Minister? Is the Minister aware that these petitioners propose withdrawing payment of their union dues unless union contributions to the coffers of the Australian Labor Party cease forthwith? Will the Minister support, on public interest grounds, the right of rank and file unionists to protest in this way against what they believe to be union inaction on gun laws, or will he sit back and allow compulsory unionism to take effect?

—I always accept that it is the right of any group in the community to express its views on political matters in a free society in a way it thinks appropriate, provided it is not accompanied by violence or other activities which might be regarded as socially undesirable, such as we have seen in a couple of instances recently in one industry. I am not sure that this question is, in any sense, within the province of the Minister for Industrial Relations. Busy as he is and `hands on' Minister as he is, I do not think he would devote much of his time to assessing the feelings of particular people in particular unions in relation to the gun laws issue. However, that may be wrong. I will certainly pass the honourable senator's question on to the Minister and see whether I can extract an answer from him. But I sincerely think it is not something which would normally come within his province as Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training been drawn to an article entitled `Improving Australia's Competitiveness', by Dr David Clark of the University of New South Wales, in today's Australian Financial Review? In that article Dr Clark asserts:

QUESTION.PARA: The average Australian employee gets paid for 57 days a year they are not at work.
Ignoring the poor grammar in that statement, is it factually correct? Does the repeated assertion of supposed facts of this type help or hinder the improvement of Australia's competitiveness?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to the question is that the assertion made by David Clark and quoted by Senator Beahan has absolutely no foundation. Moreover, he published the same false assertion on 10 November 1986 and 11 November 1987. I will detail the broad facts of the situation and I am leaving aside the 20 per cent, or thereabouts, of the work force who are casual employees and, therefore, do not get any holiday entitlements at all. Quite a few of them work for 20 hours a week or more-it is not just a couple of hours-but I am leaving them out of it. The typical Australian worker, excluding those casuals, gets 20 days paid annual leave, 11 or so public holidays-and that is a bit imprecise because it varies from one State to another-and entitlements to other types of leave, such as long service leave and sick leave.

ANSWER.PARA: If all employees remained in their jobs long enough to qualify for long service leave they would accrue between six and seven days per year, although figures published by the Advisory Committee on Prices and Incomes suggest that a substantial number of employees do not remain in one job long enough to qualify. The Australian Bureau of Statistics does not publish figures on sick leave but I understand that a Confederation of Australian Industry survey about two years ago came up with a figure of five or six. So when we put them all together we get a figure of just above 40 days a year instead of the 57 that David Clark has asserted.

Most of the ideas that David Clark puts forward are quite sound. It is a pity that he spoils it by lack of attention to detail and then compounds that by a continuing lack of attention to the same detail, even though it has been drawn to his notice. It is damaging in two other ways in the broader field. Firstly, presumably many high school teachers and perhaps even other teachers of economics would regard that as an authoritative article and pass it on to students as a fact. Secondly, the wider public-employees who know that they are not getting the alleged 57 days a year-are likely to be dissatisfied because of that and people overseas are likely to perceive Australian industry to be less competitive than it is because the alleged number of paid holidays of various types, or leave of various types, has been exaggerated by David Clark by some 40 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In light of the Government's intention to have all species of plants included under plant variety rights (PVR) legislation by March 1990, including all Australian native plants, beginning with all eucalypts in July this year, and in light of the Government's protestations that patents will not be able to be applied to discoveries but only to new varieties created by plant breeders, can the Minister tell the Senate how he will ensure that no patents will be granted for discoveries when, as yet, there is no completed, comprehensive inventory of Australia's native plant species? For example, botanists estimate that approximately 10 per cent of native species are, as yet, undescribed. Does the Minister agree that, until such time as a full inventory is made, it will be impossible to guarantee that discoveries are not being claimed to be newly bred varieties? Finally, therefore, how can the Minister guarantee that no Australian native plants will be included under PVR until such a complete inventory is made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Powell's question, of which she had the courtesy to give me notice just before I came into the chamber--
—We thought that these were questions without notice.

—She is a courteous senator and it is entirely appropriate that notice be given if it is the choice of honourable senators opposite so to do. I am just paying my regard to an honourable senator who showed me that courtesy. That is entirely appropriate.
—Just when you are unable to answer questions without notice.

—I have never had one from the honourable senator, so she would not know. The answer to the question is that the inclusion of native species will promote their development and cultivation for the benefit of Australians rather than overseas commercial interests and discourage harvesting and destroying the bush to obtain access to Australian species. Protection from improper exploitation of varieties found in the wild can be achieved without excluding native species from the plant variety rights scheme, while still allowing these breeders who develop and improve varieties and cultivation the opportunity to gain benefits for their efforts in making these plants available to people in Australia and overseas. To ensure that discoveries direct from the wild are not granted rights, the applicant will have to demonstrate selective breeding practices through at least four generations, or propagation cycles, or will have to demonstrate that a mutation has occurred under cultivation before a variety is eligible. Applicants' premises and methods will be carefully inspected to ensure that the claims made are accurate. In determining whether a variety is new the Registrar must make inquiries as to whether it is known to exist. If it is not a known variety, meets the criteria for development and cultivation and conforms with the other legislative requirements, it is eligible for rights.

ANSWER.PARA: In seeking comments on a known existence of a variety, a description of the proposed variety will be published in the Plant Varieties Journal and will be sent directly to people who are known to have an expert knowledge of the plant species. In this way the whole community will have an opportunity to comment on the known existence of the variety. As mutations are always occurring, a complete inventory of Australian varieties may never be available. Therefore the inquiries made by the Registrar will determine whether a variety is known to exist.

If the development of Australian native species is not encouraged under plant variety rights, the current practice of overseas interests taking our species from the wild and having them protected under plant variety rights in other countries will escalate, with no benefit to the Australian people. Macadamia is the classic example of an Australian native which was commercialised in Hawaii and is now considered by many to have originated there rather than in this country. Similar commercialisation of Australian varieties is occurring on a large scale in America, Israel, New Zealand and Europe. Australia is one of the only countries that exclude discoveries, and any further restriction on the development of native species would be to the detriment of this country. Encouragement of the development of native plants in cultivation will help protect the Australian bush from the ravages of those trying to gain commercial benefit direct from the wild.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I address a supplementary question to the Minister for Resources. In the Minister's response he said that a complete inventory may never exist. I ask whether that means that the Minister would agree that the claim that no discoveries would be eligible for patent is therefore a hollow claim. In asking that question, I should say that I am not concerned about the question of Queensland nuts. I think we have a lot of that species, and perhaps we do not have any problems there.

—I absolutely concur with the last comment about Queensland nuts. The difficulty of compiling a complete inventory of Australian varieties is, as I said, that mutations are always occurring, and therefore this is an ongoing proposition. So one cannot say that the known plant varieties at a particular time will always be listed as the total representation of all plant varieties henceforth. Therefore I do not agree that it is a hollow claim.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Transport and Communications. The Minister's attention has no doubt been drawn to media reports about the adequacy of coastal surveillance operations in Australia's north. In these reports retired Air Marshal Evans was reported as suggesting that Australia's north was wide open. Does the Minister agree with this assessment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some reports of evidence given by Air Marshal Evans some days ago. Indeed, I think probably a month ago similar remarks were made. I point out that the Department of Transport and Communications is responsible for getting these contracts up and running, and my colleague Senator Tate then has the responsibility for coastwatch coordination. However, it should be clearly understood that this is a civil function. Australian's coastal surveillance was never intended to give a blanket coverage of every inch of our coastline against every imaginable intruder. If we were to provide such a service it would probably run upwards of 10 per cent to 15 per cent of the Federal Budget outlays in any one year.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot agree that the present coastal surveillance is ineffective. Recent evidence of the discovery of Indonesian shipping vessels in northern Australia is evidence of that. I point out that those vessels were disguised, and were discovered as a result of the photographic ability of coastal surveillance.

At the moment, given the previous problems that existed with the contracts, the government has asked Mr Hudson to review the whole matter, taking into account views expressed by Air Marshal Evans and similar people, and to make recommendations as to what should be the future course. I hope to have that report by some time in April and we can then start to progress that future action, which will be the coordinating agencies and the manner in which future coastwatch operations will be undertaken.
