Senator Gareth Evans-Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is it in order for the honourable senator to canvass the proceedings of the Senate and a vote taken earlier today? My clear understanding of the Standing Orders is that that is out of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell is reflecting on a vote of the Senate. In its present form the question is not acceptable, and Senator Boswell should attempt to rephrase it. I call Senator Boswell.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Boswell having proceeded to rephrase his question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Boswell should resume his seat. That question is a reflection on a decision of the Senate, and therefore is not in order.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MR M. J. YOUNG: PARLIAMENTARY PENSION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I preface it by reminding the Minister that in the United States of America, a member of the Administration who takes up a lobbying position within a year of leaving office is liable for prosecution under the Ethics in Government Act, and that Michael Deaver is currently serving a well publicised gaol sentence for perjury relating to just such an offence. While I recognise that there is no such law in Australia, I also remind the Minister that his Government does have guidelines for lobbyists which it has chosen not to enforce in the case of Mr Mick Young, and that there is also a law preventing a Minister from drawing both his full parliamentary pension and his salary from some government appointments. The Minister will also be aware that the former Prime Minister, Mr Gough Whitlam, although he retired prior to the passing of this provision, on his appointment as Ambassador to UNESCO voluntarily agreed to a reduction in his salary equal to his parliamentary pension payment. I ask the Minister whether, in the spirit of that provision, Mr Mick Young has, at the very least, agreed to a reduction in his parliamentary pension equal to his fees and free travel as a consultant or lobbyist for Qantas.
—Last week Senator Messner, I think it was, asked me a question on the same point about Mick Young's superannuation.
—No, it was not.

—I was asked such a question last week, and I answered it. I thought the question was asked by Senator Messner. However, if Senator Newman was not listening, or had something else in mind, I shall go through it again. The Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act provides that superannuants--
—It was a different question.
—Well, Senator Newman asked about three questions--
—Shall I repeat the question?

—I certainly do not want the honourable senator to repeat it. In so far as the guidelines are concerned about people who engage in lobbying activities, the guidelines will be scrupulously followed. Mr Young or anybody else will not be given any special privilege, advantage or access by virtue of his background as a former Minister. I take that to be the main point. Of course, there is a confusion between consultants and lobbyists. As I understand it, Mr Young's position is--
—What is it?

—It is a matter of public knowledge about which I thought Senator Newman might have informed herself. Mr Young has been appointed as a consultant by Qantas Airways Ltd; not as a lobbyist. I do not propose to carry on this debate with Senator Newman about a whole range of questions and confusions which are in her mind. I will just say that the guidelines in respect of lobbyists will be scrupulously observed.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. I think that the Minister was so busy trying to think of how he was going to get out of it that he did not listen to the question. Therefore, I draw his attention to the fact that when Mr Gough Whitlam was appointed as an ambassador he agreed voluntarily to a reduction in his salary equal to his parliamentary pension payment. I ask the Minister whether Mr Mick Young has, at the very least, agreed to a reduction in his parliamentary pension equal to his fees and free travel as a consultant or lobbyist for Qantas.
—I am unaware of any such offer by Mr Young. I would be very surprised if he made it. I appreciate his intelligence in that regard.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance.
—Ask him about `Ollie the Grub'.

—I refer to an address given earlier this afternoon by the Leader of the Opposition to the international economics students conference, entitled `Our Statutory Authorities: Salute Them or Sell Them', in which he canvassed the liberalisation of entry into the markets of Telecom Australia and Australia Post. What was the previous coalition Government's policy in respect of competition between the public and private sectors? Has the present Government maintained that policy? What was the fate of the reports of Mr Neil Brown's Davidson Public Inquiry into Telecommunication Services in Australia and the Bradley Committee of Inquiry into the Monopoly Position of the Australian Postal Commission? What are the budgetary implications of returning to the former coalition's policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans was quite correct with the interjection; I would rather talk about the double-dip that Senator Newman's husband is in for with his parliamentary pension plus his defence services pension, neither of which he has relinquished. I suppose it would be out of order to do so, so I had better answer the question. I have read the address that Mr Howard gave at lunchtime today in which he said that the Liberals have not finalised their plans for Australia Post and Telecom, but have decided that those organisations will not be privatised. There was a bit of double-think there because several pages of Mr Howard's address effectively presented arguments as to why, in his view, they should be privatised, but, in the end, it came down, as it always does, to the hard truth that on such matters the National Party tail wags the Liberal Party dog. Mr Howard knows very well that the National Party would not allow that to happen, even though it now has rationalist luminaries in its ranks such as Senator Stone.

ANSWER.PARA: Overlooking that and a couple of other bits of double-think that came through in the speech, the previous coalition Government's policy in relation to competition between the public and the private sectors is probably indicative of what a future coalition government-should there ever be one-would have. It is epitomised in its 1981 ministerial statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions (RCF). I notice, incidentally, that one organisation which Mr Howard definitely said was to be privatised was the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. The 1981 RCF statements also said that the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation would be privatised, but that proposal was dropped within about six months.

The other point I want to make about the 1981 statement is that the then Government decided to abolish the Australia Post Courier Service to ensure that the post office could not even compete with the private sector. It was, however, allowed to retain an express service for postal items only. In other words, it was permitted to retain an express service for postal items but could not pick up the additional business that flows on virtually without cost because that was to be protected for the private sector. The underlying philosophy of doing that, of course, was a self-fulfilling one; that is, if conditions and regulations are imposed on a publicly-owned business enterprise or service which do not apply to a privately-owned competitor, inevitably the publicly-owned enterprise will be less efficient and less profitable than the private competitor. I suspect that, should the Opposition form a coalition government again, we would see a repeat of that sort of regulation-not of deregulation-in a way that favoured private sector operators rather than public sector operators.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday last Senator Peter Baume asked me a question relating to the Victorian Public Authorities (Equal Opportunity) Bill. At the time I undertook to look further at the issues he raised. The report in the women's newsletter of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association is accurate and relates to Victorian equal employment opportunity legislation. However, as I said last Friday, the affirmative action and equal opportunity legislation introduced by this Government refers to programs for achieving equal opportunity for women, but we do not have contract compliance or quotas. The legislation states explicitly that employment promotion must be on the basis of merit. It rejects quotas. Employers set their own objectives and forward estimates. It has no harsh penalties, the only sanction is being named in Parliament. I think that that in itself is a penalty. Whether or not it is regarded by companies as a harsh penalty is for them to determine. I think that the very good role that Ms Valerie Pratt is playing-I note and commend Senator Vanstone for her comments about Ms Pratt this morning in a notice of motion-and the very conciliatory role that she is adopting in working through our new legislation is very important and appropriate and it is the way in which we will bring about important changes. As I said on Friday, the Federal Government has no intention of changing the legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Question Time yesterday, Senator McLean asked me a question about the authority of unsigned letters from the Department of Social Security. The Minister for Social Security has supplied me with the following information: The Department of Social Security dispatches a substantial amount of correspondence to its clients each day and the type of communication may vary from individual prepared and signed letters or questionnaires to computer generated letters or questionnaires. The authority for requesting any action of a social security client resides in the Social Security Act 1947, as amended; not the letter sent to the client. The letter merely communicates the request. Such requests for action are usually based on section 163 of the Act and this is generally stated in the letter.

ANSWER.PARA: Under section 163 a formally signed request is not necessary. The Department of Social Security does not expect there will be a significant increase in automated unsigned letters. In fact, technology is moving at such a rapid rate in this area that the computer production of signatures on automated communications in the social security environment may well be a development of the future. The Department expects that these developments will have a greater potential for providing safeguards in access to official letterheads.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 March last Senator Calvert asked me two sets of a series of questions each in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. The questions concerned disability services and they were quite detailed. I have quite a long and detailed answer from the Minister for Community Services and Health, as befits the question. Therefore, I table the document and seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

Expenditure by this Government on services to people with disabilities has certainly not been cut. Overall expenditure has increased from $74.4m in 1982/83 to $150.8m in 1987/88-a growth of 102 per cent.
In 1987/88 alone, $9.8m has been spent on new and upgraded services. Some 84 new projects commenced and an additional 30 were assisted to expand. Some 8,000 clients benefited from these initiatives.

It is not correct that funding for capital has been severely cut. Funding of capital equipment and maintenance under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act and the Disability Services Act has never been an automatic entitlement to service providers and requests for funding in this area have always exceeded available Commonwealth funding.

Money for essential equipment and maintenance claims is available in this financial year and State offices of the Department should be processing claims towards the end of this month. Requests will be assessed on the basis of whether the funding will specifically help the service provider deliver better outcomes for people with disabilities in the service.

All funded organisations have now signed contracts with the Department of Community Services and Health under the provisions of the Disability Services Act. The block grant method of payment which has been introduced allows organisations much more flexibility than in the past to manage their services. All organisations have received 1987/88 funding and I am not aware of any organisation which has waited 9 months to receive 1987/88 funding.

I recently approved 140 proposals at a cost of $2.53m (and a 1988/89 cost of $1.57m) for transition funding to help service providers, including sheltered workshops, reorient their services to meet the principles and objectives of the Disability Services Act. This is part of $6m available in 1987/88 and $15m in 1988/89.

Funding for the establishment of new services will again be available at the beginning of the next financial year and organisations with large waiting lists should be considering establishing new services to provide for this unmet need.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to address the causes of the serious decline in Australian living standards.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has brought forward for discussion the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to address the causes of the serious decline in Australian living standards.

I suppose that the millions of Australians who are feeling the stress of their declining living standards, who are, as one constituent in the electorate of Balga put it to me last Saturday when I was walking around in the polling booths, finding it difficult, even with a night job, a second job, to raise the money to pay the bills, will be very consoled to know that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who is the most senior economic spokesman in this place, contributes to the debate in the way we have just heard-namely, to come in here to tell us a little story about the Tolpuddle Martyrs.

TALK.START.PARA: —He still got it wrong.

—Whilst that might be amusing, and Senator Stone has interjected to say that, in any event, he got it wrong, I think it is a mark of why we need to bring this matter forward for discussion that we can have the most senior economic Minister in the Senate simply prepared to ignore a debate on something which is a major concern to the men and women of Australia. The position of the Government seems to have been set out by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, in remarks which were reported from him this morning when he said that `economic policy was working like a charm'. Again, the tens of thousands, the hundreds of thousands and, literally, millions of Australians who are feeling the squeeze will no doubt be consoled to know that Mr Keating believes that the Government's economic policies are working like a charm.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose, too, that the hundreds of thousands, indeed, again millions of Australians who have just administered a sharp rebuke to the Labor Party in a series of elections around Australia might have expected something a little more in the way of response than the `business as usual' remarks we have had from members of the Government since that time, including Ministers in this place. Today we heard Senator Button, in response to various questions, indicating that as far as the Government was concerned it was business as usual. We had Senator Walsh extolling the virtues and the success of the prices and incomes accord-his expression was `the success of the accord'-in Question Time today, which he measured as having delivered substantial declines in real wages.

It may well be that the Government and the changes in our terms of trade brought us to a point where there was an imperative that there be a decline in real wages. The sad thing is that there has been absolutely nothing coming forth from the Government which would indicate that it sees some means in hand to reverse that decline, to ease the pressures that are being felt so solidly by the voters-indeed, the people who work in Australia, whether they be voters or not. Again, it was typical of the Government that when I raised in Question time this afternoon with Senator Button the steep price increases that have been experienced in respect of motor vehicles, he immediately gave us the ingenuous answer that that was principally because of devaluation. That was without any regard, of course, to whether the quite extraordinary devaluation of the Australian dollar that we saw a couple of years ago was in any way related to the actions of this Government and was, indeed, avoidable. It is so easily forgotten that the enormous rises in prices that people have had to pay for imported goods have not come out of thin air. They are something which flow from a loss of value of the Australian currency which, in itself, is related to the lack of economic management of the present Government and, not least, to the big spending Budgets and high taxing Budgets which marked its first two years in government.

This matter of public importance is brought forward at a time when it is quite clear that there is an extraordinary amount of unease within the Australian community. That unease is in no way confined to your State, Mr Acting Deputy President, which has just so remarkably rejected the New South Wales Labor Government. What we saw either on the same day, or in the recent past, was the same public unease evidenced in the ballot box in South Australia in the by-election for the seat of Adelaide, in the two State by-elections in my State of Western Australia, in the single by-election in Victoria and, of course, in the city council elections in Queensland, which was not a revulsion against the status quo but a strengthening of support for the Liberal administration of the Brisbane municipality.

I would like to record in the early part of this debate, which will, of course, focus on economic issues-issues which will be addressed by me, Senator Stone and Senator Lewis on behalf of the Opposition-that the unease in the community is not solely economic. There is a far wider sense of disquiet and concern. All that we are addressing in this debate this afternoon is one element of where the Australian Labor Party is seen to have failed the Australian community.

Serious questions are being asked about what sort of society is being produced under the virtual Labor government of the whole of Australia over recent years. There is widespread concern about crime rates. There is widespread concern about lack of respect for institutions and for values being put at risk. I believe it is important that in the remaining weeks of this session we should also have debate on some of the other issues which are causing such great concern in the community.

There is a real confusion, and I do no more than remark on it at this time. It seems to me that there is a growing resentment, for example, against minorities in the community. I express some personal concern for that. But I believe that that is arising from a situation in which there is not a seeking of equal treatment but, rather, a display of difference in a way which is causing concern among those who feel that the rights of the majority are threatened. Mr Acting Deputy President, I know that in this respect there are very difficult issues for the Australian community. I know that you have had a great deal of concern in this respect throughout your own political career.

I do no more than remark at the beginning of this debate that there are strains in the Australian community which I believe should be addressed and which this Government has dealt with in a thoroughly negative way. I mention Aboriginal policy as one example of where we have moved backwards instead of forwards. Many Labor supporters would share that view. I believe that just as the Government has been arrogant and contemptuous of those who have brought forward for consideration concerns about the direction of this country, it has been arrogant about those areas which, in the past, it has claimed to make its own.

I think it is also important to note that the disquiet in the community is not just about the Labor Party. There is also a deep disquiet about the role and functions of trade unions in this community. The diminishing membership of trade unions is one mark of that. The almost universal view that trade unions have too much power is another mark of it. The fact that trade unionists themselves substantially share that view is an indication again that this is an area in which reform is needed. Yet, again, this Government responds with arrogance and, indeed, with contempt, to those who criticise the status quo and bring forward suggestions for change.

One of the unhealthiest aspects of debate in Australia at the moment is the fact that quarrelling with this Government brings forth a torrent of personal abuse. The other day, Senator Lewis made a point to me. He said, `Mark it. When you criticise this Government the response will be in personal terms'. That is true. The reality is that this Government has made an art form of abuse. In particular, the Ministers who carry the primary responsibility for economic policy-Mr Keating and Senator Walsh-have been leaders in that. Words such as `sleazebag' and `scumbag' have become part of the vocabulary of this community because of what has been said by the political leaders of this Government, and those who are entrusted with the economic health of this country in particular. I hope that we can have some debate which is free from the negatives of the debate which has taken place in the past.

The contempt and arrogance of this Government is marked by the speaking team which it has put forward in this debate. We put forward this debate in the context of a substantial rejection by the Australian community of the Labor Party on the basis that there has been an enormous squeeze on living standards. I mean no personal disrespect in what I have just said about Government speakers. I see there is some jollity about the fact that I am suggesting that Senator Bolkus and the new senator for the Australian Capital Territory, Senator McMullan, are in some way unworthy participants in this debate. They know that that is not my point. My point is that this country faces critical economic problems and not one of the economic spokesmen for this Government is participating in this debate.

It may well be, of course, that the economic spokesmen simply do not have any answers because they do not know what to do in the May statement, they do not know what to do about the national wages policy and they do not know what to do about the excessive power of the trade unions. It may be that they are too embarrassed to take part. But we are to get a response on the declining living standards of Australia from a Minister who is in charge of consumer affairs. He will be backed up by backbench members of the Labor Party for whom I have respect. But it is a measure of either the arrogance of this Government or its incapacity to deal with the matters that have been raised that no economic spokesmen will participate in this debate.

I hope there will be no dispute that the economic concerns of the Australian people are very real. It was, I think, fashionable in Labor circles to laugh at those economic concerns when they were principally the concerns of farmers and small businessmen. Those concerns were raised in the early years of this Government before the squeeze on living standards had really begun to bite. Now the squeeze is on almost every Australian. I suppose some people have done fabulously well out of the Labor Party, and that includes those Labor Party apparatchiks who have found their way into this place. I have previously commented on the 27 trade unionists and five Labor bureaucrats who have found their way into the Parliament over recent years. They have certainly looked after themselves very well.

The truth is that throughout the towns and suburbs of Australia there is real hardship and difficulty. A polling booth worker I spoke to last weekend at a by-election in Balga, which is in the heartland of Labor territory in my State of Western Australia, said to me, `I have to moonlight because I cannot pay my bills'. He said, `I have supported the Labor Party all my life, but it has made life impossible for me'.

Another example of the arrogance of this Government has been its preparedness to laud itself as well as to abuse its critics. Mr Keating is famous for his vituperation; he is also famous for his self-praise. He is also well known for his convenient on-again, off-again arguments. Privatisation is vandalism in one year; it is a necessary economic reform in another. Mr Keating is the man who said that Europeans would be lighting candles in their cathedrals if they had an economy like that of Australia. I can only say that his judgment on that matter, like his judgment that economic policy is working like a charm, is sadly awry. It is not true in his electorate; it is certainly not true in Balga.

The reality is that to an Australian on a modest or medium income the prospect of purchasing a new car has now become a nightmare. I have given the figures already. There has been a 60 per cent increase in the price of a small car. This is the sticker shock that any car salesman will tell us about. That purchase has become an impossibility for a substantial number of Australian people who thought that they were in the middle income category.

Simple things like paying rent have become a nightmare. Rents have skyrocketed, most of all in Sydney where there is quite an extraordinary crisis. In Perth, which is my city, rents went up by nearly 30 per cent in one year. So we have a situation where renters, who in Australia are generally not affluent people, have been put under enormously heavy pressure by the policies of this Government, one of which was the negative gearing policy which the Government has been forced to reverse.

This Government has sought to meet that problem by putting more money into public housing. The effect has been-and we might hear from the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) on this-that in four years of Labor rule, the waiting lists for public housing have increased by something like 50 per cent. There have been huge increases in expenditure, but the overall economic approach has been such as to throw an increasing number of needy Australians onto the public housing lists. The reality is that a housing list of something like 100,000 when Labor came to government has become something like 150,000 today. Taxes and charges for middle and lower income Australians have become a nightmare. The figures show quite clearly that such Australians are paying a higher proportion of their incomes in tax than ever before.

Unemployment might be slightly down; but again, perhaps we will hear from Senator Bolkus about that. I think it is one of the proudest boasts of this Government-one of the things that I would be most pleased about if I were in the Government-that there has been a real increase in employment. I think all Australians should be very positive about that point. But what about the situation for the unemployed? There has been a slight diminution, a reduction of a couple of percentage points, in unemployment. The reality is that when one looks at the duration of unemployment one realises that a significant number of Australians are locked into extraordinary periods of unemployment. There has been a really massive rise there. I am glad to see Senator McMullan, who will be participating in this debate later, nodding. This is the sort of problem that is a nightmare for those who are caught in that trap.

The Government has done a lot in this regard. It has conducted great crackdowns on the unemployed. Imagine how we would have been branded as attackers of the weak and the unemployed if we had had a crackdown on the unemployed in the same way as the present Government. It has made a massive attempt to cleanse the unemployment rolls and yet there has been a substantial increase in the period for which people are on unemployment benefit. That is one of the most sobering and negative features of the present Government and perhaps that is one reason for having Senator Bolkus, who represents the Minister for Social Security in this place, participate in the debate.

Another matter to which I wish to refer because it is part of this general pattern of hardship is the fact that families with dependants have been sadly neglected by this Government for five years. The Government has acknowledged the cost of dependency for less than a quarter of Australian families. It has turned assistance for families with dependants into a matter of welfare and about 25 per cent of Australian families are getting some increased assistance under the family assistance supplement, which is an extension of the family income supplement which I, on behalf of the Fraser Government, introduced in 1982 for implementation in 1983. The reality is that all families outside that bottom quarter have seen their position, relative to that of the rest of the community, deteriorate under this Government. There has been no adjustment of family allowance and no adjustment to the taxation allowance for spouses. If honourable senators talk to middle income people who are trying to look after a spouse or who have a spouse working part time and who are trying to educate, house, clothe and bring up children, they will find that those people are experiencing enormous difficulties and they have received absolutely no acknowledgment from this Government in the last five years.

In this context many people are restless and resent the black tie and cigar image which has been referred to by Labor spokesmen. Let me touch on that very quickly because it can be seen as a footling criticism. If it is a criticism which suggests that Labor Ministers should not be in close communication with business, I reject it. I accept that Ministers of this Government should be in the closest possible communication with the business interests of this country, just as they should be in close communication with other sections. But as a former Minister for Social Security, my own experience is that one cannot understand the problems that one is administering and the people whom one is seeking to serve if one does not spend time with them.

Whilst the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) may see crowds in shopping centres rushing to touch his hem-that is a marvellous thing for the Prime Minister and I am sure he enjoys it-my own experience as a Minister trying to look after the interests of less fortunate Australians was that if one does not spend time with them, one does not really understand the bits of paper that are put in front of one. I believe that Labor and Liberal supporters alike are entitled to be concerned about whether this Government has made any real attempt to retain its connections with the working men and women of this country and with those who for various reasons cannot work. Whilst rejecting that tall poppy attack syndrome which says that a Prime Minister should not talk to a top businessman, I still say that there is a serious question about whether the people who shape and lead this Government have enough contact with the reality of Australia to properly govern this country in the general interest.

Very little time is left for me and I am grateful that Senator Stone and Senator Lewis will follow me in this debate. I am sick of this Government blaming the terms of trade. The terms of trade have turned around and suddenly the Treasurer is not talking about them. Commodity prices have risen and have helped to ease the situation, but suddenly there is no talk about terms of trade. The Government's response to the decline in our terms of trade was disastrous and it caused many of the difficulties we now face, just as its cosy relationship with the trade unions has stopped it from tackling some of the wealth destroying practices which are also part of the problem for the men and women of Australia. The reality is that taxes do not have to be so high. The Australian Financial Review now shows cartoons of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer awash with money. That is the reality. The Government is overtaxing and that is part of the reason for the hardship that is being experienced in the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to address the issue of the alleged failure of the Government to address the causes of the serious decline in Australian living standards. The matter of public importance which has been brought before the Senate today is nothing more or less than a scurrilous attempt to mislead the Australian public. We are being asked to treat the Australian public as a mob of mugs with short memories. Today we see the birth of the Australian Amnesia Party-appealing to people out in the electorates who cannot think back more than two or three years. Was it not the last Liberal Government that presided over a massive decline in living standards? Was it not Senator Stone who was the Secretary to the Treasury during the term of that Government? Was it not the Howard-Stone double which presided over such a massive decline and which went to the last election promising further cutbacks and burdens for the Australian population?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the record. When we came to government we were left with the legacy of a $10 billion deficit and an economy out of control. More importantly, we were left with a structural imbalance in our terms of trade. Today we have been asked to turn things around overnight by the wave of a magic wand. Senator Chaney said that there has been a turnaround in our terms of trade and asked why things had not been fixed up overnight. I am sure that his economic knowledge goes much further than to expect us to believe him when he makes those sorts of prognoses.

The new catchcry is that the Australian Labor Party has lost touch and the average working person feels that Labor no longer represents him. This claim is coming from all sections, but it is hypocrisy when it comes from members of the Liberal Party of Australia. What do they mean by this? Do they want us to forget that the Liberal Party opposed every wage rise for workers under the Hawke Government? Do they want us to forget that it was the Liberal Party in government that opposed 19 out of 21 applications for wage increases?

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to real incomes during the time? They rose.

—Babble on! Does it mean that Mr Howard, as Leader of the Liberal Party, forgets that he touted a policy of tax cuts for the rich and spending cuts for welfare at the last election? Does he ask us to forget that it was the Hawke Labor Government which created one million jobs? Was that an illusion? Does he ask the Australian public to believe that Labor's commitment to equity through measures such as the family assistance package does not exist? Mr Howard, Senator Chaney and others in the Opposition are basically saying, `We are the people for the time because we want to exploit the cynicism in the Australian community. We can lead them on. The times suit us. We have once again seen the opportunity to mislead and misconstrue'. At a time when the Press Gallery is running around wondering how the Government is going, it was interesting to note the results of a public opinion poll this morning. It showed the Labor Party's popularity down from the last election by 2.8 per cent. However, it showed that the Liberal Party's popularity is down 10 per cent from its position in July 1987-from 46 per cent to 36 per cent. This indicates to me--
—That you cannot rely on polls.

—It indicates to me, firstly, that we may not be able to rely on polls but, secondly, that the degree of cynicism that those opposite expect in the community is not there. Their shallow, easy, bandaid responses are not getting through. The Sydney Morning Herald summed up the situation rather succinctly in an editorial on 3 March 1988. Talking of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to maximise the Liberal vote, he turned his back on economic rationality. He-
that is Mr Howard-
seems to have damaged the Opposition's credibility with business generally . . .
It goes on:
He will be without the intellectual direction and policy content that made him an attractive alternative to Mr Peacock. He will become Mr Peacock's poor substitute.

It is rather curious also that the dry politics which have been presented to us by the Federal Liberal Party as the panacea for our ills were not supported in New South Wales. The Sydney Morning Herald said of Mr Greiner:
The first big Liberal victory since 1983-will it be won by a politician who is dripping wet?

Let us look at the record. Let us look at the reality. Let us compare our record with that of Senator Vanstone's Party in government. If the people out there are being asked to believe the allegations that the Opposition has made here this afternoon-

TALK.START.PARA: —You are being asked what is happening now.

—If Senator Vanstone has something to contribute, either in Question Time or in a debate, she should get herself on a speakers list. She should not just sit there cack-ling away, disrupting the debate. I ask her to be quiet and to listen for a second. Let us judge the Government's record and let us judge the basis from which the Opposition is starting in this debate. We talk about jobs. Under this Government there has been a growth of one million jobs-about 200,000 a year. The unemployment level is down from the 10.5 per cent that we inherited to 7.8 per cent. It should be noted that, if participation rates in the economy were what they were in 1983, the real level of unemployment now would be 3.7 per cent. I am one of those who applaud the increase in participation rates but, if we are to compare like with like, that should be noted. We should also compare with that record the fact that in the same operative period under the Liberal Government unemployment rose from 6.3 per cent to 10.5 per cent. Where is the Opposition's credibility on employment? Where is its credibility on growth in the economy? It presided over real negative growth, whereas this Government has presided over positive economic growth.

SPEECH.PARA: We talk about wages. It is rather interesting to digress for a moment and analyse Senator Chaney's contribution. He is concerned about living standards in the community and spent most of his speech talking about the sensitivities of doing too much for minority groups and his concern about our being too close to the trade unions. I would have thought that if Senator Chaney were looking at the most disadvantaged in our community, those with the greatest needs, he would be looking at the minority groups-at women, at the ethnic community and at wage and salary earners. He would not be coming in here in the context of a debate that he has put up and arguing that the Government is doing too much for those groups. We go on to the next step. Let us look at the wages record. The Opposition that comes here today concerned about falling living standards has opposed every wage increase application during the term of this Government and 19 out of 21 during the term of the previous Fraser-Howard-Stone regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under whose regime living standards rose.

—We will get to that in a moment. The reality is that, given the policies of those opposite, had they been in a position to have those policies implemented, a worker on $300 a week now would be earning $239 under the Howard-Stone policies. I say to Senator Messner and Senator Stone that if the Opposition's claims and arguments had been put through the arbitration system--
—What is your authority for this?

—I would never look to Senator Messner for an authority on anything. Let us go on to tax cuts. Senator Stone presided over the Treasury. He and his colleagues come to us now showing great concern about the decline in living standards of ordinary Australians. Let us compare the record and the promises. We have been responsible for three cuts in personal income taxation-in November 1984, December 1986 and July 1987. We have gone to the people with the intention and a real, meaningful desire to cut taxes, but what has the Opposition done? Its latest proposition on tax, put forward at the last election, was to abolish the assets test, to abolish the fringe benefits tax and to abolish the capital gains tax, all in all costing revenue $1,320m-money from those who can best afford it. Where is the concern for the ordinary wage and salary earner there?

SPEECH.PARA: We then go to the social wage. Our social wage policies have been questioned by Senator Chaney. Let us go across the board. He mentioned housing. We have provided an additional 70,000 rental dwellings in our five years of government, compared to 40,000 during the term of the Government of which Senator Chaney was a member. We have spent $5.3 billion on public housing during our time in office, more than three times the $1.7 billion that Senator Chaney was responsible for spending. We have provided home loans to 72,000 low income households compared with the former Government's 50,000. I am not saying that we are living in utopia, but Senator Chaney's credibility gap was on show for the whole 20 minutes in which he participated in this debate. Not only are we into direct involvement in housing in the ways that I have mentioned, but also the success of the first home owners scheme cannot be doubted. Since the inception of that scheme we have provided assistance totalling $1.2 billion. Families can get up to $6,000 deposit or interest subsidy and it has helped set up over 270,000 households. Compare that to the meagre ad hoc responses that were made from time to time by the Liberals.
I turn to child care, which is a major concern in the community, particularly to women and sole parents. We have approved 110,000 places with an expenditure--

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that got to do with living standards?

—Someone asks what it has got to do with living standards. It has a very basic connection with living standards. Senator Tambling's ignorance and the ignorance of the Opposition are shown very clearly on this issue. The provision of child care has a great impact on people's capacity to earn, to live. I am sure that Senator Vanstone, who has turned quiet for the first time in the last three weeks, would totally disagree with Senator Tambling's assessment of the situation. As of June 1982 there were 42,000 child care places. We have increased that figure to 110,000. Once again, this does not represent utopia, but it shows that we are very much down the right track.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the Government's major forthcoming concerns is the longer term unemployed and training programs for them. Under Fraser and Stone such assistance was not part of the dry economics at the time; it was rejected. Our policies are very much geared towards helping the long term unemployed get into the work force. In talking about assistance to low income earners and low income families, I turn to the Government's family package-assistance to low income families. I would like to read, for the information of cynical senators opposite, a letter that appeared in the West Australian of 14 March. It is not a Government gimmick or a public relations exercise; it is a letter that appeared unsolicited, written by a Mrs Kelly Spencer, Hovea Terrace, Kensington-someone I had never heard of. It reads:
Extra money
I would like to thank the person or persons in the office or department who devised, developed and approved the family allowance supplement for working families.

The extra $88 per month is a real Godsend. It means I can buy my son a winter dressing gown and a pair of joggers . . . And if I really want to spoil us I may even be able to buy a piece of meat for a Sunday roast.

This letter highlights the major concern shown by the Government for the poor in our community. The family allowance supplement package is geared towards giving assistance to 600,000 families with 1.2 million children. It is geared towards the Government's pledge to do away with child poverty. It is based on a payment of $22 per week for each child per family, a child from birth to 12 years old. It has a very high eligibility test. Under this Government child payments for people on social security have increased in real terms by 59 per cent. Under Senator Chaney's Government they decreased in real terms by 35 per cent. Opposition members are fully mindful of the fact that in July they went to the people prepared to cut the social wage by $7.8 billion. They said, `We do not care where it comes from, we will find the cuts'-$7.8 billion. What a hide they have today to cry crocodile tears over the decline in living standards of ordinary Australians. Not once did they address adequately the basic problems in the community. Not once did they show real concern for the living standards of all Australians. They went to the people with a program which would cut back all those areas I have mentioned, and more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you think people are so unhappy?

—Senator Chaney says he does not understand what this has to do with the motion before the chamber. Well, a basic concern to many Australians is the rate of their pensions and the rate of their social security incomes. But the disregard of those concerns of ordinary Australians was shown once again today by Mr John Elliott, the President of the Liberal Party. One does not know which part of the Party he is in these days but once again he is showing disregard for not only the living standards of ordinary Australians but also, may I suggest, the living standards of Liberal Party members in this place. He has come out in support of a consumption tax, something that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has opposed-something the Liberal Party national President is strongly in support of. This Government rejected a consumption tax because of its effect on ordinary Australians and ordinary Australians' living standards. The Liberals persist regardless and in doing so show the hypocrisy with which they treat the Australian electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality of this Labor administration has been to protect the interests of our constituency and of all Australians at the same time. As I have said, we have presided over an increase of one million jobs. The job growth in Australia under this Government has been more than twice that of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries and four times the growth under the previous Government. The unemployment rate is at its lowest level for 5 1/2 years. There is nothing more basic to the level of living standards of Australians than employment. This Government's record is far in excess of anything the Opposition was able to achieve.

In closing, let me go back to where I started. By bringing this motion before Parliament today the Opposition, in some cheap political endeavour to maximise any vote in Port Adelaide, is asking the Australian people not only to forget the record of Howard, Fraser and Stone but also to forget the promises of last July, the disregard for their living standards. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance which we debate today, brought on by the Opposition, is this:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to address the causes of the serious decline in Australian living standards.

So far we have heard from one Opposition and one Government member and I think we have come no closer to looking at causes, although there has been a sense of `anything you can do I can do better'-or worse, depending on whether one is in the high income or low income bracket. It seems, as it very often does to the Australian Democrats in this place and elsewhere, that the tunes are very often similar. We do not deny for one minute that there has been and continues to be a serious decline in the living standards of a great many Australians. We are happy to be involved in a debate about the causes of those declines. As I said, we tend to find a similarity in the tunes played on both sides of this House because the economic agenda in Australia has been shifted to the right. The Hawke Government, the Opposition and the business community appear to be abandoning the role of government that people have expected since the depression of the 1930s. That is the sort of role that saw the Government setting broad social parameters to direct society. The Government played a role in reducing inequality by providing income, education, health and social security services and by ensuring that all Australians benefited from industrial development and economic growth.

Today the role of government seems to be seen by both sides of the House to be increasingly limited to serving the immediate aims of Australian and international businessmen and financiers. This shift has come about because the Hawke Government and its predecessors have encouraged the Australian economy to become overly dependent on the fortunes of the world economy and, with that, the whims of international financiers and transnational corporations. It is fascinating to see reported in the Press on 5 March the release by the Federal Opposition of a document called Five Years Hard Labor in which the Opposition appears to be complaining about the fact that this has happened. The document says:
. . . through economic mismanagement, Labor has systematically whittled away Australia's economic sovereignty and delivered us firmly into the hands of foreign bankers.

This is a move which was applauded by the Opposition, a move not taken by the Opposition when it was in government only because those people who wanted to introduce foreign banks into Australia and deregulate the economy to the extent that it is now deregulated could not hold sway over Prime Minister Fraser at the time. What they wanted to do has been progressively done and continues to be done by this Government. What we always hear from the Opposition side when these moves are made is a bleating which says, `Gee whizz, they have done it again, stolen some of our policies'. Of course the big losers in all of this are the ordinary Australians, low and middle income earners, and those dependent on government income support.

Let us look at what is happening first of all with the external sector-issues of foreign debt, foreign borrowings and foreign ownership. Our gross foreign debt which was below $6 billion in 1975 had risen to more than $35 billion in 1983. It is now more than $110 billion and still growing. The problem associated with that debt is now the paramount economic issue in Australia. It means that we must, first of all, pay interest on the debt. To do this in foreign currency we export more, import less, borrow more or sell more Australian assets-farms, homes, land and industries-to overseas investors. Of course, eventually we must reduce the debt. In the meantime, we pander to those who lend to us because they need to be encouraged to lend to us again when borrowings need to be rolled over. Those who have loaned to us demand cuts in expenditure, tax cuts for businesses and higher income earners, less government borrowings and reductions in the level at which our industries are protected. They are not concerned about the social consequences in Australia of these actions. Our level of indebtedness continues to grow, albeit at a slower rate. Instead of trying to reduce our indebtedness, the Government is encouraging us into greater and greater debt. It is not the ordinary Australians, the people we are discussing today whose standard of living is declining, who borrow overseas. About two-thirds of our foreign debt has been borrowed by our private business sector. In the late 1970s it borrowed heavily to invest in our resources industry, anticipating a resources boom that never happened.

Since the deregulation of our financial market and the floating of the Australian dollar in late 1983, Australian enterprises have borrowed to finance share speculation and takeover activity. The Government continues to encourage borrowing by allowing the taxpayer to subsidise foreign borrowings through the process of negative gearing, a process which the Democrats consistently have opposed in this place and which the Government has yet to do anything about. I refer to borrowing on unproductive company takeovers and mergers and then not paying tax on the interest of those borrowings. One looks at what happened with Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. The buying and selling of BHP, Elders IXL Limited and Bell Group Limited shares, in the struggle for control of BHP since 1983 have added over $9 billion to our foreign debt and cost at least $680m in revenue.

Let us look at foreign investment, an area that is typical of the Government's shortsighted approach. We are so desperate for foreign currency that the Government has reduced the controls on foreign investment in Australia. Foreign investment has almost doubled in the past 12 months from $9.8 billion in 1985-86 to $18.5 billion in 1986-87. The Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) has suffered staff cuts and the Government is exempting more and more transactions from its surveillance. I feel that the FIRB should properly be renamed the foreign investment approval board. The short term benefit that Australia gets is foreign currency. However, it also means that increasingly Australian houses, farms, factories and industries are sold to overseas owners, the price of a house to a struggling Australian family rises and more of our media is sold off to foreign buyers. In many ways this has the effect of lowering our standard of living.

Transfer pricing is another issue in the external sector with which the Government has not come to grips. Australia is converting at a rapid rate its foreign debt problem into a foreign ownership problem, which opens up further avenues for tax evasion by transnational companies. A company that operates in many countries can shift profits around, and does, from country to country, so that the biggest profits are made in countries that will tax that profit at the lowest rates. That process is another that the Government is not addressing and is another cause of a loss of revenue to this country, and consequently down the track a lowering in the living standards of many Australians.

The more Australian industry is owned by transnationals, the more tax revenue will continue to be lost. Last year the Commonwealth Auditor-General told the Australian Taxation Office that billions of dollars of revenue may be lost in this way. The Australian Democrats have been pointing this out to governments since 1977. Now our Tax Office is beginning to investigate such schemes. Only last week the Tax Office announced that it had discovered that $1 billion was transferred to an Australian company operating in Monaco.
. . . as part of the setting up and implementation of profit shifting, transfer pricing and other intended tax avoidance schemes'.

That is a quotation from a report by the Tax Office. If Australia cuts its company tax rates to counter this form of tax avoidance, other countries will cut their tax rates further, business will be very happy with this downwards spiral, we could get close to a zero rate, but it would be at the expense of ordinary Australians and of the poor. It is the logical conclusion of an international competition to produce the lowest tax rates for industry and investors. It is an international downward spiral into which we have been tightly locked by this Government.

Taxation in general can be used to encourage or discourage particular economic activities and to redistribute incomes and access to services which promote equality of opportunity. The Hawke Government and the Opposition parties, which in recent times have been mesmerised by New Right economics, are inclined to use our tax system to allow business to do whatever it wants and to redistribute more income and wealth to the wealthiest Australians. In regard to this matter of public importance it is certainly not all Australians whose living standards have gone down. Australia now has over 30,000 millionaires; 10 per cent of the Australian population owns 60 per cent of the wealth of Australia while at the same time over two million Australians live below the poverty line.

The Government's response to this is to give the biggest tax cuts to the highest income earners and to cut the provision of basic services-health, education, child care and so on. Now the Government seeks to pander to big business in Australia, which wants corporate tax rates to be cut. Ten years ago pay as you earn (PAYE) collections accounted for 53.7 per cent of total revenue and company tax for 17.8 per cent. Now PAYE taxpayers contribute 55.8 per cent and company tax has fallen to 12.7 per cent. Let us not forget that this has been during a period of significant wage restraint. Between June 1983 and December 1987 the consumer price index rose by 36 per cent and in that same period the average male award rates of pay rose by 23 per cent only. In 1985-86 corporate taxes as a proportion of gross domestic product in Australia were lower than in Britain or Japan. Yet we hear all this bleating from both sides of politics about the necessity for lowering corporate tax rates here as well.

Once social security levies borne by employers are included, Australian companies enjoy the second lowest tax burden in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. The lowest overall corporate tax rates are in Turkey. Despite a nominal corporate tax rate of 49 per cent, we well know that many of Australia's biggest companies pay very little tax. In 1987, the Adelaide Steamship Company Co. Ltd paid less than one per cent of its profits in tax, Bell Group 10.46 per cent, and Elders IXL 10.48 per cent, and so on. That is the sort of picture which leads to a reduction in the living standards of ordinary Australians. The businessmen who complain that pensions are draining our system fight to protect superannuation concessions that amount to over $3 billion of government revenue forgone. They also ignore the fact that under current superannuation concessions those on highest incomes get the highest government subsidised benefits, while low income earners, social security recipients, women-who do not participate at anywhere near the same level as men in superannuation schemes-and those who work part time, an increasing proportion of our work force, get little or no benefit from over $3 billion of annual tax concessions.

Taxes can be used one way or the other and indirect taxes could scarcely be topped for taxes which have the potential to be regressive. This morning on Michael Schildberger's show on ABC radio the Liberal Party President, John Elliott, was campaigning very hard-once again exceeding his brief to speak only on current policies in the Liberal Party-for the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax. On that program, I understand, he said that he and Mr Howard were at one on that issue. It is an issue which if carried out would be very much to the detriment of the living standards of a very great many people in Australia. It appears that this is to be the subject of a major national conference or meeting of the Liberal Party the week after Easter. I am sure that the voters of Port Adelaide, to whom I am sure the Opposition has addressed its thoughts in bringing forward this matter of public importance, will be interested in this development.

Those voters will recall vividly that Paul Keating-the other heir apparent of the other conservative party in this place-went to the National Taxation Summit pushing hard too. But for community groups, the welfare sector, political opposition from the Australian Democrats, among others, and the unions we might now have such a tax. We have seen creeping growth in indirect taxes in any case, even though the whole issue was knocked on the head. We saw in last year's Budget increasing indirect taxes on wine, and we saw the introduction of indirect taxes on milk and fruit juice, taxes which only the Democrats opposed. This extremely regressive form of taxation is a creeping form of taxation. There is an obvious need for tax reform. Australian Democrat electorate surveys have just begun on the question of raising the tax threshold to avoid poverty traps which exist for pensioners and low income earners. We have had a 100 per cent response at the beginning of this survey on the question of tax reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most remarkable feature of this debate is the fact that Senator Chaney could say all the things he did say with a straight face. This matter of public importance looks like something that has come out of a time warp. Five years ago it would have been entirely appropriate because the government of the day was failing to address the causes of the serious decline in Australian living standards. Today that is not the case. I shall shortly deal with some of the comparisons, records and reviews of the current economic circumstances in order to deal with that question.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I do so, I wish to refer to comments made by Senator Chaney and Senator Powell. I waited with interest to hear Senator Chaney's articulation of the causes of the serious decline in Australia's living standards but he never referred to them. He gave an interesting little discourse and detoured through obviously what was the trivia and minutiae of the market research of the Liberal Party of Australia and said, `If I throw something in about minorities this will pick up a few people in Port Adelaide; they might be worried about that too', but he never actually mentioned anything about the causes of the serious decline in Australia's living standards. If honourable senators had listened hard they might have thought that there was some reference to the 1983 Budget and he even reluctantly acknowledged that perhaps something had happened to Australia's terms of trade. TALK.START.PARA: —Induced by the trade union movement, Senator, as you know perfectly well.

—It is true that the Government at that time was not in proper control of the economy-there is not any doubt about that-and I think the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate (Senator Stone) and others should take responsibility for that. There was a recession and they were responsible. But Senator Chaney's detour through trivia did not in any way deal with the causes. He had the grace to refer to the fact that the Government made an outstanding contribution to the living standards of one million Australians because it had put them in jobs. I would like to refer to some of the contrasts in a moment. On a couple of occasions, for those former Western Australians, such as Senator Stone and me, Senator Chaney threw in the name of a working class suburb such as Balga just to prove that he has been to one. I think it is the first time that he has visited Balga since the last by-election there in 1973.
—Of course, you would know, Senator, wouldn't you?
—I think I have been there slightly more often than the honourable senator.
—How long is it since you have been there? You wouldn't have a clue.

—Fortunately, I have lived in Canberra for seven years and I have not had to put up with that sort of problem recently. When the by-election was held in Balga in 1973-the Australian Labor Party only just won that-Senator Chaney might have been there. He has not been there since but he thought that he would throw in a couple of references to prove how in touch he was. In the course of that he was trying to establish that the Labor Party was out of touch.

SPEECH.PARA: Just to show how in touch the Liberal Party is, I am reminded of a photograph I saw in the newspapers and on television during the last election, which I enjoyed tremendously, of my friend and former counterpart, the director of the Liberal Party, Mr Eggleton, Mr Howard and the President of the Liberal Party, the then Treasurer of the Liberal Party, Mr Elliott, going for a campaign review, trotting up the steps of the Melbourne Club. Perhaps they were going there to get in touch with the electorate, to get in touch with the feelings of ordinary Australians in that home of the elite. No wonder they came up with the tax policy that they did. I am sure that it was very popular in the dining room of the Melbourne Club. It reminds me of an anecdote from Mr Peter Howson's diaries in which he said, `I felt the need to get in touch with the electorate so I went to lunch at the Melbourne Club'. Not only did he do that regularly but also Mr Elliott, Mr Howard and Mr Eggleton did it during the last election and that is an example of with whom they are in touch and whose interests they serve.

I will make only a brief reference to the contribution of Senator Powell because it was not an unusual Australian Democrat contribution. She really said, `If only the world were different things would be easier'. That is true. If only we could disentangle ourselves from the international economy the world would be a much easier place and the economy could be managed, but we cannot. We actually have to trade to survive and we have to live in the international economic community. We cannot wish away the problems. We cannot say, `If only the world were different'. We have to deal with the world as it is.

I would like now to deal with some of the Australian economic facts as they are and to look at some of the comparisons. I would like to look at some things initially besides wages, although I want to come back to that because, as Senator Bolkus said in his contribution, there is a very important point to be made. Living standards are more than just wages, even if Senator Tambling was unable to appreciate the relationship between child care and living standards somewhat earlier. Let me refer to some of the comparisons between the performance of this Government in dealing with issues that affect the living standards of ordinary Australians and the performance of the previous Fraser Government in which Mr Howard was Treasurer. I will not dwell on the question of jobs because it was so well covered by Senator Bolkus, but there are one million more Australians in employment now compared with a fall of 186,000 in the last year of the Fraser Government. Unemployment has fallen to 7.4 per cent. I do not pretend that that is a satisfactory level; nobody could find a 7.4 per cent unemployment rate satisfactory; it is still too high. But we must compare it with the fact that in the last year of the Fraser Government and because of the legacy which this Government inherited there was an increase of a quarter of a million people who were unemployed and the rate was higher than 10 per cent. Inflation is on track to be at 6 per cent by mid-year compared with 11.5 per cent when the Fraser Government was removed from office and, of course, that was not the high point; it had been 12.3 per cent during that year.

Senator Chaney referred to the fact that there has been an increase in waiting lists for public housing. One of the reasons undoubtedly is-we all know the lead times in dealing with these matters-that in the last 12 months of the Fraser Government there was a 20 per cent fall in housing commencements; a 16 per cent fall in housing finance approvals and commencements were at the lowest level for 20 years. Of course, that creates the backlog of demand for housing. A 20 per cent fall in commencements and a 20-year low in housing commencements must cause a shortfall in housing. It has. It is a backlog that needs to be overcome. It is being overcome.

Having made some comparisons, let me turn to some more explicit references to the record of the Hawke Government in dealing with issues of relevance to the living standards of Australians. I have referred to the question of jobs which have been created at more than twice the rate of the Western industrialised world and four times the rate of the Fraser-Howard Government. I have referred to the decline in the unemployment rate. Senator Bolkus referred to the introduction of the family package of tax-free cash assistance for families. I have referred to the question of inflation and the fall in recent times in interest rates. We have the raising of the age pension by 8.4 per cent in real terms; the introduction of the home and community care program to improve the choices available to elderly Australians in need of care; assistance to 270,000 young families through our first home owners scheme; the doubling of funding for public housing with 220,000 more families now living in public housing; a 28 per cent increase in real terms of general recurrent funding for each child at school and a trebling of the financial assistance for poor students and the restoration and improvement of Medicare which has protected almost two million Australians who previously were without health insurance. We have more than doubled the number of child care places that were provided under the Fraser-Howard Government. Underpinning all this, we have reformed the tax system to make it fairer and more efficient and, as Senator Bolkus said, we have delivered tax cuts three times in the period we have been in office which has created a tax saving of approximately $14 per week for someone earning $400 a week. That is not a perfect record. Nobody likes to be in government in a time when there has been a decline in real wages. I should not imagine that anybody would prefer that to be the situation. Nobody would deny that the international circumstances with which we have had to deal have made the decline in national living standards inevitable as they have had their impact on gross domestic product in Australia.

I would like briefly to review some of the other current economic circumstances that indicate the broad economic situation in which Australia finds itself, the competence with which this Government has adjusted to those international economic demands that have been imposed on it and with which it and many other countries have had to deal. I refer to the overview of the economy provided in the latest Treasury Round-up which states:

Information available since the stockmarket decline points to a continuing growth in the Australian economy, further improvement in the current account of the balance of payments, and easing consumer price pressures.

It goes on to refer quite accurately, at that time in February, to the improvement in the Australian dollar but, of course, could not possibly refer to the March situation where the dollar is back at above 74c. In other areas of the overview it states:
The upturn in housing activity remains strong.
Notwithstanding a small fall in December, the number of private residential building approvals (seasonally adjusted) rose by 14.5 per cent in the December quarter 1987.
Associated with the lift in new building activity, the number of housing finance approvals for new dwellings (seasonally adjusted) rose by 22.8 per cent in the December quarter.
That compares with a 20 per cent decline in the last 12 months of the term of the Fraser Government. With regard to the labour market trends, The Round-up said:
After some apparent hesitancy immediately following the share price fall, employment grew strongly in December and January and the unemployment rate fell.

Further, it said that the balance of payments is $2,000m lower than the deficit recorded in the same period in 1986-87, and that the gap between Australia's inflation rate and that of our major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development trading partners narrowed. No-one says there are no economic problems still to be confronted. No-one says that the Australian economy has not been through a difficult period. What must be said is that there have been substantial economic and social achievements in that context, and the conditions have been created in which real wage decreases can start to be turned around-as the most recent Economic Planning Advisory Council paper on medium term growth pointed out. It is inevitable in dealing with the matter of public importance raised by the Leader of the Opposition that we must look at a comparison of the alternative Government's policies for living standards. As Senator Bolkus said, the Liberal Party and the National Party have opposed every wage rise that workers have sought during the term of the Hawke Government. In fact, they opposed any wage increase on 19 of the last 21 occasions on which increases were sought. By way of comparison, under the wages policy within the accord there has been a series of indexed wage rises totalling more than 22 per cent. Therefore, a worker who received $400 a week in March 1983 when the Australian Labor Party first came to power is today receiving at least $90 a week extra as a result of national wage price increases. That is $90 a week that has been opposed at every step of the way by the representatives of the Liberal and National parties.

—No-one is denying that there has been a decline in real wages. However, if the total level of wages were less, one's real wage would necessarily be even lower.
