TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. According to the figures prepared by the Parliamentary Library in 1982-83 the real disposable income-that is, after inflation and after tax-of a male employee with a dependent spouse and two dependent children was $21,406. In 1986-87 that same employee receives $20,425 a year. That is a significant fall over the course of four years, during the whole of which period this Government has been in office. Though I do not have the figure for 1987-88, all the indications are, based on the Government's own forecast, that the figure will either fall again or, if it rises, will rise by the most marginal amount. The fall in real incomes after tax in 1986-87 was the first time in 30 years that this important measure of family welfare went backwards-and it did so during the term of the present Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important to note that in thinking of how one arrives at calculations of incomes after tax, one has to take account not only of tax rates but also of what used to be called concessional allowances. The two most important elements in family incomes, apart from the actual wage or salary, are the dependent spouse rebate and the family allowance, properly so-called. Under this Government both the family allowance and the dependent spouse rebate have remained unchanged in money terms. In other words, both of those factors have fallen by approximately 30 per cent in real terms after adjusting for the inflation that has occurred during the life of the present Government.

Real disposable income is income after tax and after adjustment for inflation. Let us consider what has happened with taxes and inflation. Under the present Government taxes have jumped sharply, particularly for the single income family. One has only to look at the publicly available figures to see that a single income family on average weekly earnings was in March 1983, when this Government came to office, paying 17.5 per cent of income in tax. In January of this year that same family had to pay 22.5 per cent of its income in tax. That represents an additional 5 percentage points of income being used to pay taxes. Equally importantly, in some ways, whereas five years ago the marginal tax rate-that is to say the tax rate being paid on the last dollar of income being earned by a wage and salary earner-was only 30 per cent, today it is 40 per cent. He pays 40 per cent if he goes out and works a bit more overtime or does something of that kind. Tax for single income families has risen by 80 per cent during those five years, which is far higher than the rate of increase in money incomes. It is not just inflation that has been running faster than the rise in money incomes in some years; the rise in tax-take from people has been running much faster. Hence the residual, what is left, in the pay packet after adjustment for taxes and inflation has declined sharply.

The problem with tax under the present Hawke-Keating Government is not confined to income tax. During this Government's period of office, the excise on petrol has more than trebled. When this Government came to office it was 6c a litre; today it is 20c a litre. Although the world price of oil has halved in the last five years-it was about $US34 a barrel when this Government came to office and about $US16 a barrel last month-the price of petrol has risen by almost 30 per cent, from roughly 44c a litre in the March quarter of 1983 to roughly 57c a litre in the last quarter of 1987. All motorists are aware that the Government has had its hand in their pockets not merely by way of income tax but by way of petrol tax.

There has been a whole host of imposts. Time will not permit me to go through them all, but I will take one because it also illustrates the value one can place on the assurances one receives from the present Hawke-Keating Government. When Mr Hawke gave the rural policy speech on 23 February 1983 during the election campaign, he said:
Labor has pledged not to impose a sales tax or any excise on wine.

However, in the 1984 Budget-less than 18 months later-his Treasurer (Mr Keating) duly introduced a wine sales tax of 10 per cent, as it was then. As I have said, the other new and increased taxation imposts under this Government are too numerous to mention within the time available to me. So much for taxes. What about inflation? Under the present Government, the cost of living in Australia has risen at a rate far exceeding the rates of our major trading partners abroad and is still doing so. It is still rising at double the rate of our major trading partners and, in the case of some of the more important ones, the rate is much more than double. In the 12 months ended December 1987, the Australian consumer price index rose by 7.1 per cent. In the United States the figure was 4.5 per cent; in France, 3.2 per cent; in the Federal Republic of Germany, one per cent; and in Japan, 0.4 per cent. Those are the kinds of comparative performances which I think are being hammered home to Australians year after year-not merely as a matter of academic interest but because those relative rates of inflation in this country are what, in the end, determine the rate of depreciation of our dollar against the currencies of the other countries concerned-that is, the deutschemark and the Japanese yen. The continual depreciation of our currency is what, in turn, feeds our domestic inflation and wage-price spiral which feeds back into the cost of living for Australians.

One can cite many arid statistics on the cost of living, but this phenomenon hurts Australians when they fill up their cars with petrol-a matter to which I have already referred-or replace their cars. Senator Chaney has already referred to the fact that in the past three years or so there has been an explosion in the price of motor vehicles in Australia. He quoted the price of a Ford Laser having risen by 63 per cent between May 1984 and December 1987. It may be that a more representative vehicle-certainly, it is the one which puts the best complexion on it from the Government's point of view-would be a Ford Falcon, the price of which rose by 43 per cent during the same period. Everybody who contemplates having to replace a motor car these days is confronted with what Senator Chaney quite rightly referred to as `sticker shock'-that is, shock at the sight of the price sticker on the vehicle, if it has one.

The matter of public importance before us speaks not merely about the fact that there has been a serious decline in Australian living standards but the Government's failure to address the causes of that serious decline. I want to spend my last remaining minute or two dealing with that subject. Why are real incomes not rising? Real incomes can rise in only two ways. They can rise because, once again, we benefit from the `lucky country' syndrome-that is, a movement in the international terms of trade which is favourable to us; the price of our exports rises, through no effort on our part, and suddenly we can buy more imports and be richer as a consequence. In that sense living standards can rise. That has not happened, although one of the things about which the Government has been conspicuously silent is that during 1987-88 our terms of trade have improved by something like 7 per cent. Yet, notwithstanding that, real incomes in Australia are still falling. That is one way in which real incomes can rise.

The other way in which real incomes can rise is the fundamental way because it is the only way we can influence it ourselves-that is, by increasing our productivity; by increasing our production per worker, per head of population in the end. What is happening in that area is a national scandal. We have a whole battery of restrictive work practices-we have restrictive trade practices also-imposed on us by our trade union bosses. Partly as a consequence of that we have a very poor record in terms of business investment. That is not a criticism of the business men and women making those decisions. They are confronting a situation in which the after-tax return on such investments is very heavily depressed. On some measures, it is little more than half of what it was in the late 1960s. Even on the most favourable measures, it has not recovered to the level of the late 1960s and early 1970s. Under those circumstances, it is hardly surprising that we are not getting increases in productivity. Until we get increases in productivity, we cannot hope to stem this serious decline in Australian livings standards to which this matter of public importance is addressed. In the immortal words of Senator Richardson last Monday, this Government `has forgotten what the common people are all about-we don't understand them any more'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The terms of the matter of public importance are:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to address the causes of the serious decline in Australian living standards.

I was not able to hear all of Senator Chaney's contribution in opening this discussion for the Opposition, but I have no reason to dispute my colleagues Senator Bolkus and Senator McMullan who pointed out that he had nothing to say. I then listened to Senator Powell, on behalf of the Australian Democrats. I found one of her comments most remarkable, that is, that this country has become overly dependent on international markets. I am not sure whether I can conclude from that that Senator Powell suggests that we should build a wall around Australia or go back to trying to build the one we thought we had for a while, or what she proposes. If I understand anything from what Opposition speakers-not the least being Senator Stone in his contribution-or our own speakers in this debate are saying, it is our relationship with the rest of the world that is critical.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that, Senator.

—I am about to paraphrase what Senator Stone said to show that that is what he did say. Senator Powell also seemed to suggest that it was the Australian Democrats who helped in the debate against Mr Keating's option C. I must say that I think that Senator Powell was off on a remarkably misdirected Australian Democrat shot there-allowing all power to the Australian Democrats but not, I suggest, any real understanding. We have just heard Senator Stone's contribution to the debate. He referred early in his speech to the serious decline in Australia's living standards and then said that he would come back to the causes of that decline later. He balanced his contribution to the debate by addressing the causes-that seemed to be the opening line of Opposition speakers to the debate-in only the last three minutes of his speech. In fact, he conceded very significantly that the terms of our trade are critical to the wealth of this country. In fact, I think that in his remarks he conceded de facto the point made by any number of speakers for the Government. I refer not only to the remarks of my two colleagues speaking for the Government in the debate today and the spokespeople for the Government in the debate in the other place yesterday, but also to the numerous times in which there have been speeches on behalf of the Government in this sort of debate over the last five years.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important in particular to read what was said by members of the Opposition in the House of Representatives yesterday. I refer to page 1121 of the House of Representatives Hansard for 22 March 1988. In that debate Mr Howard said:

I return to the question of the slump in living standards. It is undeniable that one of the reasons why living standards have fallen over the last five years is the adverse effect on the Australian economy of the downturn in commodity prices during that time. The Opposition has never at any stage over the last five years denied that fact. Never at any stage have we sought to argue that that is not an element.

That is a statement from the Opposition. From the mouth of Mr Howard yesterday and, I think, from Senator Stone's mouth today, we have a clear understanding of one of the most significant causes of the decline in Australian living standards. As the Opposition has acknowledged, it is as a result of `the adverse effect on the Australian economy of the downturn in commodity prices during that time'. That is something that cannot be sheeted home to the Government. It is something that the Government has had to deal with. It is something the Government has dealt with.

I think it is important to acknowledge that the Opposition says that that is the case. The Opposition knows precisely the cause of the serious decline in Australia's living standards. However, somehow the Opposition has failed significantly to address the problem today-although I must say that Mr Howard made those remarks in speaking to the same matter of public importance yesterday in the other place. Lest anyone hasten to say that I misquoted or only partially quoted Mr Howard, I add that he went on to say in spite of accepting the contribution to the downturn in the terms of trade that commodity prices cause, that it was the Labor Government's policies in its first two years out of five years in office that made a `direct and major contribution to the decline in living standards' of the Australian people. Mr Howard said that in particular the expansionary fiscal policy of the first Labor Government Budget and its allowing the highest deficits in Australia's post-war history were very significant contributors to the decline in living standards. I turn now to page 1124 of the same House of Representatives Hansard to quote from Mr Keating's defence-which I think says it as well as anything in response to those statements by Mr Howard. When the Government came to office, it had to deal with the enormous difficulties left to it by seven years of coalition government. In particular, I refer to the massive deficit, massive unemployment and double digit inflation left to it. Mr Keating said:

In changing Australia this Labor Government did not ram it into a recession with increasing unemployment, so that the unemployed took the brunt of the losses. We did it sympathetically to that working class constituency out there. We said, `We are unable to provide massive increases in real wages, but we will ensure higher employment growth'.

Clearly, that was the aim of the Government. Clearly, that is why the Opposition cannot hold its head up in bringing forward this matter of public importance for debate today. As Mr Howard has acknowledged, it is a matter of fact that falling commodity prices have been the root cause of the decline in the living standards of Australians. In large part it is true that there has been a reduction in real wages-although Senator Stone was not accurate in relation to all wage categories. I noted that when he was addressing figures in regard to Australian wage earners he somehow slipped over the benefit now available to workers as a result of the superannuation contribution. As well as that, the Government, appreciating the difficulty on its hands, has been at pains to extend, increase and target its spending under the social wage. My colleagues have actually highlighted some of those points. I want to pick up on those points again. While it is true that there has been a drop in real wages, it is also true that huge and very successful efforts have been made by this Government to ensure that there is a buffer against the difficult times through the development and promotion of a social wage.

We have seen the creation of one million new jobs in the five years since we came to office. It is true that for people already in the work force it may not seem of direct benefit to have the bloke or the girl next door get a job. However, workers who examine seriously what happens to their tax expenditure and how the Government has to focus its costs will know that for every worker out of work there is a loss of revenue to the Government and a direct outlay in terms of social security payments. Certainly too, people who were previously unemployed and who have now got jobs know very well that they are far better off now than when they were locked into the poverty of benefits and/or pensions. I do not think that we should blush at all for overseeing the creation of one million jobs in those five years. It is an extraordinary, quite fantastic, achievement. It is a rate twice that of any of our Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development competitor countries. Certainly, it is four times the best that the Opposition could do when it was managing things. I noticed that Senator Townley interjected in the course of Senator Bolkus's speech and asked his reason for citing child care as a contributor to the living standards of Australians. What a remarkable line!

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Townley? Are you operating in a time warp?

—I beg Senator Knowles's pardon; Senator Townley's name was given to me. I could not see who said it. Is Senator Lewis going to claim that it was him? Someone from the Opposition said that child care-I know it was not Senator Knowles--
—Senator Townley has not been in this Parliament since the last election.

—I beg the pardon of honourable senators. I wonder who said it. One Opposition senator seemed to insist-it was a man, so I ask Senator Knowles and Senator Bjelke-Petersen not to worry; it was neither of them-that expenditure by the Government on child care which has resulted in a more than doubling of child care places in the last five years has not contributed at all to the living standards of Australians. That is an absolutely remarkable confession of a failure to understand what child care provisions are about. These places are not a kind of whimsy on the part of government. They represent the Government's recognition of the fact that if we are to be on track for economic recovery and increased productivity in this country, then we have to make provision for all people who want the opportunity to work, to train, to study and to contribute to the productivity of this country, to enable them to do so. If such people have a responsibility for children, they need child care. Child care is a hard economic necessity. Child care is part of this Government's overall economic understanding. It is a recognition by the Government not only of the economic necessity and reality of child care but also of the social justice implications of it. Any women or men who are currently benefiting in their work or study because they have proper and comprehensive child care provisions know very well how important that child care is to their own living standards and as a contribution to the Government's program towards increased productivity and recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as child care places, we have also seen an enormous increase in the number of children staying on at school to year 12. The Government has a direct policy to encourage children to do so. In fact the results are remarkable. I notice from the matriculation results in South Australia this year that the retention rate for year 12 is not the 50 per cent that the Government hoped to reach but well over 60 per cent. Already in my State retention rates have gone from 36 per cent in 1982-83 to over 60 per cent in 1987-a remarkable turnaround. This is, of course, a critical part of this Government's economic program for recovery and proper and full participation of all its citizens. This is clearly of benefit to the living standards of Australians.

At the same time, we have seen a dramatic increase in the number of tertiary places available for those children who finish school or those older people in our community who make the decision to come back into study. According to the last figures that I saw more than 49,000 extra tertiary places had been created in the years of Labor government until 1987. I see that the figures presented the other day by the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) indicate that there has been a considerable increase on that number this year. Again, that opportunity to study is part of an improvement, and the prospect of further improvement, in the living standards for Australians.

I will not cite again the housing figures. Senator Bolkus said that 70,000 new houses had been started under Labor compared with 40,000 under the coalition Government. Senator Chaney interjected and said, `But the waiting lists are longer'. Can I conclude that Senator Chaney argues that we should not build houses so that we can keep the waiting lists shorter? I have never heard a more specious argument in all my days.

My colleagues have spelt out the targeted and splendid increase in living standard provisions for low income workers by means of the family allowance package. This package not only provides $22 for children under 13 years of age and $28 for children between 13 and 16 years of age, taking into account the extra costs involved with older children, but also provides rent assistance of up to $15 for people in the private rental market. As well as that, there has been an increase in the allowance which parents receive to help them deal with the costs associated with the care of disabled children.

The Opposition takes no account of the targeting by the Government of increased expenditure in the social wage area clearly because of its cheap preference for scoring mean political points. None of the people who are beneficiaries of the community service programs, of the increased expenditure in education, of our great Medicare contribution that guarantees that the previously uninsured two million Australian are not denied access to health care, will be other than appreciative of what has happened since the Labor Government came to office.

There is a furphy around that we have not been true to Labor policies. It is a furphy. In fact, it is now becoming something like a gross lie. It is certainly not the case. The living standards of Australians have declined only in the real wages sense. The Government's achievements in other areas, such as community services which were made during very difficult economic times, need to be on the record. The Government needs to be congratulated for dealing with that very difficult situation of the loss of income and wealth to this country. We should also take into account the consequence of that in terms of the living standards of Australians. In addition, we should take note of the benefits that the Government has been able to provide for so many Australians, particularly those at the lower income level and pensioners and beneficiaries, during that time. This Government has taken steps to ensure that, while living standards have to be addressed when times are tough, it makes its contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the matter of public importance brought forward by my colleague, Senator Chaney, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to address the causes of the serious decline in Australian living standards.

I draw attention to the fact that not one senior Minister, not one economic Minister in this Government-not Senator Button, not Senator Walsh, not Senator Evans-has been prepared to join in the debate today. This is a clear indication of the way in which this Government has become arrogant and uncaring about the decline in Australian living standards.

This decline cannot be denied. In fact, the last speaker, Senator Crowley, openly admitted the decline. Real disposable income-that is, people's income after they have paid their taxes-actually fell in 1986-87. Over the past five years the Hawke Government has presided over the unprecedented hocking of Australia to the rest of the world. We are now more in debt than at any time since the Great Depression. We are in debt to foreign creditors and financial markets.

The boast of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that he has restored Australia to economic prosperity is a nonsense. Last night's Melbourne Herald reported two examples to demonstrate the nonsense of the Treasurer's boast. A family comprising a husband and a wife, both in full time employment with three teenage children, gave details of their difficulties in meeting their financial obligations on $900 a week combined income-and rightly so as the story revealed. By comparison, the plight of the other family-a single income family on $400 a week with three children-can only be described as desperate.

Five years ago, before this Government came into office, both families would have been living reasonably. They would not have been well-off, and, certainly, the single income family would have had to spend very carefully. But they would not have been desperate. The two-income family probably would have been paying off their own home. Now that option is out of their reach, even on a combined income of $900 a week.

In my State of Victoria, the cost of home ownership has doubled and redoubled in the past five years and has put home ownership out of the reach of thousands of ordinary Australians. The price of a modest home has risen from $40,000 to $80,000 and, within the last two years, has redoubled to as much as $160,000. How on earth can a young couple afford to buy a home at those prices? But, of course, we know that the Australian Labor Party has always had a secret agenda to reduce home ownership in Australia.

Ordinary Australians recognise that there is no value in their money these days. They know that their standard of living continues to decline under this Government. Frequently, young people tell me that they have tried to save for a deposit to buy a house but that it is extremely hard to keep any of the money that they manage to save. They shop at the supermarket and the same amount of money buys less and less with each passing month. They move to cheaper cuts and shop around for specials, and even then they cannot save. Constant and never ending price increases are destroying Australian initiative. People can no longer afford to buy quality clothing. The cost of footwear has increased by 40 to 50 per cent and children now wear runners, rather than shoes. A family with three kids would be lucky to get any change out of $100 from an outing to the movies and a takeaway meal. Few can afford it. The drop in attendances at agricultural shows demonstrates how many children today are being denied this treat as parents are forced to tighten the purse strings.

Federal, State and local government charges increase annually. People tell us that the cost of living has risen by more than 50 per cent in the past five years-that is an average of about 10 per cent per annum. They are not wrong. The figures produced by the `world's greatest Treasurer' would not show such an increase, but ordinary people know that that is the sort of increase that they have to cope with. Meanwhile, what is the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) doing? He is playing golf, gambling and smoking cigars with his wealthy mates. He is fishing from their luxury launches and congratulating them on becoming multimillionaires under his Government.

The comparison between Australia under this Government and the South American countries under their dictatorships is becoming more pronounced. In Australia now, the poor get poorer, the middle income earners get poor, those on fixed pensions are unable to cope and superannuants are taxed to take away their savings. Of course, those with the right connections in the Australian Labor Party have no trouble in becoming richer and richer. As in South America, the gap between the very very rich and the very poor is becoming very, very wide. Of course, the mates get all the perks. Neville Wran gets the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Brian Burke gets Ireland so that he can research his family history. Chris Hurford retires to the United States of America. Mick Young takes his superannuation before the May mini-Budget cuts superannuation to ribbons. But he is not satisfied with his superannuation plus an income from Qantas Airways Ltd; he gets the Prime Minister to act as his employment agent. Cronyism and rorts have been elevated to an art form by the Australian Labor Party in office. Apart from the many publicly known jobs for the boys, there are some 27 former Labor Party apparatchiks who are now members of this Parliament.

Meanwhile, our national debt continues to rise. At the end of December 1987 our gross foreign debt was almost $112 billion or around $7,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia. Our net foreign debt is almost $87 billion, representing an almost four-fold increase since June 1983. As a result, 20 per cent of our export income is required just to meet interest payments on the net debt, while two-thirds of our export income is required to meet principal repayments plus interest. yet Mr Keating continues to promote himself as `Australia's greatest Treasurer'. A chief executive officer of a public company who incurred such a debt would get the sack and, given the chance, the voters will do the same to this Treasurer.

Inflation in Australia has been running at more than double the rate of our major trading partners. By the end of 1987 the consumer price index in Australia was at an annual rate of 7.1 per cent, compared with 4.5 per cent in the United States, 0.4 per cent in Japan and one per cent in West Germany. In the five years since the Hawke Government came to office the excise tax on petrol has more than trebled, rising from 6c to 20c per litre, even though during the same period world oil prices have fallen from around $US34 a barrel to $US16 a barrel. In other words, while world oil prices have halved, Australians are paying almost 30 per cent more for petrol. The number of new car registrations has fallen from 452,000 in 1984 to 358,726 in 1987. This is not surprising when one considers that the price of a car such as the Laser has increased by 63 per cent, the Commodore SL by 57.5 per cent and the Falcon GL by 43 per cent. In the same five years of this Government's office a case of beer and a bottle of scotch have each increased by about 50 per cent. That is an average rate of about 10 per cent a year and that is the sort of increase that people have come to expect under this Government, regardless of the official figures.

Meanwhile, this Government has implemented draconian taxation measures which particularly affect the pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayer. Under the guise that `taxing benefits all Australians'-what rubbish-taxpayers are being ripped off by bracket creep. Average weekly wages exceed $500-that is, about $25,000 a year-and the maximum rate of income tax cuts in at $20,000, substantially below the average weekly earning rate of Australian employees. Further, what the taxpayers do not lose in income tax they have ripped off them in sales tax, excise or tariffs. Tax per week for PAYE wage earners has risen between 40 and 60 per cent and tax paid after Medicare levy and rebates as a share of gross income for a taxpayer on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and two children increased from 18.8 per cent in September 1985 to 20.2 per cent in September 1987. After the final instalment of the Hawke Government's income tax cuts in July 1987, tax bracket creep meant that a single income family was paying $15 a week more than when Labor came into office.

Real disposable income fell by 1.2 per cent in 1986-87, the first time in 30 years that this important measure of family welfare had gone backwards. Young families have had to scrimp and save, make all sorts of economies and even go into debt in order to survive. So-called wage increases have not kept up with rising prices, higher income tax and rising costs of government services such as telephones, water and rates. About 80 per cent of young families frequently have trouble meeting family bills and expenses and Australia now has one of the world's worst levels of personal and consumer debt, with record numbers of people being forced into bankruptcy and a 20 per cent increase this year.

Today there is a new poor-the young Australian with a family and total family income of less than $25,000 per year. Such people face the crisis of frequently finding that there is no money for clothes, medical care or even food. The number of homeless has increased from 10,000 in the 1970s to 40,000 today. Under Labor, Australia is now a less fair and more unequal society than it was five years ago.

More than 140,000 young Australians are unemployed. But the real problem for the unemployed is the term of their sentence under this Government. Also, 25,000 young Australians are locked out of tertiary institutions and 100,000 low income Australians are condemned to hospital waiting queues because of Medicare. After five years of Labor, an additional 700,000 Australians have fallen below the Henderson poverty line and single income families with two children have suffered a $42 a week decline in their standard of living.

It is clear that the Government has failed to address the real needs of Australia and has failed to do what needed to be done when it came into office-that is, to cut government expenditure. It has squeezed Australian taxpayers to increase the revenue of this country in order to meet additional expenses. Even now, after last Saturday's electoral debacle, Government Ministers and members of the Australian Labor Party are still talking about spending their way out of their electoral troubles. But spending more and more money means raising higher taxes. It means more inflation and a further decline in Australian living standards. The sooner this Government realises the problems it has created for ordinary Australians, starts to cut its expenditure, tries to reduce taxes for the ordinary people and tries to reduce the government add-on costs which arise around this nation, the better this country will be and the sooner our living standards will rise.

DEBATE.TITLE: A SAY, A CHOICE, A FAIR GO

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I welcome the National Agenda for Women report entitled A Say, A Choice, A Fair Go. I must point out that any Australian woman who accepted an invitation-as I did-to the launch of this report, which turned out to be a shopping centre extravaganza and a campaign stunt for the New South Wales election, would have been excused for thinking that this was an extraordinarily important document. I certainly believe that it is. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and a series of speakers at the launch said it was important, and yet here we are being presented with this report in the normal line of government reports with a five-minute period in which to speak on it. Compare this with significant ministerial statements which we often get in this place and other exercises on defence, foreign affairs and even parliamentary privilege, which can take up hours and hours of the Parliament's time. However, I suppose that I should be grateful-and so should all Australian women-that this report at least appears at the top of the list today and that this is a broadcast day. I suppose, as usual, women have to be grateful for small mercies. This is a book of promises, even a book of platitudes; but I am afraid that I must draw attention to some of the issues in it which really need to be questioned.

One welcomes the promises and looks forward to their being carried out, but I feel that we have to ask some questions. Child care is an issue which is obviously addressed in a report on a national agenda for women. I ask: What about child care? The lack of substantial support, in spite of the figures which have been put forward in the earlier debate and no doubt will be put forward in other contributions on this report, is evidenced by the fact that we still do not have our 20,000 new child care places. I ask when the Government will address the demands of day care providers, who are increasing in number since child day care positions have been increased under the Government's policy. When will these providers be given acceptable remuneration? When will we reach a stage when fees for child care can very often cost people the same amount as some fairly exclusive private secondary schools?

Questions of women in the paid work force are addressed. There is still, however, enormous discrimination in the paid work force. I have to ask: When will the Government eliminate the express discrimination against women which still exists in some 550 Federal awards? When will the Government remove all the remaining exemptions to the Sex Discrimination Act which are not clearly justified on occupational safety grounds? When will the Government implement the promise of the Prime Minister to bring the sex discrimination provisions within the brief of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission? When will it evaluate any discriminatory impact of wage productivity decisions?

Issues of poverty need to be addressed. Women and their children still constitute the majority of Australians living in poverty. Women are still significantly worse off financially after divorce than men. Women in Australia still earn only some two-thirds of what men earn. Women are still discouraged, implicitly and explicitly, from education that will facilitate their financial security. The Government, in making a list of promises such as this one, has to be reminded that it is women who have suffered most in, and have been excluded from, education because of the implementation of the so-called higher education administration charge. That is an ongoing problem.

We have to deplore, after all the Government's promises, the fact that the Prime Minister says in his foreword that the Government will be watching the progress of Australian women closely, but then at the end of the document the Government excuses itself from providing any resources to address the many issues that it raises in this report. Perhaps a note of warning should be sounded here. Women very often have to say, `Well, this little bit will have to do us'. But women will not always put up with that, and we may reach the stage where more and more Australian women come to agree with Eva Cox, who pointed out in the Age of the 11th of this month that she is not sure whether we can actually afford men in this society, that men comprise 90 per cent of those in prison, 70 per cent of alcoholics, the bulk of drivers involved in serious accidents, et cetera. She went on to suggest that a program of equitably calculated knackering might change the behaviour habits of men and that this might make them less costly. Her remarks are accompanied by a cartoon in which a woman says to her child, `I'm sorry about daddy, but he was a cost the economy just couldn't afford.'. She concludes her remarks by saying:
If the boys keep running things their way, feminists might one day take over and decide on some more drastic cuts.
Since most of the decision-makers in government are men, I suggest that they read Eva Cox's article. It might provide some incentive towards action, not talk, when it comes to women's issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) will recall that on 17 March this year I asked him whether the Government had established an interdepartmental committee (IDC)-either formally or informally-or some sort of working group, to look in detail at matters of environmental legislation with a view to getting a greater input from departments, for example, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. I asked what the precise nature of any such interdepartmental committee or working party was and what it was specifically undertaking at present. The Minister responded by saying that, apart from a Caucus discussion, the only IDC which he could recall was an IDC currently looking at land use. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: That may report towards the end of April. It will report to a range of Ministers and I anxiously look forward to seeing it.

I then asked for details of that inquiry into land use and the Minister undertook to give them to me. I thank the Minister for the information relating to the interdepartmental committee on land use and also the additional information, of which he was not aware at the time. He has since informed me that there was a second IDC on forestry in addition to the one on land use. I thank him for the information he supplied regarding the IDC on land use. However, I am concerned that he reneged on one aspect. He indicated that he would be quite happy to give me precise details and I then asked why there was some secrecy about the IDC's terms of reference. The Minister will recall that the Opposition put forward an amendment. Given the fact that the Government had those IDCs on environmental matters relating to land use, forestry, conservation and the impact that other departments could have or should have on those matters, we thought it desirable-seeing that one of those committees was due to report by the end of April-to defer the legislation until it had reported. That seemed quite a reasonable response, but unfortunately the Minister has some concern about the need to get this legislation on the statute books with some undue haste.

It would appear that the Government acknowledges that this is an imperfect piece of legislation and that a number of inquiries are running on the issue. Therefore, I ask the Minister: Is the advisory committee to examine the economic cost of all the National Estate and World Heritage proposals, which was foreshadowed by Mr Kerin on 22 March, one and the same as the interdepartmental committee on land use? I ask the Minister to address his mind to that issue. I think that there is some confusion in the public mind about this host of committees. It would appear that potentially there could be at least three committees. Perhaps the Minister can advise me whether the committee which was foreshadowed by Mr Kerin on 22 March is one and the same as the interdepartmental committee on land use to which he referred in answer to my question. If that is not the case, I ask the Minister: What is the link between the interdepartmental committees on land use and forestry and the proposed advisory body? Further, when were the interdepartmental committees on land use and forestry established? Were they established at the same time? To whom will they report?

In light of the fact that we have a knowledge of the existence of those two interdepartmental committees and that the Opposition lost very narrowly the vote to amend the conservation legislation earlier today, I ask: Does the Minister feel obliged to recommit the Bill to a vote in this chamber in light of the new information that has come to his and to my notice? When are the interdepartmental committees on forestry and land use expected to report? Does he have some more precise information on that, because I think that we are entitled to have it? Will the Government give consideration to deferring the Bill until both reports have been brought down?

I think that our earlier amendment related to the interdepartmental committee on land use, but the Minister will acknowledge that there are a number of other committees. This shows that the Government has some real concern about the impact of environmental legislation. For example, the Minister has acknowledged that the interdepartmental committee on land use involves departments such as the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, Treasury, Prime Minister and Cabinet, Aboriginal Affairs and his own Department. The Minister has not told me the terms of reference because of so-called secrecy provisions. I regret that. I wonder why there are secrecy provisions. The Minister was limited to telling me that all that will be looked at are the decision-making processes relating to land use. There seems to be a bit of duplication. For instance, the forestry IDC involves the departments of the Prime Minister and Cabinet; Industry, Technology and Commerce; Primary Industries and Energy; and the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. That committee will look at forest resource management and proposals put forward by the Forestry and Forest Products Industry Council and the Australian Conservation Council.

In fact, in view of all these committees and all these concerns, can the Minister tell us whether he will provide some amendments in the near future, pending the outcomes of all the IDCs? I repeat: If the Minister is so concerned about all the IDCs, will he give us an assurance that pending the outcome of the reports of the IDCs there will be amendments to this legislation in the near future? Obviously, the Minister would not be intending to set up all these bodies and inquiries if there were no concern about the legislation. If there is concern about the legislation, why does the Minister not defer it or at least give the Senate some assurance that he will bring forward certain amendments based on the sorts of recommendations that such bodies are likely to make? All these bodies are involved in reviewing the policies and decision-making processes which are now applied to a range of Commonwealth decisions which affect land use and conservation generally in Australia. Further, since one aim of the reviews is to improve existing arrangements and to develop new principles and criteria to apply to Commonwealth land use decisions, I think that my requests have a great deal of validity.

Finally, does the Minister-I hope he is noting these questions-consider that the existing practices and legislation are deficient? If he considers that they are not, why has it been necessary to set up the various committees? Why, therefore, is it necessary to have an IDC that will investigate forestry as well as an IDC looking at land use?

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate, although I am sure Senator Parer does not need reminding, that we are debating clause 1 of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I rise to speak on clause 1 of the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. The genesis of the Bill is the World Heritage listing of the northern rainforest. We all know the history of that, when, following the last election, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), on advice from people who, basically, had no scientific knowledge, recommended that an area of far north Queensland be listed as soon as possible with the World Heritage Commission. As has been so clearly outlined by Senator Puplick, those of us on this side of the chamber have no objection to World Heritage listing of areas--
—Ha!

—That is, provided that it is done in the right way. There are two main criteria for World Heritage listing. Firstly, the area must be capable of being listed. Secondly, it must be capable of being managed. Of course, this means that consultation must be carried out between the State Government and the Federal Government. Senator Richardson will say that there is no necessity that it must be carried out. However, brochures from his own Department clarify the process for nominating Australian properties. Senator Puplick has indicated that in July 1984 at a meeting of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers:

SPEECH.PARA: some guidelines were agreed to apply to new nominations of Australian sites to the World Heritage List which involved full consultation with the State and Territory Governments. These guidelines were reaffirmed at the November 1987 meeting.
They were reaffirmed as recently as 1987.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reaffirmed them. I was there.

—Senator Richardson reaffirmed them but he has not put them into practice. Notwithstanding the telexed invitation to the Prime Minister of this country by the Premier of Queensland, there has been no consultation. I think also that it is worth quoting further from the same document, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: the Government's approach to World Heritage listing is a positive one.The Prime Minister has said that ` . . . we will consider nominations from all States for areas they believe should be given World Heritage status and we would work to have these areas accepted for World Heritage nominations'.

There is the rub. There has been no consultation. Even worse than that, I have not heard any honourable senator on the other side of this chamber or, indeed, any Australian Democrat, say one word about the individuals-Senator Richardson's constituents-whom we stand here and defend. These are ordinary everyday workers. These are individuals, the ordinary Australians. These are the people Senator Richardson calls the `common man'. I indicate that that is an expression I would not use because I would say `the individual, ordinary Australian'. I would not say the `common man'. These are the people Senator Richardson says the Australian Labor Party has neglected and who deserted the Labor Party in droves at the last election.

I would like also to raise one other point to which I would like Senator Richardson to respond. The other aspect of World Heritage listing is the ability to manage the area. It must be capable of being managed. In the nomination for World Heritage listing to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation-signed by Senator Richardson himself-there was a clear imputation to people overseas in three parts of that nomination that somehow there was agreement between the State and Federal governments. The application for nomination asks who will be responsible for management of the nominated area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who manages the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park?

—I am glad that Senator Sanders has mentioned the Great Barrier Reef because that nomination was done in the proper way. It was done cooperatively by the Queensland and Federal governments. I recognise that there were negotiations between a Federal Liberal government and the State Government of Queensland. If my memory is correct, there was a letter signed by someone from the Federal Government and the Premier of Queensland at that time. That was a proper management situation. The answer to the question of who is going to manage the area is that it is envisaged that the management will be carried out in cooperation between the State and Federal governments. Everyone knows that that is false. I believe that Senator Richardson has misled an international organisation. Members of the World Heritage Commission have expressed to me their embarrassment at this nomination. I am told that the chances are about 70:30 that they will come back to the Minister in November and, at that stage, not accept the nomination.
—What will happen to the logging while that occurs?

—The Government does not care about that. There is a 70:30 chance that they will come back to the Minister in November and say that they will not accept the nomination at that stage. Therefore, the imputation is that this nomination will not happen until the Minister gets together with the Queensland Government and makes some decent arrangement.
—They couldn't give a darn.

—The World Heritage Commission knows that without the agreement of the State and Federal governments the area cannot be managed. The Federal Government does not own it. That is one of the major points. I believe that Senator Richardson, by signing that nomination and misleading an international organisation-it is bad enough misleading this Parliament-has embarrassed everyone in this country and that is good reason why he should step down.

SPEECH.PARA: I will refer to further parts of the Bill as we proceed in the Committee debate. However, in conclusion, I would just like to repeat that the genesis of the legislation for the World Heritage listing is to prevent the State Government from taking legal action through the courts, to prevent the normal sorts of legal processes to which we in this country have become used and which we expect. I ask also: if the Minister is so sure of his scientific knowledge-I understand the challenge through the courts was to be based on scientific knowledge-why is he bringing in a piece of legislation that prevents the Queensland Government from pursuing a legal action-an action which should be available to every Queenslander and every Australian?

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Boswell. I am sure that the honourable senator will be able to tie in his remarks to clause 1.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I certainly will confine my remarks to the title of this Bill-the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. SPEECH.PARA: I tried to ask a question during Question Time in the Senate today. Senator Evans pulled Standing Orders on me, but that does not prevent me from asking that question now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Boswell, it does and you must not reflect on a vote of the Senate.

I suggest that they had heeded the call of the luminaries of the Australian Labor Party to distance themselves from the greenie and conservation vote. They were told to avoid it like the plague. That is why they did not want to have their names recorded in the Hansard of this Parliament. They did not want to have their mates say, `Why did you try to take my job? There it is in black and white-that is your name'.

I have been forced to apply for access under the freedom of information legislation in order to know what the scientists and economists say about this World Heritage listing. I have not been able to obtain any scientific or environmental impact evidence because the Government is not prepared to lay it on the table.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh admitted that he did not have a clue what compensation would be paid. That is an admission from one of the senior Ministers of this Government. So there is no idea of what compensation will be paid. There is no idea of what scientific evidence the World Heritage listing legislation is based on. There is no environmental impact study. There is no provision for the 2,000 to 3,000 people who are going to be thrown out of their jobs. We are flying in the dark. The Senate has had before it one misrepresentation after another.

I am very concerned about the standing of Australia in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO). The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) says-and I presume that this is in regard to the nomination of the wet tropics rainforest, north-east Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you concerned about our standing with UNESCO? You do not even agree with the whole organisation.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, Senator Sanders has screamed into my microphone for the six months that this debate has been continuing. I ask you to ask him to desist.
—Senator Sanders, I would appreciate it if you could do that because I am trying to determine whether what the honourable senator is saying has relevance to clause 1.

—I want to refer to what the Minister said in a submission by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, on behalf of the Government of Australia, to UNESCO. Senator Richardson -I take it that this is his signature and it is no forgery-says:

SPEECH.PARA: A joint authority of the Australian and Queensland Governments is envisaged to assume responsibility for the administration of this property.
That is signed by Senator Richardson. He misleads not only the Senate but also UNESCO on three occasions in this nomination. On page 16 of the nomination he says:
The envisaged joint authority of the Australian and Queensland Government will also be responsible regarding the preservation and conservation of the World Heritage area.
On page 17, Senator Richardson says:
There are Statements of Purpose and Management Guidelines for the National Parks managed by the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service.

Senator Richardson has told the Senate on a number of occasions that he cannot, has not and never has had any talks with the Queensland Government. Therefore, how can he get an agreement? How can he put that before UNESCO and say that these arrangements will be jointly managed? I say that is a blatant piece of misrepresentation. I would call it something else if I did not have respect, not for Senator Richardson but for you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I will not use the word that I should use and which people would understand. Senator Richardson has made three blatant misrepresentations under his signature-Graham Frederick Richardson, Minister of State for the Environment and the Arts.

Senator Richardson has not only misrepresented this Parliament but he has also embarrassed Australia by misrepresenting us to an overseas organisation. I suggest that that is definitely not good enough. It is not good enough for the Senate and it is not good enough for our international standing when a senior Minister of this Government places the Australian people in such a position.

This Bill also takes away the right of the High Court of Australia by investing its powers in the World Heritage Committee. I suggest that that is a sellout not only of the Queensland State Government and the Senate but also of the courts of Australia. It is an admission that our law courts do not have the expertise to deal with these matters. Senator Richardson sits in this chamber and will not defend this action. I can see that all of the backbenchers behind him, who should be giving him support, are diving for cover. They are not going to be involved in this stupid piece of legislation that is going to rob their mates of their jobs and destroy towns. They would not touch it with a barge pole. Senator Richardson has been left to carry the can for this piece of legislation. If he takes my advice-and I have been around the political game a while too-I would back out of this so fast that he would not see which way I went. It is like the charge of the Light Brigade-death behind us, death beside us and death in front of us. The Minister is going to get shot right out of the saddle as he did last Saturday in the biggest political rout since the charge of the Light Brigade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. I would ask you to examine the relevance of what the honourable senator is saying to clause 1 of the Bill.

—I was waiting for a break to indicate to Senator Boswell that whilst what he is saying is quite entertaining, I do not think it has much to do with the question before the Chair at the moment, which is that clause 1 stand as printed. The honourable senator might try to tie his remarks into the question before the Chair.

—Clause 1 is the short title and says that the Act may be cited as the Conservation Legislation Amendment Act 1988 and I thought that that gave me a fairly wide scope to debate the intent of the Bill. Obviously when we come to debate the following clauses, I will take cognisance of your remarks, Mr Temporary Chairman, and restrict my comments to each individual clause. However, I suggest, with due deference to you, that on clause 1 I have scope to canvass the Bill in a wide-ranging way.

SPEECH.PARA: This piece of legislation circumvents the proper trial of live issues before the High Court of Australia and it removes the right of the Queensland Government to defend its position in the High Court. This is tantamount to changing the goal posts after the game has started. That is dirty pool in any way that one cares to look at it. The Queensland Government wanted to present a case to the High Court and, while it was preparing that, the Government went and changed the rules. I suppose that that is the way in which the Australian Labor Party fights. You have always been recognised as a gutter and goanna tactician, but you will meet your Waterloo.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Boswell, you are addressing the Chair. I hope that those remarks were not directed to the Chair.

—I certainly would not direct those remarks to you, Mr Temporary Chairman. They were directed through you to Senator Richardson. I used those words because they are terms used quite widely in country areas of Australia. I certainly do not mean any offence to the Chair.
—Senator Richardson has probably never been there.

—He probably has never been there. He went up into the country area of Queensland once but he got such a fright that I do not think he will be prepared to go there again. He displayed some wimpish tendencies there-he cried and so forth. I want to talk about some of Senator Richardson's misrepresentations in the second reading debate. He said that the Queensland Government had said that it would not consult with him. I have already tabled a telex from the Premier of Queensland, Mr Ahern, which was sent some time in December asking Senator Richardson to consult with him. Yet Senator Richardson says that he has never had an invitation to consult with the Queensland Government.
—Did he say that?
—He has said that on numerous occasions to the Senate, yet here is the telex in black and white. Senator Richardson never cares to admit such things.

SPEECH.PARA: Again today Senator Richardson said that the timber industry was on its knees and that it was only a matter of time before the whole industry closed down. I have made this point to the Senate on numerous occasions but I will make it again for Senator Richardson's benefit because there are none so deaf as those who do not want to hear. Senator Richardson should know that the Queensland Government reduced the timber harvest from 195,000 cubic metres a year to 60,000 cubic metres of its own volition in order to sustain an industry that would be able to keep 3,000 people employed and produce $33m a year. That is called sustainable logging. Obviously Senator Richardson does not understand it, or he does not want to understand it. I have mentioned this time and time again in this Parliament and Senator Richardson will not acknowledge that the Queensland Government, through its Forestry Department, has cut down the intake of logs--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. I call Senator Durack. The question before the Chair is that clause 1 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am well aware of that, Mr Temporary Chairman. I was just going to observe that point at the beginning of my speech. We are debating the short title of the Bill, which is that this Act may be cited as the Conservation Legislation Amendment Act 1988. In my speech at the second reading stage I observed that the title is a complete misnomer; the legislation ought to be called the Preservation Legislation Amendment Act 1988. I am very disturbed by the fact that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and the Government do not seem to understand that there is a vital difference between conservation and preservation. Conservation is the pursuance of a policy which involves the intelligent and sensitive use of resources in such a way that they are conserved over a period, but it does not exclude economic activities in relation to an area; whereas preservation is the maintenance of an area of land in its pristine and natural state. Of course, that would involve the prohibition of most, if not all, economic activities and, indeed, social activities and tourism.

SPEECH.PARA: This is exactly what the Government intends this Bill should do-preserve this vast area, 850,000 hectares, of north Queensland in its present state. The sharp point of this legislation is that it will ban logging. The legislation itself does not actually do that. One of the reasons that I speak of the short title-as you, Mr Temporary Chairman, are so concerned about relevance-is that this Bill does not in itself prevent logging, but it is clear that its intention is to give the Government powers to prevent logging. The Minister has already issued regulations under the existing Act to do just that. The intention is-he made this perfectly clear in his second reading speech and on numerous other occasions-that he will use the additional powers that he believes this Bill will give to him to issue new regulations to prevent logging.

There is no doubt whatsoever that it is the Government's policy to shut down completely the sawmilling industry in this area of north Queensland; to destroy the jobs of nearly 1,100 timber workers and people involved in the logging industry in north Queensland; and to destroy at least another 1,000 jobs or more as an indirect consequence of this legislation. This piece of legislation is quite improperly termed `conservation legislation'; it should be termed `preservation legislation'. That is one of the matters we should be concerned about because the Government's whole policy in relation not only to this area but also to environmental policy is not one of sensible conservation of resources, but of the prevention of economic activity. Indeed, that has been shown by its attitude to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, which was passed to prevent any economic activities, specifically the construction of a dam in the south-west of Tasmania. The Government's policy in relation to the whole Kakadu area in the Northern Territory-20,000 square kilometres; an area greater than Wales-has been to shut it down, apart from a small proportion, not only to any economic activity but also to any attempt to find out what the economic wealth of that area is.

The same policy is now being pursued by this Government in relation to something like 9,000 square kilometres of north Queensland. It is clearly a policy which this Government intends-or it did until last Saturday-to continue to pursue. There is apparently no end to the voracious demands of the extreme environmentalists. So far there has been no sign that this Government will say to them, `Enough is enough'.

Maybe as a result of the reaction of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, to the electoral disaster for the New South Wales right wing-Senator Richardson's colleagues in the former New South Wales Government-this policy will be arrested. I hope that it will be, in the interests of Australia.

This policy, in the way the Government has been pursuing it so far, is in no sense a conservation policy but a policy of locking up vast areas of Australia to any economic activity whatever, without knowing the economic wealth of those areas. I have already instanced Kakadu. The areas in stages 2 and 3 of Kakadu that have been locked away by this Government have not been fully explored in any shape or form. The areas of south-west Tasmania which have been locked away by the World Heritage listing have never been explored for their economic wealth, nor has any estimate been made of it, and a large part of this area of north Queensland is now being locked away from the traditional industry, which has been logging and sawmilling. The ridiculous aspect of that decision of this Government is the fact that logging has gone on in this area for 100 years. The values of the very areas that the Government wants to list as being in conformity with World Heritage values have been the subject of this economic activity for 100 years. Why should that now be stopped by this Government if this is a genuine piece of conservation legislation?

This legislation is clearly not designed simply to preserve this area because it has been conserved by sensible economic activity. This Government's real aim here is to pander to the greenie vote and to stop any logging whatsoever. That is what this is all about. The World Heritage listing is simply the means by which this Government wants to shut down an activity of great significance to Australia and enormous significance to the constituents of Senator Boswell and Senator Parer, 2,000 of whom will lose their jobs as a result. It is of great significance to all the small business people throughout this area-70,000 people who will have their businesses in many cases destroyed and at least seriously affected by the Government's decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Western Australia will be next.

—The south-western forests of Western Australia will definitely be on the hit list, as will other vast areas of Australia. This simply cannot happen. The Government should be pursuing the proper conservation policies, not these preservation policies, this total capitulation to the greenie vote and the likes of Senator Sanders who has been shouting throughout this debate. Of course, the Australia Democrats are in league with the extreme environmentalists, as are Senator Richardson and the Government. This simply cannot go on. The situation is that vast areas of Australia will simply be ruled out from any economic activity. Already 23 per cent of Australia is being ruled out from economic activity and on the greenie agenda another 20 per cent will be ruled out.
—That's just nonsense.

—Not only will this legislation rule out any economic activity; Senator Richardson is making these decisions-he cannot deny this-without knowing the economic value of the area concerned. He has made these decisions on doctrinaire grounds. He did not know what the economic cost of these decisions would be when he made them. He made them on the eve of the last election. He had not seen any socio-economic reports in relation to this area. Maybe he now has these reports.
—He has got them but he won't tell anybody.

—I am told that he has them, but he will not tell anybody what they contain because he does not want the world to know what the cost of this legislation will be. It is disgraceful and totally irresponsible for any government, to present legislation to this Parliament without letting us know what the economic costs will be. We know what the social costs will be, but there will be economic costs as well. Senator Richardson has those documents but he will not make them available to this Parliament for the purposes of this debate. Fortunately, we have a report from Professor Percy Harris of the James Cook University, who has revealed the economic costs. But that was not Senator Richardson's doing. He wanted to stop this Parliament knowing what the economic consequences of this legislation will be.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to my point that this legislation is quite wrongly named conservation legislation. It is preservation legislation. It is designed for the prevention of economic activity in a vast region and the prevention of the maintenance of social and community life in a major area of Australia-an area of great and growing importance to this country. The Government is stifling economic and social activities in this area. As I have said, it has revealed its policies in Tasmania and the Northern Territory and presumably it will continue to pursue a policy which it calls a conservation policy but which is no such thing. As I said, it excludes large tracts of Australia from any possible economic development or even an inquiry into the economic value of the areas concerned.

The High Court of Australia in the Lemonthyme case last week, as I pointed out in the second reading debate, made it quite clear that World Heritage listing is consistent with the balancing of economic activity and conservation of the environment. But these decisions are decisions of the Government and the Parliament of Australia. The Government is using the World Heritage listing quite wrongly to try to justify its determination to stop important economic activities in Australia because it simply wants to pander to the extreme environmental lobby. World Heritage listing, as the High Court has shown in its judgments in the Lemonthyme case, is not inconsistent with reasonable economic activity. The Government, by what it is doing in this legislation, is denying very reasonable and necessary requirements for the future good health of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: A spokesman for the Geneva-based International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), an independent network of government and non-government organisations, said the North Queensland and Tasmanian wilderness areas were `clearly of world heritage calibre'.
