I point out that leading up to the nomination of the Great Barrier Reef there was considerable opposition from the Queensland Government. There was strong pressure for oil exploration on the Great Barrier Reef and for mining for limestone on the Great Barrier Reef because these were seen as economic activities. In that case, the conservationists won the day and convinced the Queensland Government that it should cooperate. Now we see a healthy World Heritage area that is also of great economic benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is fishing on it and other activities.

—Many tourist activities will continue in the wet tropical rainforests that will return an economic gain in that area. It has been asserted also that the cycle of cutting of this forest is a once every 40 years cycle and that because some areas have been logged-on that cycle presumably-and because they are now included in the World Heritage area, therefore logging is consistent with World Heritage. That simply does not follow.

—Order! Senator Coulter, I wonder whether you could make your remarks pertinent to the question before the Chair, which is that clause 1 stand as printed. If you were listening to the previous speaker, he did it very well. I do not think that you are tying your remarks in with the clause!
—With respect, Mr Temporary Chairman, every point I have made has been in answer to points other speakers have made in this debate, which have been allowed.
—That is a point, but if you could try to tie your remarks in. I think I am fighting a losing battle, but can you try to tie them in with clause 1.

—By way of conclusion then, I would like to pick up a point made by several speakers for the Opposition and particularly Senator Walters who said that we need a strong economy. It was said by the previous speaker that there was some conflict between preservation, conservation and economic development. The Bill is about conservation. It is called the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill. I ask Senator Walters whether she has a bank account. I suppose she does have a bank account. Does she consider she can develop that bank account by taking money out of it? That is precisely what she is asserting she is doing by chopping down trees in the rainforest. Senator Walters also said that 40 per cent of our earnings come from mining. Let us stick with mining. Mining is a non-renewable activity. One can only take something out of the ground once. When one takes material out of the ground, one is shifting wealth from one place to another. One is depleting the wealth in one part of an account and adding it to the other side of the ledger. If we had a sensible system of national accounting which looked at the resources-which it does at the moment-but which, in addition, kept account of the stock, I would not find too much objection to the sorts of economic arguments that were developed, perhaps best by Senator Puplick. But, at the moment the economic balance sheets we keep do not reflect the diminution in the stock of our non-renewable resources or in the diminution of those resources that are potentially renewable but which have been overexploited in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly want to refer to the misrepresentation that has gone on that is relevant to clause 1. In my speech in the second reading debate I drew the attention of the Senate to the misrepresentation the Minister made in his nomination to the World Heritage listing body, and I will not go over that ground again. I just want to put on the record the further misrepresentations that have gone on. The whole concept of conservation of the northern tropical rain forests has been predicated on the idea coming from the Government that only by total isolation of the area can forests be preserved and, furthermore, that is the only policy of which the body that administers the World Heritage legislation-namely the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN)-approves. Nothing could be further from the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in my speech, the IUCN is a mature, scientific body that has been perverted a bit by some extremists from Australia joining it to politicise it for their own ends. To come up to date, the IUCN General Assembly had a meeting in Costa Rica from 1 to 10 February 1988. I wish to refer to only two of a number of resolutions produced at that meeting. They give the lie to the assertion of the Minister that the only policy that IUCN approves is total isolation of the rainforests. Recommendation 17/69 on the tropical forestry action plan reads:

Welcoming the initiative of FAO, UNDF the World Bank and World Resources Institute in developing the Tropical Forestry Action Plan and noting the support of the international development assistance community for its implementation;
Welcoming especially the importance that the TFAP attributes to the broad environmental role of forests as a basis for sustainable economic and social development . . .
I ask the Minister to note the words `sustainable economic and social development'. In other words, it recognised that forests can be managed and harvested. The next paragraph reads:

Recognising that the implementation of TFAP would result in investments in establishing and managing protected areas and in the better sustained yield management of natural forests and would thus favour the maintenance of very extensive areas of tropical forests.
That meeting was saying that one will preserve the forests and also improve large tracts if there is an intelligent management plan. The next paragraph of the resolution reads:

Recognising further that several of the TFAP components can contribute effectively to the reduction of human pressure on forest lands, to the halting of deforestation and to the restoration of degraded forests:
Noting however that TFAP targets for investments in forest ecosystem conservation have not yet been met . . .

It then goes through its recommendations. The resolution from the General Assembly of the IUCN this year in Costa Rica clearly supports the management of forests on a sustainable yield basis. In simple language, it recognises that forests not only are maintained but improved by intelligent harvesting plans-plans that are demonstrated to be well within the capability of the Australian forestry industry. The next recommendation, 17/70, of that General Assembly meeting in Costa Rica of the IUCN, a body which will vet the application for Australia, follows a similar line. It begins:
Considering that a sustainable international trade in forest products may provide a sound basis for investment in maintaining tropical forest resources;

Recognising that, after adequate provision has been made for the establishment of protected areas, other areas of tropical forest, specially selected for the purpose, may justifiably be allocated for the sustainable production of timber and other high value products, provided that such management has been shown to be possible in these areas;
Recognising also that this sustainable production may well serve the interests of conservation . . .
Again I ask the Minister to note those words, if he can understand what they mean. I shall explain them to him:
Recognising also that this sustainable production may well serve the interests of conservation.

In other words, here we have the ultimate scientific body saying that one can log forests if one knows what one is doing-and if one logs them to an intelligent management plan, one will improve them and preserve them for humanity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in support of my colleagues Senator MacGibbon and Senator Durack. In doing so I wish to address the short title of the Bill and refer to the fact that the Bill is inappropriately named and titled. I remind the Minister of the appropriate definition of `conservation', and that is appropriate use of a natural resource or the sustainable use of natural resources. Both definitions imply the use of a natural resource, apart from the preservation angle. I ask the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) whether the World Heritage Commission or an associated instrumentality has issued a request or reminder that the Australian Government should not expect the World Heritage Commission or its agencies to solve environmental conservation problems that are more appropriate for resolution by the Australian Government here in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on clause 1 and to refer to statements made earlier by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson). He referred to the way in which the trees in the area concerned had been cut away and that there was not very much of the forest being left. I believe that the forest up there has been very well managed by the Forestry Department in Queensland. I speak as one of Queensland's senators and I am very interested in this topic, having been to this area to see it for myself. Statements made by some of the folk up there tell us how Ravenshoe and some of the other towns in the area will become ghost towns. I believe that the forests in north Queensland have been very well managed. They have been cut regularly on a systematic basis for 100 years. In my opinion, there would not be anything to list in World Heritage if the forests had not been properly managed.

SPEECH.PARA: I also draw the Committee's attention to the fact that only 10 trees per hectare are taken every 40 years. That seems to me to be management of the forests in a well organised way. The Minister said that tourists want to go to the area to see the forests. I would point out that tourists have been going to the area for many years. I recall visits there a long time ago when I saw for myself the beautiful rainforests. Nobody in their right mind would want to destroy that beauty.

Another angle is the fact that there is talk about raping our forests. It seems to be all right to put bulldozers through forests in the Third World but not very satisfactory to put bulldozers through ours. These are some of the points that we want to think about. We must realise that the families of the people who live in the area are very concerned indeed. The Australian Labor Party claims to be interested in people, but Labor Members should think about the people who are losing their jobs. These are important points that must be borne in mind in this Committee consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to an extraordinary number of speakers on clause 1, which seeks only to name the Bill, I shall attempt to answer some of the points that have been made. The first point to make is the obvious one that there has been no attempt to stretch Commonwealth constitutional powers in this Bill. All the Bill does is to state clearly what the High Court has already endorsed in terms of Commonwealth constitutional powers in the Tasmanian dams case and, more recently, in the Lemonthyme case. The fact that we would take action to do just that should surprise no one.

SPEECH.PARA: Where people are missing the point in this debate comes back to what Senator Puplick said about the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM) agreement. Senator Puplick attempted to give the impression that in some way the Commonwealth allowed for his solution, that spineless solution I spoke of today, which would give States a veto. All the CONCOM agreement ever did was to call for full consultation. Full consultation can mean many things. I would have considered that three years of consultation with the Queensland Government adds up to a reasonable definition of the word `full'. Surely three years of trying with the Queensland Government to have a realistic discussion about what can happen with tropical rainforest management is just about long enough. After that three years the Commonwealth chose to act. So it is true that in November 1987 CONCOM reaffirmed the agreement. I was there and I was more than happy to reaffirm it. However, we would not agree to Queensland's wish to allow for State veto which Senator Puplick and the Opposition are again agreeing to tonight. We would not agree with it then and we will not agree with it in the future because, naturally enough, the Commonwealth has been given important constitutional responsibilities over external powers. That power over external affairs is one that this Government intends to live up to. What is in this Bill does not one skerrick more than live up to the responsibilities that the Commonwealth already has. We will not walk away from our responsibilities. We will never walk away from them and, in this case, we are choosing to go on.

Senator Puplick quoted from many things today and this was made much of by Senator Walters who talked of a dirty tricks campaign. She has been in a dirty tricks campaign of her own. If she looks at what I said on the AM program she will see that I said, `The way it is being portrayed suggests that we have lost touch with the common people'. I wonder why neither Senator Walters nor Senator Puplick could remember those words. I suspect that they did remember them but they chose not to say so.

Let me deal with a couple of other points that were made. Firstly, we had Senator Watson speaking about interdepartmental committees (IDCs). Senator Watson is, to say the least, a little confused about IDCs. What Mr Kerin is reported as saying in the newspapers and at yesterday's Press conference I think was a reference to an idea that he has, something that he would like to see done. I am more than happy with that. I have no objections to Mr Kerin or any other Minister having ideas about what should be done. However, I cannot point to a government decision that has yet given vent to it. The IDC on land use, which has been spoken of, is not specifically about World Heritage listing and it never was. It is a review of the process of Commonwealth actions that could affect land use. It looks at principles and criteria and that is a reasonable way of going about it. I referred to it when I was answering a question asked by Senator Watson the other day because as far as I could gather from what he was on about that came closest to the matter about which he was worried.

The IDC on forestry has nothing to do with World Heritage listing. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his policy speech last June before the election, stated very clearly that we would be much better off trying to get some sort of national strategy to deal with these forestry problems rather than deal with them on a one-off basis, issue by issue, forest by forest right around Australia. The IDC certainly will look at that. I am happy for that to be done; I have no argument with it at all. Senator Watson asked me whether our procedures are deficient because we are having IDCs. I think there is a great deficiency when it comes to land use in Australia. The great deficiency is that the Commonwealth has so little power over it. It is because of that that we have seen such extraordinary land and soil degradation around Australia.

I cannot say that the remarks that Senator Boswell has made about me have been all that complimentary. I will just have to learn to live with them. I will say something nice about Senator Boswell. It will take all the decency that I can muster within me to say that Senator Boswell is perhaps the only senator in the Opposition who has ever shown a real concern for soil loss, soil degradation and salinity. The fact that he has is to his credit. I only hope that, as a result not only of this IDC but also of inquiries being made by CONCOM, we can get some sort of rational national plan to deal with what I believe is by far the nation's biggest environmental problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have suddenly discovered it. When did you discover it? When did you talk about it before?

—I have been talking about it for a long time. If we are talking about sudden discoveries the honourable senator's interest in the environment is pretty sudden-so sudden in fact that he still has not discovered it. We wonder when and if he ever will.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go through some of the other comments that have been made by so many speakers in this debate. I have talked about the problem raised by Senator Watson concerning deficient procedures. If we are to have any procedure for settling our arguments on forestry-that is only one of the environmental problems in Australia-we have to look at a way in which we can integrate Commonwealth decisions with State decisions. We have to make sure that the attitudes of all departments on this are sought. That is what is being done by the IDCs. The IDCs are a result of a government decision taken some time back. The honourable senator asked me for a date. I do not remember but I think a pretty fair guess would be that it was last November or December-certainly a long time prior to the Caucus debate to which the honourable senator referred in the question he asked me the other day.

I have tried in the past to make some things clear to Senator Boswell but I have had difficulties because I am not sure whether anything can be made clear to him. Senator Boswell stood up in this chamber and told us how wonderful it was that the Queensland Government had reduced its cutting quotas from 195,000 cubic metres to 60,000. In fact, it was in stages. As I recall it, it went from 195,000 to 130,000 and then to 60,000. I am pleased that those quotas were cut. Nonetheless, is that not an acknowledgment that those yields were never sustainable? Is it not the case that for years and years the Queensland Forestry Department held itself up as a model of sustainable yield forestry. What happened? The model kept going wrong so the model had to be changed each year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—That is exactly what happened. The cutting quota went from 195,000 to 130,000 and then to 60,000. Why? Because the 195,000 gave the industry only a few years life. It was all going to be dead after a couple of years. As it is, the reductions that the Queensland Government made caused enormous unemployment-much more than this decision can cause. I keep noticing that when we get to the numbers of people who will lose their jobs as a result of this decision of the Federal Government, the numbers creep up and up. Tonight, and in the last couple of days, I noticed that we seem to have settled on a figure of 3,000. The difficulty that I have with the figure of 3,000 is that it is not the number that even the industry or the unions claim will be made unemployed as a result of this decision. When I met with the industry and with the unions I was told that the numbers were somewhere around 600 to 700. I have not seen a scrap of evidence to suggest that those figures are wrong. The industry has not changed its figures so I have not either. I have stuck with the same figures.
—Why don't you put the environmental and social impact statements on the table and then we will all know.

—I ask Senator Boswell to remain calm. I worry about his health when he gets so excited. I am sure that the Temporary Chairman, who is a doctor, is noticing that as well. I look at those north Queensland figures knowing that, in a very short time, I will be going to Cabinet and I will be getting a package of compensation of jobs and money for north Queensland. It is at that point that the question of Queensland's cooperation will become rather important because a lot of money and a lot of jobs will be able to be provided. It will then be up to the Queensland Government to decide just how much of the interests of north Queensland it really has at heart. If it has the interests of north Queensland at heart it will cooperate with the Federal Government not just to manage the area but also to make sure that jobs and money can be provided to north Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what the Commonwealth Government is about but it is not what the Opposition is about. It is prepared, in concert with some of its State colleagues, to stand in the road of any package of compensation. They can attempt to do it, but when the crunch comes the pressure from the people will be so great that they will all have to back off. I do not know what Premier Ahern's attitude will be on this question. However, I know that I will be talking to him in the next few weeks and I hope that once the package is announced I will have his full cooperation in delivering services, jobs and money to the people of north Queensland.

Let me turn now to the remarks made by other honourable senators. Senator Parer seems to be convinced that the nomination will not be accepted in December. Of course, we heard that about the nomination for Kakadu. We will hear it about this nomination for the rest of the year and we will be sending teams of people overseas. No doubt the Queensland Government, the Tasmanian Government and the Northern Territory Government, as usual, will have junkets everywhere. Of course, the hearings will not be held in Paris this year. As is my lot in life, when it comes to my turn to attend they are switched to Brasilia. Nonetheless, there will be hordes of officials from different governments turning up in Brasilia and arguing against the nomination. However, just as with all the speeches about what would happen in, say, our High Court cases, the realities are that the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) has made very clear the values that it puts on those forests. Indeed, senator MacGibbon is strong on quoting the IUCN. In 1984 it passed a resolution calling on Australia to nominate the wet tropics rainforests-

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that why you did it?

—Australia is now complying with that resolution. Senator Parer asked why we do it. We do it because we have a commitment to heritage values. We do it because we are signatories to the World Heritage Convention. One wonders where were these voices then. Where was Senator Walters? Where was Senator MacGibbon? Where was Senator Watson? Most honourable senators opposite were somewhere other than in the Senate, but why did not most of those who were here complain to the Prime Minister-I think his name was Malcolm Fraser-when he pursued the Kakadu nomination? Senator Durack made a speech about Kakadu. Senator Stone interjected about Kakadu. Where were they when Malcolm Fraser proceeded with that nomination? I suggest they were all sitting here agreeing with him.

SPEECH.PARA: Even Senator MacGibbon might have had some regard for the magnificent values of that area. Even Senator Walters might have had some regard for the values of that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —She wouldn't.

—I am sorry. I withdraw that. Senator Sanders is right: Senator Walters would have had no regard whatsoever for the magnificent values of Kakadu. Fortunately there seems to be a majority of senators who do have some regard for the value of the wet tropics.
—Tell us what stage we are talking about?
—I shall not take up what stage Senator Walters is at.
—Forget about her.
—Senator McKiernan is correct; this is a time for restraint.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, on a point of order: Senator Richardson deliberately misunderstood my interjection. Stage 1 of Kakadu National Park was nominated.
—No point of order is involved.

—I am disappointed that the debate has gone this long on clause 1. Obviously the Opposition will attempt to deny the legislation passing through the Parliament this week. I hope that is something we can overcome because, come 1 April, the Opposition wants to see the loggers go back into the wet tropics rainforest, but the Government intends to make sure that they do not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the debate seems to have revolved around logging in Queensland and Tasmania. I share the concerns of those States about their logging. However, my fears are more for Western Australia and what might happen in that State in due course. Having listened to references to logging all day, I hope I will be excused for making a few of my own observations. Senator Coulter from South Australia and Senator Sanders from Tasmania suggested that timber is a non-renewable product. My family has been involved with a forest in the alpine area of Europe. We have traced back the history of that forest for 1,000 years, and some of the timber was logged as recently as six months ago. It has been logged for 1,000 years. No doubt that forest goes back to before the Roman times.
—Is it a rainforest?

—It is a forest. So much for that sort of argument. Senator Bjelke- Petersen said that Queensland had been logged for 100 years. That is a short period. I turn to more of the Democrats' hypocritical suggestions that I heard in this chamber today and on other occasions. If they eat meat, drink milk, drive cars, wear clothes or build houses, they are hypocrites. Every house has some timber in its roof. If any of the Democrats will say they do none of those things, I shall be the first to say that they are not hypocrites.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to Western Australia and the Kimberley region and Shark Bay. This Bill will encompass those areas in time. Senator Sanders need not worry about that, because that will happen. In fact, tomorrow at Shark Bay--

TALK.START.PARA: —How much rain falls there?

—This has nothing to do with rainforest, so do not worry about how much rain falls on Shark Bay. This Bill encompasses all conservation and world heritage. Shark Bay and the Kimberleys are on the Australian Conservation Foundation hit list. If honourable senators have not seen the hit list I shall show it to them. That hit list was incorporated in Hansard the other day. It includes the Kimberleys and Shark Bay, so I need excuse myself no further for talking about those areas. Tomorrow evening a meeting will be held at Shark Bay. That area is a sensitive region, having been recognised by pastoralists and the State Government alike as such for quite a number of years. An arrangement has been made as to how it can be farmed or worked as a pastoral station. A pastoral board controls how much stock can be run on a pastoral lease. I do not think there would be any argument from the Australian Democrats on that. In a sensitive region the stringent conditions of how much stock can be run have been made even more stringent. Under present conditions one sheep could probably be run on 200 acres. What do the conservationists want? They want to turn that area over to World Heritage listing or whatever and then, as everyone says, let the tourists in.

—On a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. I draw your attention to standing orders 269, 438, 440 and 441 which have to do with disorder in the chamber. When Senator Panizza was speaking he had his foot on the furniture. That is a disorderly act and I ask that he refrain from despoiling the furniture.
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Panizza is addressing clause 1 of the Bill.

—I shall remove my foot from the chair. However, if I see honourable senators, especially in that direction, with their feet on the furniture in future, I shall take them up on that. I return to Shark Bay. The conservationists want to drive out the fourth generation pastoralists who have had leases for the past 113 years. They will be given reasonable compensation, but only if the whole of their stations are taken, not just parts of them. The conservationists want to let tourists in wholesale. If the conservationists wanted to take over that sensitive area and lock it up for all time, I might have found some excuse for them. However, they want to let in the tourists. I shall come to Senator Richardson's comment about tourists and wool. The tourists will do far more damage to that sensitive area than would one sheep grazing on 200 acres. The other day Senator Richardson told the Senate that tourism is now worth more to Australia than is the wool clip. I should like to see the figures researched before they are ever repeated in this place, because I totally disagree with that statement. The point I make to Senator Richardson is that when the sheep are shorn and fleeced this year, they will be there to be fleeced next year. But the tourists will not be there to be fleeced a second time. They can be fleeced only once.

SPEECH.PARA: Returning to the Kimberleys, that is a vast pastoral region. As I said, it is on the hit list. When it is taken, what will happen to the cattle that are left there? The pastoralists will be driven out, but they will not be able to get rid of the rest of the cattle. What will the Government do? Will it use helicopters like it did in Kakadu National Park, as we saw in a photo in the Australian shooting willy-nilly--
